Bottle. Dark brown pour with a thick mocha head. Floral, mocha coffee, charcoal, brown sugar, caramel. Good carbonation. Lighter than expected body with short finish. Pretty nice

Bottled. A black beer with a large and creamy beige head. Aroma is malty, roasted malt, brown sugar and yeasty. Taste is sweet malty, roasted, chocolate, coffee. Nice balancing bitterness. Medium to full body
Noire, effervescence moyenne, col brun moyen. Un peu de tout pour ce très bon stout: du corps, du café noir, du pain grillé, de la réglisse, du chocolat noir et un peu de fruits foncés. Excellent!

Bottle. 2006 edition. Pours pitch black with a dense creamy brown head. The aroma is chocolate, deep roasted malt and ripe dark fruit. The flavor is only light oxidized and has notes of prunes, chocolate, cocoa, roasted malts and raisins. A little sour malty touch. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle; Pour is murky brown, with a modest khaki colored heat into this glass; it retains average / above average, with some light spotting present. This is what you want out of the style ; the nose is licorice, spice, coffee bean, with sweet bread and a certain nuttiness present. The flavor profile reveals a cola like body and carbonation ; moving to grasses, light smoke, chocolate, caramel, with some grassy hops and a bit of licorice. It has a lingering finish that has a nice feeling -

Bottle. Pours a near black color with a huge tan head on it. Nose is slightly roasty with some very subtle non-sweet chocolate notes and some hints at some licorice. Taste is slightly sour with some subtle roasting in there.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 Typical Belgian stout, sweet and full of extra ingredients like nuts, licorice and spices. Good one.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 bottle @ home. schiuma beige abbastanza grossolana per una stout, molto persistente. birra di colore marrone scuro riflessi ramati, velata. aroma abbastanza intenso fruttato di ciliegia acerba, luppolo vecchio, un po di tostatura ed un odore acre che ricorda le fermentazioni miste. Note di zucchero di canna grezzo. il gusto è totalmente diverso. intenso e persistente è abbastanza acido, dolce abboccato poi sul finale amaro da tostatura. si riconoscono caffè, noce e liquirizia. molto carbonata, corposa, ha un ottimo equilibrio, infatti i 9 gradi sono scomparsi, ma non é totalmente armonica. annusandola ci siaspetterebbe tuttaltro. sembra una belgian dark strong amara... stranissima ma molto buona.

Bardzo dobre piwo tresciwe i przede wszystkim palone i moze troche za slodkie w pierwszej chwili, ale potem przechodzi w dlugi wytrawny finisz i lekko gozki. Piwo niesamowicie wyglada, czarne jak prawdziwy stout, piana bezowa i lekko brazowawa, gigantyczna i drobno pecherzykowa, rosnie w oczach, do konca utrzymuje sie. Polecam milosnikom dobrych stoutow.
Réservée uniquement à l'exportation, de plus en plus rare, un brassin d'exception, à déguster sans modération.

33cl bottle into tulip. Lille. 

Appearance: dark brown with slight ruby tint. Tan head with good stability. 

Aroma: chocolate, coffee, spice notes, alcohol. 

Taste: on the sweeter side with a nice bitter coffee finish.

Palate: full body from very active carbonation. Somewhat tingly on your tongue. Good long finish. 

Overall: not what I would typically consider a stout, but very good jut the same. A very nice aroma and flavor are this beers best attributes. Feels very warm in my stomach.

0,33l fles gedeeld met Nikos. Donker bruin met gistdeeltjes. Brood en hop in de geur, smaak is wat wrang en droog. Lijkt ook erg op een barley wine, jammer maar deze tussenweg tussen een barley wine en stout komt niet helemaal uit de verf.

A good Belgian stout, but I still think the American stouts have them beat. This one is nicely nuanced, with good stout malt base and an initial sweetness that gives way to a coffee-flavored dryness before surfacing again. Surprisingly thin mouthfeel tho for the ABV. Overall, B+

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Schwarz, schöne beige schaumkrone, eher stark karbonisiert, malzig kaffig im aroma, im geschmack und nachklang kafferöstig, abgang etwas rasch und "fad", mässige bittere

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Delicious stout, full of fruits on the aroma and flavours. Bitter tart and aromatic, it must be enjoyed again, so I can actually list the incredible fruit basket that it offers.

Rated from beer log during 2009 Belgium trip... Color is black, aroma of sweet malts, dark chocolate... Roasted malt flavor with notes of alcohol, espresso... Sweet finish, interesting stout

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

January 2011 bottle to a tulip glass. Pours a dark brown/black with a big mocha head that subsides rather quickly. Aroma is yeast, prunes, raisin, molasses. Taste is raisin bread, licorice, and roasted coffee with chocolate and bitterness in the finish. Sweetness is cut by the alcohol bite. Thin medium mouthfeel with some effervescence. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33 cl, flaske, 9,0 %, nydt på Ørsted Ølbar, 15. september 2013.
Rating no 100 på ratebeer. Kaffesort imperial stout med højt flot moccafarvet skum, ca. 4 cm. Det tætte skum minimeres til ca 1/2 cm efter et par minutter.
Meget skøn aroma, som minder én om en belgisk strong ale med mere frugt end kaffe og indeholder noget friskt. 
Syrlighed og sødme i skøn symbiose i smagspaletten! Masser af smag af den gode gær. Uhm, denne øl er lige efter min smag... Middel kulsyreindhold. Lang halvsyrlig eftersmag. De Dolle har gjort det igen: givet en fantastisk øloplevelse! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

found this one in a pub. poured a dark brown colour with a small brown head. aroma is sweet with coffee and chocolate and some caramel. taste isnt that strong bit of a watery coffee, with some dark fruits, caramel, raisins, hints of smoke.
33 cl. bottle. Pours almost black with a nice tan head. Aroma of roast, chocolate, fruit, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruits, caramel, and licorice. Enjoyable.

0.33 l bottle. Black colour with s thick light brown head. Roasted caramell and malty sweetness, hints of hops. Caramell, dark fruits, roasted and coffee flavour. Mediym body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ar: Acedic sourness, some dark caramel.
Ap: Deep brown, lots of chunky yeast, with an enormous and rocky light tan head with great retention.
T: Acedic sourness up front, with a cherry and leather quality - some cola and plum - the sourness and acidity really dominate.
P: Medium body with exceptionally high carbonation - finish is very dry.
O: It is difficult to find the stout in this beer as the sourness has almost completely taken over.

Poured from a bottle dark brown with a tan head aroma is interesting smells strong and sour. The taste is sour as well hard to
Detect anything but sourness

From a 33 cl bottle shared at home. Pours black with a massive tan head. Was a bit of a gusher. Metallic caramel nose. Flavors of plum, licorice and raisins. Very effervescent mouth feel. Moderately bitter finish.

Drank this on the Manitoba bridge in Bruges in honour of fallen Canadians who took Bruges in WW2. The aroma has a smoky wood note with tons of coffee, licorice and espresso. Bitter and heavy with a bitter chocolate and tons of roasted malts and espresso. Not balanced at all but very tasty.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Pours brown to black with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, honey, caramel, caramel, dried fruits, flavor is dry with malt acidity, roasted chocolate, fruitiness, medium bodied

At a tasting, thanks zvikar, lively bubbley head, deepish brown colour, yeasty and rubbery aroma with some roasted coffee behind, feels quite astringent, flavour of roasted coffee and charred wood, light bodied and much too sour. Quite difficult to drink.

33cl bottle. Pours deep dark brown, almost black, with medium beige creamy head. Looks really good. The aroma is a blend of caramel, yeast, chocolate and roasted malts. Gives the impression that its quite sweet. It definetly is when tasting: lots of licorice and caramel notes with a touch of dark chocolate. Hints of ripe fruits as well. Medium/creamy mouthfeel, perfect carbonation. Its a good beer, not my style of Stout though.

Bottle at Monks. Pours a near black, dark brown with one finger of fluffy mocha head. Nose of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, spice. Full body with a lot of roasted malt and spice. Sweet with bitter roast and hop finish.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours black in color with a beige head. Burnt wood, cold coffee and notes of licorice in aroma. Coffee and bitter chocolate in taste. A bit of licorice and bitter chocolate in aftertaste. Feels a bit raw somehow on the whole. Enjoyed as morningcoffee outside by the sea.

Bottle bought from the Bier Tempel in Brugge, Belgium (last year). A black coloured pour with a very healthy tan/beige head on top. Roasty, malty, chocolate aroma. Tastes similar, roasty, malty, chocolate, some coffee, slight bitterness towards the end.
2013 - 06 - 07 330ml bottle. black colour. medium, lasting, tan head. roasty, chocolate in aroma. medium bitter, light sweet taste.

Bottle. 9.0%. Best before June 2013. Pours dark brown/black with a big, dark tan head. Rather sweet aroma, roasted, with a hint of liquorice and a light metallic overtone. As it warms a hint of vanilla appears as well as tart and dark fruit notes. Flavour is roasted and tart ,with dark fruit notes and a light metallic overtone. Bitter roasted finish with a mild alcohol burn. Lingering tart grassy note. Overall pretty good. The tart notes clashes a bit with the other notes though. 07.06.13.

June 2010 bottle showing very nicely! Pours pitch black wih gushing foamy head that sticks around. No lacing. Nose is espresso. Aromas are well
Layered, vanilla, espresso, dark fruit, some nuttyness and toasted bread.. Tastes are medium/heavy sweet and medium bitterness. Body is foamy. Lovely!

Nose is chocolate malt, a soft smokiness and some sour cherries. Initially sour, the chocolate malts and smooth body come through later. Some dried pit fruits and some raisin. A soft sour finish with a touch of roast. Nothing too out there, but still quite pleasant.
330 ml bottles on several occasions. Pours pitch black with a nice marroon head. Sweet body, roasty and malty taste. Full chocolate. Nice.

Stout belga di colore nero intenso con schiuma eccellente. Al naso si sente lalcool, forse troppo per il suo stile. In bocca lalcool si sente meno, vengono fuori sentori di cioccolato, liquirizia e tostato per un gusto rotondo.

12 oz. bottle from Nikki Liquors. The vintage is 2012 or maybe 2011. Snifter shows pitch black with a ring of off white head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, candi sugar, light licorice notes and caramel. Im now guessing this did sit awhile before I bought it last year. Light oxidation. Flavors of cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, light char, light licorice notes and plenty of dark fruit. The body is a bit thinner then I want. No alcohol noticeable. Overall, it just a bit above average.

Encore un stout belge, donc pour les States, un foreign stout (?) : sorry, what does it mean ?
Nouvelle classification de bière : les foreign stout  Quest-ce que vous avez pris ce soir ?	
Oh moi, juste un foreign stout  Mais le foreign, il se pointe à 98/98. Pas mal le gars...
Vous écoutez un blues . Oui, mais cest un foreign blues. Ah oui, cest pas bien alors 
Bref, servez-moi « just a stout, please ... ».
Par les Dolle Brouwers, et pour le marché US précisément  Sont fous ces Dolle (fous en
flamand). Titre à 9 % abv... Je sens que ça va faire mal 
Couleur noir dencre (de Chine). Pas la bière, lencre !
Clarté absolument nulle, mon colonel . On ny voit rien là dedans, poussez-vous...
Bulles indétectables, mon colonel, on doit tirer à vue (si je puis dire ).
Mousse très belle, couleur moka, épaisse, à flocons moyens et crème en haut. Je prends, mon
colonel  ah bon, je nai pas droit à la parole  bien, mon couillon, mais je prends malgré tout.
Arômes de café, réglisse, pointe de coriandre et cerise (noire, bien sûr), touche de tarte aux
myrtilles.
1ère bouche très forte de café expresso de grande classe, avec des notes de mûres et de pain
fortement grillé. Arrière-bouche bien verticale sur du café, puis céréales, puis levure.
2ème bouche déjà plus équilibrée, avec de fortes touches de malt et du bois flammé.
3ème bien fondue (je nai pas dit foutue, mon colonel, pas de ça chez nous. Oui, mon colonel,
je la ferme ) Grande amplitude avec des nuances de fruits noirs.
Arrière-bouche sur le café avec un houblon superbe.
La longueur ne fait quamplifier tout cela (non, je nai pas fini, mon colonel, je ne fais que 
commencer, et puis vous commencez à me bourrer solidement ). Nous avons des sublimes
gorgées de classe pure, équilibrées mais fortes, puissantes. 
La levure est dun très haut niveau, dune veine splendide.
Lalcool est bien dosé, parfait. (mon colonel, avec tout le respect que je vous dois, je vous 
le dis, cet alcool pète très fort. Non pas lennemi, mon colonel. Cest dans mon verre)
La finale, ah la finale, quelle finale. Un feu dartifice (non, il ny a pas le feu, mon colonel,
cest dans mon verre  oui encore, mon colonel  Il est con, ce colonel).
Les Dolle sont peut-être des fous, mais ils savent brasser (non on na pas pris leau, mon 
colonel, je parle de brasser de la bière .. Il est fou, ce colonel). Ils savent même brasser
des « foreign stout », une catégorie normalement impossible à brasser, puisquelle nexiste
pas !!! Et puis je vous le dis mon colonel, je vous  non, mon colonel, je vous  oui,
mon colonel... je vous reçois 5 sur 5 . Dailleurs, je donne un 5... (oui, mon colonel, jai 
atteint lobjectif  Ils sont tous à terre) Et moi aussi, dailleurs ...
Bottle from App Vintner - pours pitch, with a nice roasty nutty chocolate aroma. Taste is a little sweet. Nice!

Bottle. Pours a near black color with a huge tan head on it. Nose is slightly roasty with some very subtle non-sweet chocolate notes and some hints at some licorice. Taste is slightly sour with some subtle roasting in there. Not my favorite in the stout family.

Ottimo aspetto, si presenta di un bel nero, schiuma di una buona persistenza. Al naso offre subito i sentori tipici dei malti tostati, ma lascia percepire anche sentori leggermente affumicati e pepe. Gusto molto complesso, diverso da una tipica stout, oltre al caffè, cacao e liquirizia si possono distinguere anche aspetti vinosi di frutta rossa matura. Il corpo sostiene molto bene il grado alcolico, che non risulta affatto eccessivo. Molto particolare.
Aroma is earthy malts, chocolate and raspberries.  The flavor is dark malts, a burnt quality in there, chocolate, a thick/course texture from the sediment and a mix of fruit and milk acidity.

330 ml bottle into snifter, bottled in June 2012.  Pours nearly pitch black color with a huge 2-3 finger foamy and rocky light tan head with incredible retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Thick soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a ton of streaming carbonation retaining the head.  Aromas of chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, raisin, toast, candi sugar, coffee, light clove, licorice, and yeast earthiness.  Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of roasted malt notes with moderate fruity/spicy yeast notes.  Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, light char, raisin, toast, light clove, candi sugar, light licorice, and yeast earthiness.  Lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, toast, candi sugar, raisin, light clove, and earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Damn nice balance and complexity of roasted malt notes with light-moderate yeast esters; with zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a damn nice Belgian style export stout.  All around nice balance and complexity of roasted/yeast ester flavors; and quite smooth to sip on.  A very enjoyable offering.
Huge tan head, fruity and medium roast on aroma.  Fruity and slightly sweet  with low coffee & roast. Slick and prickly mouthfeel, high carbonation
Pours black with creamy tanned head. Aroma is chocolate, dark fruits, candy sweetness, coffee. Taste is chocolate, candy sugar, coffee, bitter aftertaste. Very well balanced.
Dark black color. Aromas of coffee and chocolate. Taste the same, with some malt and liquorish aftertaste. Nice beer.

11.2 oz bottle bottled Jan 2010 as an extra from adamjackson. Poured 90%head and 10%body, super full slightly fizzy beige head over a medium density black body once it settles down. Aroma of soy sauce, black olives, musty cellar and some dark chocolate. Body has lively fizzy carbonation with a quicker fading aftertaste for what a big beer this is. Flavor of dark melted chocolate, burnt toast, old coffee beans, vanilla and some soy with black olives.

2006 vintage bottle shared from Deanso.  Pours dark brown, almost black with a beige head.  Aroma is musty, licorice, overripe dark fruit and port aspects, a touch of vanilla and chocolate and caramel.  Flavour is moderate  to heavy sweet and light bitter.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.  Excellent
Bottle at hbf13. Black with light brown head. Roasted licorice aroma, some alcohol, coffee. Strong licorice and coffee taste, hoppy finish, vanilla.
Aroma is a bit subdued, sweetness, hints of other stout notes. Black beer, brown head. Taste is light sweetness, coffee, bit hoppy alcohol finish. Could ne a bit stronger finish, dry. Medium body.

Bottle from Dedollewaitor, ta. Jet black with a tan pockmarked head. Aroma is dark fruity. Flavour is chocolate, liquorice, raspberry on a salty base. Finish is a bit like soft centred Christmas day sweets
11.2oz bottle to hotel glass. Nice dry stout. Plenty of hop bite. Very lively carbonation.
Pours opaque black with a tan soapy head.  Aroma of chocolate, caramel, and licorice.  Coffee, roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, and dark fruit flavor.  A tad hot.  Very nice beer!

11.2 oz bottle.  Cap says June 2010.  (did not notice that when buying at BOTW)  Started pouring down middle of glass... mistake... like a volcano.  Most carbonation in a beer in a long time.  Head slowly disapated.  ok lacing.   Extremely dark pour.  Aroma is chocolate, caramel, some dark fruit, and licorice. Palate is moderate and highly carbonated. Some light sour fruit elements in the taste, and alcohol with a bitter chocolate finish.  The alcohol was too noticeable for my taste.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. On the dry side with lots of chocolate and coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Another one courtesy of the cool Icelanders :). I have to rerate this one eventually, bit ashamed of the vagueness of the ratings that day. Anyway.... impressive appearance, black, dark head. Slightly sourish, red wine barrel like notes build on a heavy malty background. Coffee is the main thing in the taste though, and basically carries this. And thats it for my notes. Damn.
UPDATED: APR 16, 2013 Original rating 7.8.2010. Pours black with a nice head. Aroma coffee, chocolate. licorice. Full bodied. Not Bad.

Black in color tan head with good lacing. Smell roasted malts brown sugar and some fruit like raspberry. chocolate fades to toasty coffee slightly bitter with a bit of fruit. Nice creamy light mouthfeel coats tounge leaveing pleasent aftertaste. Overall very good.

Dark brown body with brown head. Strong malt aroma. Taste is a little different. Creamy body. Flavor is mainly roasted malt but with some sweetness that is different. Not sure what the flavor is, fruits? Hop finish is a little present compared to a more choclately one that i would like. Pretty good and a little different, Im fine with a good  American stout though.

Amazing discovery, i was used to sweeter or bitter dark/black beers. And this one was recommended by the people over at moeder lambik. At first i couldnt quite situate the taste, but this one sneaks in quietly. I think i finished this in 1h time, and really enjoyed it. caramel, chocolate, coffee, roasty, cheese aromas and salty taste

Cerveza negra con mucha espuma de color marrón claro. El olor tiene algo que me recuerda al vino tinto. Cuerpo medio y bastante seco. Sabor especiado, un poco picante, con notas ácidas y un fondo a café expresso riquísimo. No se notan los 9º de alcohol.

Bottle. Pours black with a massive tan head, excellent retention/lacing. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, licorice, dark fruit, light metallic notes. Taste is licorice/dark fruit, chocolate, more metal. Palate is soft, a bit oily/slick, light bitter finish. Interesting.

33 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20100327.
Pours dark brown color with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel, dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and cocoa. Flavor of toasted malts, cocoa, caramel and coffee. Dry palate. Excellent.

2013.02.10 - De Dolle Extra Export Stout - 11.2oz bottle in goblet glass.  Bottle cap marked "Bottled JUN2010". 

Pours a very nice deep chestnut brown which becomes dark brown to black when the glass is full. Huge 1-2 inch foamy caramel head settles to about a 1cm lacey foamy head. 

Aroma is basic Belgian earthy yeast.  You get some peppery notes, and some roast aroma. 

Mouthfeel is medium heavy.  Carbonation seems adequate but possibly a little light.  A bit of a creamy feel but it's mostly from remaining foamy head, though some is from the malt.

Taste is nice.  Malty sweetness is evident on the front end, and then carbonation, roasty malt and a bit of tang on the middle. spicy and perhaps a bit pepper on the middle.  Little to no alcohol for 9% abv.  Maybe a bit of licorice as other reviewers noted.

A nice Belgian stout.

Aroma 6/10, Appearance 4/5, Taste 7/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 16/20

33 cl. bottle poured in to a snifter. Pitch black with a massive, cloudy, tan head. Sweet aroma with fruity and roasted malts notes, red berries, coffee, chocolate and licorice. Taste is sweet. Medium to full body, creamy texture, and a soft carbonation. Finishes lightly bitter with yeasty notes. Complex - good.

330 ml. bottle. Bottled June 2012. Pours an enormous, well retained, tiny bubbled, beige head, with extensive lacing, over a reddish brown (SRM 24) body....nose is chocolate dried fruits including plum and fig....taste is light chocolate, dried fruits, vanilla,  barest hints of sourness, finishing with a moderate coffee, hop bitterness.....mouth feel thick, creamy, slightly sticky, minimal astringency, alcohol warmth present, carbonation adds light spritz.. This is a wonderfully complex, well balanced beer. The ABV is high for a Foreign Stout, but it otherwise it is not heavy enough to be an Imperial. BJCP 8/3/15/5/7

Black plum color, with some ruby shining and beige and foamy head.   Dark chocolate, coffee and liquorice with a back of Porto wine. Slightly more bitter than a traditional stout, has a deep taste, very well balanced, to yeast, coffee and liquorice with nuts. Pretty good beer.

Bottled in 2010.  A dark brown stout with a short and creamy tan head.  Nice and roasty chocolate malt aroma.  Flavor is soft chocolate malt and mild raisin with a slightly tangy finish.  Mild bitterness and sweetness.  Relatively thin body with a creamy mouthfeel.  Well hidden ABV.  The flavor could be a little more robust.

Tap. Black with a thick lasting khaki brown head. Aroma is mild sweet roast, red berries, raisins, prunes and slightly acidic. Taste is medium/heavy sweet, body is medium/full, average carbonation, creamy texture. Pretty complex and interesting but also very drinkable.

Draft. Pours very dark with with a huge and extremely long lasting foamy tan head. Aroma is complex with berry aromas, raisins, red berries, musk, chocolate, dark cherries, dark sugar, lacto-acidic,hops, cocoa, nuts.Taste is medium sweet, bitter and light+ sour. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is above average. Finishes with coffee, chocolate and dried fruit. Interesting brew - its unconventional and the nose is intriguing and quite inciting. I´ll have to try this one again.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2016 Refrigerated 11.2 oz. brown bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black with medium brown head.  Nice medium small bubble lacing, thick body, medium carbonation, and sweet roasted aroma.  Taste is sweet roasted malt, milk chocolate, and cherries,  This is hands down the best foreign stout I have had.

donker bruin met zeer schuimige witte kraag.
aroma: chocolade, toffee, kruidig, geroosterde mouten, chocomout, kandij suiker.
smaak: kruidig, notig en zure tonen.
indruk: hij proeft behoorlijk alcoholisch, kruidig, espresso en zuur en metalig.
onprettig

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2014 Kaatuu lasiin hyvin tummanruskeana/mustana, vaahto on runsas, kestävä ja väriltään vaaleanruskea. Hajussa on marjaisuutta, mausteisuutta, tummaa/kuivattua hedelmää, paahdetta ja kevyesti lakritsia. Maku on todella lakritsinen, joka vyöryy suuhun vahvasti. Sen lisäksi löytyy yrttiä, juurimaisuutta, hiven marjaisuutta ja lopussa pippurista mausteisuutta. Suutuntuma on hiilihappoinen ja melko täyteläinen sekä melko pehmeä. Todella hyvän makuinen vahvan belgin ja stoutin hybridi, jossa tuoksu ja maku poikkesivat paljon toisistaan. Lakritsi on pääosassa.

Aromas of fruits and esters. Smells like they used a Belgian trippel yeast or something. I think I like the aroma best actually. Very unique for a stout. Color is a cloudy dark brown, possibly because I just flew back with it from a ski trip. Flavors of bitter chocolate, dark roasted malts, and similar fruits to a quad. Finishes dry, but with a lingering fruit.
Bottiglia. Fantastica export stout dallo spiccato aroma di espresso e un retrogusto leggermente torbato, 9 gradi praticamente inesistenti, un cioccolatino al caffè da regalarsi e assaporare a pieno!

Ottima. Nel bicchiere nera con abbondante schiuma. Aroma di cioccolato al latte e di cappucino. Il malto tostato è relegato da qualche parte sotto quel manto nero  e fa fatica ad uscire. Al palato cremosa, liscia, suadente. Ritornato i sentori di cappuccino e cioccolato al latte resi caldi e suadenti dalla presenza notevole dellalcol (9 di ABV). A me è piaciuta un casino. Il papillon colpisce ancora.
Bottle @ Restaurang Treskillingen. Dark brown, almost black, colour with a large dark head. Aroma of malt, fruit, licorice. Rather dry. Bitter flavour of malt, chocolate, licorice.
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2014 Dark with brown foam. Taste of coffee and chocolate. Bitter stout and some sour hints. But too much carbonation in my opinion.
Black body, brown head. Aroma has roasted round maltiness, fruits, yeast. Nice roasted to ashy flavour. Some berries. Flavour is bit onesided, too heavily carbonated.

Bottle on many occasions, one recently with Bill, pours a black color. Notes of nuts, wood, chocolate, roasted malts, plenty of hop bite from the nugget hops. A delicious sticky palate with long lasting flavors.

Poured from 330 ml bottle at Cork & Bowl restaurant in Occoquan, VA.

Opaque, deep dark brown with large tan head and very good lacing.

Aroma of caramel, toffee, dark fruit, and sweet roasted malt.

Taste of roasted malt, caramel, hops and bitter coffee.

Light/medium body and high carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Solid stout.  Pretty dry, medium bodied, with a dark appearance.  Coffee and licorice dominant, but there is some bread and toffee in there as well.

Burnt caramel sweetness like a really dark treacle on the nose. Taste is similar with a strong sweetness married to a roasted earthy note. Fades to strong dark caramelised dark fruits helped along with smooth carbonation. Very tasty and enjoyable for a cold winters night.

Bottle from Beer Merchants. It pours opaque black with a thick tan head. The nose is salted caramel, liquorice, plastic, roasted malt, light smoke and coffee grinds. The taste is espresso coffee, roasted malt, light acidity, soft berry, earth, ash, light sourness and liquorice with a dry, roasty finish. Full body, moderate carbonation and velvety mouth-feel. Complex and well balanced. Im not a great fan of the smell, but it tastes damn delicious.

pours very liquid ( not thick) and dark . white, steady and very fluffy foam. smells stoutish on the bitter side, tastes very bitter as well. i get some coffee, no chocolat.. not overwhelming on anything, very balanced. nice belgian RIS !

On 33 cl bottle.
Black color, brownish foam.
Lightr roasted aromas, malt, choclate and licorice.
Full body & high complexity.
Solid bitterness, and very well balanced.
Very enjoyable

Black pours with a 2 finger, creamy tan head. Huge roast and dark fruit nose up front, some leather, earth, spice, bittersweet chocolate, dense rye bread, licorice and burnt sugar. Flavor is much more licorice forward than the aroma, its pretty strong in a very good way, some chocolate, buttered roast nuts, dark fruit, roast, husky grain and burnt sugar in there as well but the licorice really steals the show for me. Palate is a little too thin and a bit too sharp in carbonation for me, but it doesnt really hurt the experience too much. Pretty good stuff overall.

Dufter af sød lakrids og lidt metallisk. Tynd skum men ellers flot mørk brun. Skummer i munden pga meget kulsyre. Ikke tung. Mørk bitter smag af kakao og vanille og mørke frugter.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 Im going to take the time to re-rate this as something seemed terribly off with my previous review, and as I managed to pick up a bottle recently at Ølbutikken. So here goes... Pours black with a thick light tan head. Aroma is yeast, earth, spices, light roasted malt, nuts. Taste is initial sour - very surprising! - before turning into a distinct coffee bitter finish that lingers. Body is kind of light with lively carbonation. In retrospect, I might have been slightly too harsh on aroma and appearance, but overall I still agree with my previous assessment. This doesnt really come together. The sourness and lively carbonation clashes with the strong coffee finish and the aroma. Its like a mix between an imperial stout and Fanta Lemon. Not entirely pleasant.

Pours dark with off off white head
Sours barley malt tones. Dark fruits, hints of coffee and chocolate
Wow! What is this? A black lambic?
Frizzy frizzy palate. Some sweetness, high sourness, some dark fruits

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Tasted from 33cl sloped Belgian brown bottle (02/2012) into a Willybecher glass. It poured an opaque very dark brown color, hazy reddish at the edges, with ENORMOUS, firm, rocky, purplish-beige foam and lace that never went away. It took four really slow, staggered pours to fill the glass; so persistent it was annoying to be honest. Emphasis was definitely on the Belgian yeast aromas: strong black pepper, clove, plums, figs, black cherries, active compost. Faint burnt grain and noble hops underneath. Aromas and flavors reminiscent of a boozy, sparkling port wine, if there was such a thing. Other flavors were toasty, very melanoidin-y, cidery, light lacto-bacterial sourness, almost no residual body or sweetness. I didnt get the claimed caramel, coffee and chocolate, maybe the slightest hazelnut and licourice. Definite charred grain bitterness, but too highly attenuated to seem anything like a stout.. Palate was very light but alcoholic, extreme carbonation, slick spritzy mouthfeel, lingering overripe fruit and red wine aftertaste. Reminded me of dark Unibroue beers, several Trader Joes Vintage Ales came to mind. Very interesting and tasty; a good Belgian Dark Strong Ale despite its name.

Bottle. Extremely dark pour with a monster of a beige head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, some dark fruit, and licorice. Palate is moderate and highly carbonated. Some light sour fruit elements in the taste, with a bitter chocolate finish.
Very interesting! Amazing nose. Coffee, toffee, chocolate. Definitely some oxidation. Not very bitter, a little lacking in carbonation, over the hill?

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2012 (From notes) Bottle. Black, lots of foam (though the latter might be due to an incorrect glass). Aroma is sweet, some hops. Flavor is dry, bitter, even a bit sour. Dark roasted coffee (burnt). A bit bubbly on the tongue. Perhaps I had improper expectations for this one, as I didnt think it would be so dry and bitter. I will have to try this again one day, though.
Update 16 Nov, 2012: Aroma also has some vanilla. Flavor includes some liquorice. Finish is dry, slight sweetness, bitter. Good thing I tried this again. Certainly better than I first thought it was, but still not quite my thing!

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2012 330 ml bottle. Bottled Jan 2011. BB Jan 2013. From bierkompass.de.
Black colour with big dark tan head.
Dark fruits, roasted malt, chocolate, mild sourness and sweet caramel in interesting aroma. Roasted malt, chocolate and mild fruity hops in flavour. 9% well hidden. Fizzy.

Pours a dark ruby red with a frothy brwonish head.. Aroma of sweet fruit, almost like a lambic. Flavour of dark chocolate malt with some roasted coffee and a slight dry aftertaste. Not quite as good as the initial aroma would have you believe.

Bottle shared at local beer tasting. Black body, small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malty, dark berries, some roast. Taste of malt, licorice, roasty, yeast notes, very nice complexity both in aroma and taste. Finish is dry and pretty hoppy.

Starts off with a bit of dark roasted malt quickly giving way to hints of licorice, coffee, chocolate and a fairly noticeable hop bite. The prickly carbonation still gives off a bit of an off flavor but it isnt as prevalent as in the nose. Finish has a bit of roast and a touch of booze, lingering on the pallet for some time.

Bottle poured black with a medium foamy tan head and minimal lacing.  Aroma is big on roasted malt, licorice, and dark fruits.  Taste explodes with black cherry followed by roasted malt and a hint of vanilla.  Palatable bitterness throughout and an enjoyable smooth finish.

The least impressive De Dolle beer Ive had, yet still has a lot of saving graces. Nose is chocolate malt, a soft smokiness and some sour cherries.  Initially sour, the chocolate malts and smooth body come through later. Some dried pit fruits and some raisin. A soft sour finish with a touch of roast. Nothing too out there, but still quite pleasant.

Des grosses notes de bananes, de chocolat et pain rôti. En la versant on a droit à un tsunami deffervescence qui sestompe aussitôt pour laisser un corps souple et visqueux. Belle promenade sensorielle.
Dark brown colour. Coffee and chocolate aromas. Figs, raisins in the taste.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2014 Bottle July 2012 at Eulogy. Pours flat black with a huge light brown head. Complex burned malt flavors. Dark chocolate coffee caramel. Burnt toast. Charcoal. Turnips? Touch of sweet, sour and smoke but bitterness dominates. Rich full body. Smooth dry finish. Recall more dark red fruit notes in earlier versions. Nice deep stout, though needs a big more age behind it. UPDATE: After having this beer many times in 2012 and 2013, it all but disappeared in Phila during 2014. Now finding again in Nov 2014 but it is a well aged bottle and has turned notably sour. Adds a very different element than what I was expecting. Oddly (or not) the sour element works quite well against the silky dark malts.

11.2 oz bottle, bottled Jan. 2011. Huge foamy light brown head. Black color. Lighter, smooth carbonation. Pretty chunky sediment on the bottom of the glass, here. Drier finish. Roasty aroma, with some molasses, licorice. Bitter light - sour taste. Lightly acidic. Fine, but didnt really hit the spot. The opposite of hearty. Little coffee. Disappointed. Most De Dolle beers Ive tried so far get better as I let them sit for a long period, but this one just stayed kind of "meh".

33cl bottle. Dark brown with very big tanned head. Nose : first strike was the caramel and herbs, Something like a coke. Deeper notes of toffee. Sip : medium density with oily texture. Well carbonated. Personally I think its a bit too much. Sweet and fresh, with toffee background. Burned bread bitterness with slight sweet coffee sour aftertaste. There are some notes of dried fruits like in a typical Belgian dark beer. Nice marriage between a regular stout maltiness and fruity Belgian quandrupel.

Poured from a refrigerated bottle into a snifter. Pours a dark brown with a densely packed head of foam the color of cardboard boxes. The aroma is loaded with rich dark fruits, raisins, figs, and plum. The alcohol presence comes across as a dry tartness, maybe bitterness. Its a fine line that this beer is walking. The taste is interestingly tart with a drying chocolate presence. Some fruit undertones are just floating around in the background. This beer has a ton going on. Its delicious.

11.2oz bottle not sure of the vintage, but it has a bow tie on the neck. pours out a thick rich black topped with a tan head. Aroma of coffee, light smoke, pit fruit, molasses, a little tart. Taste was just as the aroma with a nice smooth body.

Aroma of sweet molasses, slight roast, figs and caramel.  Pours black with a huge head.  Some thick chunks on the bottom giving the head some color.  Taste is smooth and roasty with great sweet candied dates.  Sweet like most de dolles but the roast smoothes it out.  Tasty.

Bottle from Etre Gourmet webshop. Pours pitch black with a huge frothy tanned head. Aroma of dark hard roasted malts, vinous sweetness, coffee and dark bitter chocolate. High carbonated. Taste is smooth, roasty dark caramel, coffee, liquorice and chocolate, full bodied, very good.

330ml bottle. Some roasty, coffee and tart aromas. Pours very dark, with some reddish reflections. Huge tan head, creamy and persistent with some lacework. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Taste is slightly coffee and some tart, fruity and herbal. Really taste and enjoyable. Nice one.

33cl. Bottle. 
Poors black with giant head. 
Aroma coffee, chocolat, malts, sour. 
Taste is bitter coffee, sour. 
Mouth-feel thin. 
Bit to sour but still ok beer.
It smells sour, a bit roasty- coffee, in the aftertaste a bit more roasty-coffee. A sour Stout. 11/10/9/11/-/11

Extreme Gushing!!! The beer in the glass is deep black, with dark brown, high, thick and creamy head. It smells very malty, very much like toffee and caramel, also slightly alcoholic. Starts with a slightly alcoholic note, very malty-roasty, intense coffee note. The middle part has lots of coffee, roasted malt and some alcohol again. Very alcoholic and coffey-roasty finish.

Dark brown bodied with a big rocky, fine tan head. Country cookies, hazelnut, yoghurt, resin. Bit sweet. Still a complex and delicate aroma. Full fomaing mouth feel, interesting mix of light bitter, sweet and sour notes. Not constant, but living in your mouth. Underlining with roasted malts, cream and Beglian yeast sweetness. Some spices. You really need a full bottle of this, I think, not just a sampler, to get to the bottom. Quite a special and very well made brew. I like it! (33cl bottle, reasonably priced)
On tap. Pours a drk black with medium tan head. Aromas of light chocolate and roasted malt. A light light, but nice flavors of espresso and dark chocolate. Somewhat smoky and sour.

Originally reviewed: 10/14/10. Bottle picked up at Brawleys in Charlotte per the suggestion of the lady working there. She said that it was her sons favorite stout. Alright, lets try...

11.2oz bottle poured into an odd-shaped goblet style glass. Popping the cap released an energetic force of carbonation, and this quickly became a gusher. Huge layer of foam when I pour this. It takes a few minutes to pour out the entire contents. The color is sort of a muddy dark chocolate brown. Not as dark as expected. I thought it would be more black. No lace left behind. The frothy capper yields scents of mashed apples, some sour notes, faint yeast, and just hints of roasted character. Not entirely what I expected, but I still like it. 

The excessive gusher should have tipped me off that this would be a highly-carbonated beer. The feel is a bit too spritzy for the style. I like my stouts smooth and creamy, albeit heavy. This one is crisp, sharp, and bordering on harsh. Though it is a bit lighter than expected. This lightness allows me to sip this with greater freedom. The sourness crosses over into the flavor as well. The yeast becomes a big player, but some chocolate comes forward as well. I like the slight roasted quality it has, but the sourness becomes tiring after awhile. Glad I tried this beer, but I probably wouldnt seek this one out again.

AROMA: strong coffee, dark chocolate, nuts, roasty
APPEARANCE: black, brown, frothy
TASTE: light sweetness, medium bitterness, umami, 
PALATE: full body, lively, creamy, astringent, bitter, long finish, 
OVERALL: intense stout dominated with coffee and cocoa beans, lively and nice astringent finish, really creamy.

23 Oct 2010 I wrote this: 33cl Brown bottle, poured into a Westmalle chalice.

Huge foaming head, tan coloured and big bubbled, below was deep dark ruby red body. The head stayed throughout the review, something I always like to see.

Yeast esters fill the nose, add some semi-sweet dark chocolate notes with a background of heavy ground coffee aromas.

The flavours followed the smells almost to the letter, with alcohol coming into the frame, which added the final piece to the brews make-up.

Well carbonated and easy to drink this is one of the best stouts Ive had so far.

Bottled. This one is almost all head on a gentle pour. Expected it as this seems to be a signature of De Dolles house yeast. Incredible. As it settles the liquid is very dark brown and murky beneath that tan head that stays for a long time. The bright nose is yeasty driven, light sweet, roasty, with hazelnut, pit fruit, and spice. The flavor is similar with the yeast and roasted malts doing a dance. Theres also some tartness in with all the coffee and dark chocolate in the mid-palate. Medium body, good carbonation that turns into a fizzy texture, followed by a roasty-bitter-dry-sticky-light finish.

Bottles @Brugge. Dark. Olof with an amazing tan head! The head keeps longer and then a awesome lacing. Aroma is weak roasted malt. Flavor is quite bitter with chocolate, roasted malt and coffee! Mouthfeel is a long bitter roasted malt. Good one!

Pour dark opaque, with a LARGE foamy white head.
Aroma is quite sour, and its hard to get anything other than grapefruit and orange peel. (Not in a good way) Perhaps some coffee and faint hints of chocolate in here as well.
Taste is a little sour, with nothing else going on.
Watery-medium bodied, with harsh and fizzy carbonation.
Dont think it was meant to be like this. ;(

Jan 2010 bottle from Hi Times in Costa Mesa. With the amount of head and the sour chocolate taste, I think this bottle was infected. By the variation in the ratings, I think all the bottles with these dates may be. Meh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33cl bottle. Pours black, with a tan head.
Smells of rasin, brown sugar, roasted malt, bread.
Tastes of a heavy sweetness, with a strong espresso bitterness that lingers, with lots of roasted malt flavors.  Full bodied. Lively carbonation. Texture is oily. Finishes dry and bitter.

Bottle from beerplanet web shop. Almost black color with huge beige head towering over my glass. Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, vanilla. Taste, milk chocolate, dried plums, espresso, roasted malt, vanilla and lot of alcohol. Strong alcoholic, coffee bitter finish. Nice, complex beer.

Pours black with brown head.
Strong smell of dark chocolate and leather.
A lot of foam in your mouth, straight coffee and roasted malt flavours then a nice bitterness. Strange acidity, lack of body?
Some vegetable notes, liquorice and chicory. Dry, as a stout should be. 
If Guiness is dry and strong for U, pass your way!
If you dream of a stronger, dryer and more roasted Guiness type of beer: this is for U!
Cheers

So I first tasted this beer at a Belgian beer festival I was running. It stands out for its complexity and simple drinkability, and was rightly one of the stars of the festival - selling out before anything else.

Its a true biere vivante - rearing up at you as soon as you pop the cap. Pouring is a tricky, lengthy operation.

Once youve tacked getting it in the glass you are confronted by a rocky espresso colored head which dies down eventually after some time, leaving about a cm of decent thick, but not creamy, foam.

The nose is fine with plenty of spice, a dustyness and some slight salty sea tang. The beer itself is black as night, giving way to a cloudy dark coffee it you hold it next to light. Its body for me suits an export stout being just the right side of a syrupy Imperial.

So the important part... Bitter chocolate is the obvious road, but the really good stuff - 80% plus, that immediate lightness followed by the eventual mouth filling all encompassing bittersweetness. But the initial taste is much subtler - candy sugar, quite distinctively Belgian. Layers of tart cherry, raisin biscuit complete the deal.

In my opinion one of the finest stouts available anywhere.

Bought this bottle at State Line late last year. Cap said bottled in Jan. 2010.

A - Pours jet black with a HUGE four and a half finger tall tan head leaving light lace down the glass. This one was extremely over carbonated.

S - Smells of dark roasted grains, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, licorice and some nice hop bitterness. The excessive carbonation gives off an off aroma that really messes with things.

T - Starts off with a bit of dark roasted malt quickly giving way to hints of licorice, coffee, chocolate and a fairly noticeable hop bite. The prickly carbonation still gives off a bit of an off flavor but it isnt as prevalent as in the nose. Finish has a bit of roast and a touch of booze, lingering on the pallet for some time.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Deep, roasty feel with prickly carbonation dancing on the pallet, lingering for quite awhile.

O - This one was ok. The over carbonation really brought it down on all levels. I may revisit this one in the future, I just hope it is better than this one was.

33 cl bottle @ home, bottled 06/2009, BBE 06/2010
Rather strong aroma with some tart notes, belgian yeast, licorice and hay. Palate has too much CO2. Flavour has salty licorice, some coffee and tart citrus notes. A foreign stout with De Dolle twist  complex and nice!

Nice opaque color. Funky, wild nose cherries and maybe with a touch of licorice. Maybe. Great bitter dark chocolate flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Interesting beer with a good long aftertaste but mostly understated.  Little alcohol burn and minimal nose.
light sweet aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice dark bitter chokolate finish

2004 bottle (!) thanks to Claaark13.  Pours black with medium frothy head which recedes after a few minutes.  Rich chocolate on the nose, soft roast,  sharp licorice, and unfortunately cardboard, oxidation notes become more strong and apparent as the beer warms.  Characteristic De Dolle carbonation on the tongue, very lively.  Stale dark malts in the beginning flavor, but fine dark chocolate, roast, espresso in the middle, tartness to finish, musty vintage aftertaste.  Overall still drinkable but a shade of its fresh counterpart.  Please note this review is of a 7-year old bottle.

33 cL bottle from Beers of Europe.  Black as night with plentiful yellow brown creamy head.  Dark roast, a short sharp sour and alcohol hit with a long chocolate aftertaste.  Pleasant lightly roasted malt aroma with a bit of vanilla.  A bit of smokiness on the palate.

Very carbonated. Black pour. Big, foamy, light tan head. Slowly falls leaving a little bit of lacing. Chocolate aroma with hints of roasted coffee. Big sweet chocolate taste that hastily makes way for a carbonic and roasted twang. Way too sweet in the front. Way too bitter in the back.

A black beer with a big, brown head. Aroma is roasted, salt liquirice, chocolate, coffee, some milky sourness, traditional, but it works. Taste is strong, strongly roasted malts are in the main part, nice bitterness and De Dolle like sourness. Medium+ body, lots of carbonation, but not too much. Typical De Dolle flavours give nice and fresh finesse, otherwise strongly roasted and balanced beer.

Bouteille de 330 ml. Arômes très vineux de fruits mûrs, présence de torréfaction et de levure fruitée. Robe brune très foncée, effervescence très active et belle mousse moka qui tient bien. En bouche, la bière montre dabord un côté fruité rappelant les mûres et les raisins secs. Puis, la levure apporte également une complexité fruitée et épicée. On retrouve la torréfaction, assez forte et légèrement astringente, en finale. Lalcool est très peu apparent pour une bière à 9%. Finale assez sèche, favorisée par leffervescence très active. Original et très agréable.
Dark brown color with medium size of-beige head. Chocolate aroma and taste.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 Bottle from Kris. Dark black colour with very persistent and large tan head. When it finally settles down, they describe it quite well. Smells more spicy than a normal stout. Taste curiously bland at first, then comes licorice, then then espresso and the finish goes on and on. Interesting beer.

Bottled 330ml. -at Känguruh, Vienna. Black coloured, medium to big sized brown head, odd sourish coffee hint with notes of alcohol in the nose. Roasted malt, coffee and subdued chocolate with strong dark fruits and heavy alcohol presence. As far as I wanted to be generous to this one I couldnt. Unfortunately alcohol ruined everything, pitty.
Indeed very lively on the tongue, Not a big fan of the explosion of espresso tastes but still a good beer

2009 vintage from my beer cellar
Good off white head.  Decent dark pour.   Lovely smooth aftertaste.  Yummy!

Bottle from Beers of Europe
Black, ruby edges in glass, large tan head which dissipates to thin film.
Aroma of fruit, bit vinous, slightly sour, port, dark fruity chocolate, liquorice, little roast malt aroma. Quite complex and unusual.
Taste of fruity berries, yeast, then roasted malt, chocolate, bit of coffee, liquorice, some sweet malts, alcohol fairly noticeable.
Palate - Medium carb, medium to full body, fruity sweet chocolate in the middle. Finish - bitter roast, some fruit, burnt crust, bit woody, ashy, cleans well.
The aroma is strangely quite different to the taste. Its quite complex - the taste seems to be a mix of a stout and a bit of sour ale. The finish contrasts from the main taste. An interesting, fairly complex beer, quite good, but Im not mad keen on it. (I preferred it strangely when it was virtually flat and warm)

Bottle (33 cl) from the Cracked Kettle. Black with a red edge, large fluffy beige head. Salty roasted liquorice aroma, with some dry, earthy gunpowder notes. Medium bodied. Semi dry, medium bitterness. Dull.
Ikke så kraftig duft. Afbalanceret, vedvarende smag. Behagelig humleeftersmag. Smag af rålakrids. Kaffe.

Thick creamy head. Typical aroma of the De Dolle yeast. Dark bitter chocolate, roasted bitter malts, dark fruit, spicy. Overcarbonated which prevents to beer to live up to its full potential. I would suggest to let it sit for a while. But after some time its much more pleasant. Excellent for a cold winter night.

Dark brown colour, brown red hue, firm exuberant tan head. Aroma of malts, roasted malt, some red fruits, light hops, some chocolate. Flavour slightly sweet, bitter roasted malts, some coffee, some roasted tones. Rather lively carbonated for a stout. Quite OK.
(From 33cL bottle @ home)

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011 Zeer donker met bruine kraag. Smaak begint met iets kersen, daarna chocolade en koffie. Te veel koolzuur en te weinig smaak (overschaduwt door het overdadige koolzuur) voor een echt goeie stout.

Bottle @ home. Deep brown appearance with a very lively, brown head, large bubbles that dissipate pretty quickly. Toasty, deep malty, a touch roasty, light organic hoppy aroma. Light to medium bodied, dark malty, well carbonated, mild espresso, light caramel/chocolate, slightly tangy flavor.

A sparkling dark brown ale with a big head of small bubbles. Sweet tones of chocolate, nuts, malts, friad fruit, sweet licorice and honey A lot sweet than a regular stout or IS and not as robust and bitter as an IS either. More close to an dark belgian strong ale. Very tasty in an spicy/sweet way
Bottle.. 33cl... It pours dark brown with a huge tan head....the aroma is dark fruit, licorice, roasted malt.... the flavor is some smoke, bitter, chocolate, roasted malt and fruit... nice stout....

Lovely stout, some dark fruit, coffee, roasty malts. very dark with brown head. 
Taste is heavy light bitter, thick as a stout. Great stout from dolle brouwers

Bottle from kingcecil, thanks my friend. Dark brown body with a huge light brown head. Aroma is cocoa, dark fruit, liquorice, smoke, roast. Flavor is smoke, roasted malt, bitter chocolate, fruit. I like it.
En botella.Negra con espuma beige,buena carbonización y retención.Contundente ,densa con un toque acido.cerveza solida.

Bottle.  Union Jacks in Oley, PA.  Pours a thick, brown-black color with a nice tan head.  Heavy duty stuff.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee being the most dominant aromas.  Heavily bodied as expected.  Goes down the gullet nice and smooth.  Certainly a sipping, colder weather brew but quite delicious.  Can feel a slight alcohol burn but still pretty smooth considering it is 9% alcohol.

Warning: pour this very carefully to have some beer with your foam. Quite interesting drinking experience. First impression was: classic Stoutish burn, which Im not a fan of. However, as you drink it, the burntness disappears into the background and a strongly alcoholic chocolate/coffee taste takes over, reminiscent of a heavy cognac soaked dessert rather than beer. Not an everyday beer for me, but I can imagine enjoying it on a cold winter evening.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2011 (bottled)  In a De Dolle goblet ..Festering in the air is chocolate mosse , blackberries , lots of roast coffee  .   A fucking humongus beige head that never dies ..customary blackness too .   Its a spirited stout , spunky id say ,loads of roast dryness, tart dark fruit, coffee ,leading to robust rich chocolate dimension ,its almost a late avalanche of texture..A pretty excellent beer.

Bottle, split with mcberko. Pours solid black with a thick lasting tan head, foams easily. Smells musty, dirty, industrial, creosote, engineering metal output. Flavour of iodine, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, burnt wood and dirty smoke. Nasty smell, not great flavour, decent aftertaste, but thats it. Not impressed.

28/09/2011 330ml bottle. Nera, impenetrabile, enorme cappello di schiuma color cappuccino, lievemente crespa, molto persistente. Aroma di malti tostati, cioccolato e lieviti, con una punta di liquirizia. In bocca, sentori tipici di una belgian ale, specialmente nei lieviti, quindi arriva la nota di malti tostati, cioccolatosa, dolce, caramellata, per niente caffettosa. Corpo medio, buona carbonazione. Una "belgian stout", sicuramente interessante, ma non proprio il mio genere di birra.

From the bottle. Poured dark brown with 2-3 fingers worth of beige head. Smelled of fruits (probably dried), chocolate, light anise and vinous flavors. The taste was of the same but it has a strange tartness to it. Finished a little funky. Needs more body.

330ml bottle. Opaque deep brown pour with mountains of mocha head that recedes slowly. Musty on the nose with hints of chocolate and coffee. Theres an almost vinous quality there too. Much more interesting on the palate to me. Theres a nice spicy hit right in the front followed by a sweet licorice taste that has a nutty character too. Finishes with lots of burnt coffee. If that musty note was in the taste as well this would be absolutely superb.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours pitch black with a huge amount of carbonation leading to a massive head of brown foam. The nose makes itself known as soon as you open the bottle.  Lots of dry roasted notes, some vinousness, light anise, and light coffee.  The flavor has a touch of sourness with notes of coffee, licorice, Cabernet, and light chocolate.   The alcohol is a little obvious.  Very light on the palate for a stout.  Definitely a Belgian take.  Dry on the back end.  Very interesting.  Worth a try, but pricey for those of us in the States.

Roasty, sweet aroma... with touch of chocolate, dried fruit (raisins ?) and some alcohol.  Flavour is much more subtle... lacking even, than the aroma.  Its tart.  Definitely roasty with a little smoke.  Sort of thin bodied for a stout.  Highly effervescent.  I was expecting more from this one... especially from the aroma.  Not worth the price.

In this bottle I taste vanilla, pipe tobacco, cherry rinds, coffee, and some strange vinous flavors.  Weird tartness on the finish gets pretty tiresome.  Pretty different as far as stouts go.  Interesting, but I personally dont really care for it.  This beer gives me a strange feeling, like I was touched in a bad way.
Black body, light brown head. Aroma has coffee, bitter chocolate, along with a dusty note. Flavour is roasted malty, with some chocolate, dry and alcoholic. Very nice.

330mL bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours black with a towering, lingering, foamy beige head. Aroma is quite funky for a stout, with high acidity, some hops, light toasted malt and metallic notes. Flavour is also quite metallic, with iodine, burnt malt, lots of yeast, with a stale, metallic finish. I dont get the ratebeer average for this - stale, metallic and much too carbonated. Not enjoyable.

Appearance: very dark brown with a full, foamy beige head and thick lace curtains.   Aroma: espresso and licorice immediately, then some lactic tang, then some spice (cinnamon, clove), then a little chocolate and toast.   Taste: slightly sour and tangy dark fruit (almost like a red wine), with a dose licorice right up front, but then a pleasant wave of bittersweet chocolate,   Finish: toasty malts give way to a talc-like dryness, with a hint of basement mustiness and, eventually, an alcohol burn.   Notes: Really liked certain characteristics of this beer--the roasty chocolate flavor and the medium-bodied easy-drinking palate. Other aspects I didnt love--the sour, lactic tang and the funky, dusty finish.  Overall, not bad.  Sunday morning breakfast stout of the week.

Bottle @ Home. Opens with a POOOFSs and beer all over the table ; (. Pours very dark brown with a offwhite head. Looks good, but i like my beer to stay in the bottle until i pour it into a glass. Aroma of dark roasted malts, dark bitter chocolate, coffee, licorice. Taste is roasted malt, bitter chocolate, loads of licorice, some dark dried fruit. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, sticking slightly tart finish. Good stuff apart from the mess on the table. 220811

Dark brown to black coloured beer with average off-white head. Herby malty and roasted hinted aroma. Full sprankling palate; Finish is bitter malty roasted, alcoholic and full creamy malty bitter roasted. Nice.

Bottle 33cl, a dark beer with huge creamy brownish head. Nose is dark chocolate and alcoholic like. Aroma is intense on dark chocolate but very drinkable, coffee notes, oily, unusual stout, pleasant, less complex, intense roasted presence.

Black as night with a massive brown head, even with careful pouring. Aroma is chocolate, roast almonds, brown sugar. Creamy texture with a medium body and noticeable carbonation. Flavour is of coffee, soy sauce and subtle amounts of chocolate, brown sugar and some bitterness in the finish.
Pours black with tan head. Aroma of dried fruits and coffee. Taste of coffe, chocolate an dried fruits. Delicious

33cl bottle. Pours an opaque colour somewhere between black and chestnut with a decent head. The nose has cherry and chocolate - black forest gateau - and Jamaica ginger cake. The taste has more chocolate and some cherries again with liquorice and rum on the end. In fact, after its gone, theres a coffee note that persists. The palate is rich in structure and texture, with a long persistent finish which is slightly clumsy but still a great palate. Overall, an excellent and almost unique experience.
Xocolata, cafè i un lleuger punt dalchol. Aromes dolces de toffe i de cigaló. Carbònic molt agradable i final llarg i placenter. Cremosa. Què més es pot demanar a una bona Stout?

330 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet (bottled January 2010).  Pours dark brown and even with a slow pour there is a thick, bubbly tan head (probably at least 3 inches thick).  The aroma is mostly floral hops with hints of semi-sweet chocolate in the background.  The flavor is a really nice balance of roasted coffee and dark fruit.  While Im not sure if the dark fruit was intentional or a result of 1 1/2 years of aging the product I am rating is quite good.  The alcohol is almost undetected although there is a bit of warmth.  Excellent overall.
This was just too much for me. Generally I like stouts, but this is just too much roasted coffee for me.

Dark brown blackish pour steady beige head with decent lacing .... Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, candi sugar, little licorice and caramel .... Taste is of roasted malts, some bitter coffee, licorice and candi sugar, caramel malts light chocolate with a bitter hop that flows into the finish.... Pretty carbonated and lovely abv hidden very well complex brew

0.33l bottle courtesy of and shared with ClubGonzo. Pours a hazy deep dark brown body with some big dark floaters and a small creamy tanned head. Aroma is quite yeasty for a stout and kinda hard to describe. Not much that reminds me of a youre typical stout here. Notes of chocolate and some light roasted malts. Lively carbonated, medium-bodied and feels sticky to oily on the palate. Flavors are quite yeasty and there is initially a nice little alco-punch. Continues with some bitter dark chocolate, a good leather flavor and ends in a bitter aftertaste along with some more noticeable alcohol. Absolutely drinkable and quite different.

Pours dark black with a big, rocky head into a New Belgium snifter.  Upon a slight swirl, the head pillowed into the size of almost 3 fingers.  Aroma of cacao, ash, slight smoke, and some earth spice.  The taste definitely takes a turn for more of a rustic sense.  Earthy, dirty, ashy, roasted malt and chocolate are at the forefront of the flavors with some anise notes hiding in the finish.  The roastiness of the espresso is at times a bit astringent, but it tends to work with the chocolate flavors similar to a chocolate covered espresso bean.  While all the flavors work well together, the beer is just a tad too effervescent.  The carbonation is nice, but a little more silk to the body would have been nice.

Bottle.  Even as Im pouring I get huge fruity notes in the aroma.  The first time I had this beer there was an extremely large head on it, and even with my careful, gentle, pour there was a huge khaki head.  This beer looks like a cup of coffee with a large head.  Aroma contains dark fruits, hazelnut coffee, and a touch anise.  Taste is slightly ashy with more dark fruits, roast coffee, and candy sugar.  Medium bodied with a dry, vinous finish.  God damn this is good!

ZBF 2008 
Voluminöser Malzgeruch, etwas alkoholisch, was sofort von Röstmalz überdeckt wird. Röstiger Malzantrunk, eine leichte Süße mildert die hintergründige Bitterkeit. Erkennbar hopfig, angenehm harmonisch, die Bitterkeit wird zum trockenen Abgang hin stärker. 	 
Test vom 11.3.2008, Gebinde: Fass 	Noten: 13,11,10,12,-,11 - 11,21
Bottle. Color black with medium brown head. Aroma chocolate, roasted, coffee, fruits. Taste hop, chocolate, coffee, spicy.

Bottle from EtreGourmet, shared with Palme. A gusher! A STOUT gusher! That doesnt happen to me too often! :-P When the geyser fades, the beer appears as a deep brown, near-black brew with a moderate creamy tan head that settles rather quickly. Nose is yeasty chocolate sour-ish tones, I know it doesnt make much sense but thats the best I can do...a bit strange. De Dolles yeast profile seems to invade even their darker brews. :-P Taste is big yeasty tones - surprisingly enough for a stout - flanked with dark chocolate and leathery sour-malt-ish notes. Quite peculiar. Burnt toast in the finish. Easily drinkable, and an interesting and original Belgian micro-take on the Foreign Stout genre.

Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, coffee, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is very sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted bitter finish. A good mix between a stout and a Belgian strong ale. A bit too sweet though. 270511

11.2oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours very dark brown with a thick, lacy tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, hints of chocolate and coffee, licorice like the description says, and some floral hops.  This beer tastes much better than it smells.  The chocolate is the main flavor and the coffee is strong on the finish.  There is a little spiciness with the dark fruits and roasted malts too.  Average texture.  A really good beer though.

Bottle...  Poured black with a thick, rocky tan head.  Started of roasty with some ash, cocoa malt, dark chocolate with a very drying, well spiced yeast flavor towards the end. Also notes of cocoa nibs, nutty malt, and even salt water.

Bottle was a pretty highly carbed slight gusher. Pour mess black/dark brown big coffee brown head not much lace. Aroma chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, coffee/espresso roast, quite roasty, cereal grain. Taste espresso, cocoa, coffee, chocolate, slight nuttiness, very roasty, light vanilla hints as well slight burnt hints. MF medium to full body medium fizzy carb. Overall very complex quite roasty and warming booze is there but amplifies the beer and is well used. aside from being a gusher very well done.

330 mL bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Raisin, chocolate, and soy sauce aroma, very vinous.  Raisin and brown sugar lead the flavor, with cocoa, smoke, and soy following.  Im reminded a bit of Dr. Pepper at times.  Anyway, its quite a tasty, full-bodied beer.

Very dark with an enormous foamy, fizzy head of tannish hue. Almost too big of a head, but let it rest. Tart for a stout, with roastiness and a crisp finish. Hints of hops, a touch of sweetness and licorice.

Bottle. Dark brown  almost black, huge and fully lasting light brown head. Moderate to full, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, fruitiness with dark berries, roasted malt with lots of licorice, some herbal spiciness. Body is medium to full, lightly sweetish and malty flavor, licorice with roasted malt and some coffee, some sourness and herbal hoppyness/spiciness. Finish is average to long, dryish with roasted malt, hoppyness with licorice. Interesting Belgian stout. Too much licorice for me, but this is balanced by roastiness and sourness.

Bottle from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Pitch black pour with a big beige head. Wonderfull aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee, wood, liquorice and roasted malts. Same hints in the taste. This beer has a near perfect balance. Good hop finish. Great brew!!

Black cloudy body, large brown foam. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, raisin, vanilla, woody, dried fruits. The taste has a heavy cloying sweetness and is lightly bitter. Full body, creamy, slick feel, soft carbonation, long finish.

pours black with a massive beige head.  aroma is a bit metallic with coffee and brown sugar notes.  mouthfeel is full and prickly. taste is rich with chocolate, maple, coffee and hops with a distincy belgian yeast tartness.  finishes long and boozy.
Bottle. Black with giant light brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, vinous, bitter, coffee and notes of alcohol.

33cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a huge light brown head. Aroma is roasted, toffe, coffe and chocolate. Taste is similar: big coffe notes, chocolate hints, licorice and roasted malts. Palate is medium with huge carbonation. A couple swirls in the glass are definitely necessary to really taste this brew. Still excellent!

A: The pour is dark brown, almost black with a huge brown head which has retained quite impressively.

S: Definitely a nice roasted quality to the nose with some coffee and dark chocolate. Some hints of licorice and dark fruits. Mild earthy and herbal notes to the nose as well.

T: Quite a nice flavor, and significantly sweeter than expected. Quite a bit of licorice to it, some dark chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee. Maybe some citrus hops and a definite yeastiness.

M: Medium in body with the carbonation on the high end of medium.

O: Solid beer from De Dolle, who I find to be a fairly hit or miss brewery.

Bottle. Moderate aromas of dark bread and dark chocolate for the malt, resin the hops, earth for the yeast with hints of raisin, toffee, vanilla and vinegar. Head is large, frothy/creamy, light brown with thick but slippery lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then the long  finish is moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium and the texture is hidden by the fizzy carbonation. The finish is lightly alcoholic and pretty dry. Because of some of the blunt aspect to this Foreign Stout its distantly removed from being an easy drinking beer, but thats what makes you slow down and appreciate its complexities.

Pours dark, dark brown with a nice tan head. Huge foamy head. Aroma is raisins, chocolate, coffee, grape juice. Taste is extremely sweet...very sugary plums, chocolate, subtle coffee. Very dry mouthfeel with a cloying sweetness. Finish is all coffee, roasted espresso beans. Very complex flavors that keep on developing.

330 mL bottle.  No date on it, but Im guessing its maybe 3 years old.  Its murky, opaque, dark brown with a nice brown head.  (I wish I had stirred it up a little before I poured, because there is a lot of dark matter left on the bottom of the bottle.  Probably lost some flavour there.  I thought that the bottle was newer.)  The aroma has roast, cherries, and a lot of soy sauce.  The flavour is quite sweet, almost candy sweet.  There is some roast in there, a little coffee.  No hops.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  A little disappointing.  May have been on the shelf at Premiere too long.

I love stouts & I seem to adore any beer made with bretts, naturally I loved this one. It was nicely dark with a creamy head, not that big, plenty lacing, looked great, smelled of espresso, black chocolate, roasted malts and tasted of lots of mocha ice-cream, milk chocolate, hazelnut, sweet coffee, espresso, with a small sour note at the very end, amazing really, it was not very thick but very creamy & smooth, lots of aftertaste, not too much carbonation, really delicious

06/03/2011 - on tap @ Zythos Beer Festival (2011-94) 
Note: this is a version made especially for the Zythos Beer Festival with bretta yeast!
Dark brown to black beer, beige creamy head. MF: ok carbon, full body, soft creamy texture. Aroma: mocha, coffee, apple skin, lemon, fruity. Taste: mocha, coffee, citrus, fruity, caramel. Aftertaste: mocha, coffee bitter.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2015 Bottle 330ml @ yngwie
Pours dark brown with a huge tan head. Aroma has notes of malt, roasted, tartness, coffee, yeast and some fruitiness. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter and light sour with a long fruity, roasted and slightly sour finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle 330ml @ home
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of malt, alcohol and dried fruits. Taste is light sweet. Body is light to medium, texture is thin, carbonation is flat. [5 3 5 3 10 = 2.6 3/7/2011]

11.2 oz bottle.

Pours a thick, dense black with not so much as brown on the edges and a deep, thick tan head that rises above the lip of my snifter. This is as good of looking a stout as you will ever see. The head slowly recedes into a nice cream capping the beer leaving some nice lacing.

The smell is rich and roasty, with a nice hit of chocolate. It has has a creamy bready overtone to it that melds great with the coffee and cocoa scents. The yeast provides a mild twang and there is a bit of licorice over it all.

The taste is pretty wild. The mouthfeel is a bit overcarbonated for the style but the flavor is BDSA meets stout. It has a ton of dark fruit over top a chocolaty coffee base.

Overall this is an entertaining and unique beer that I would try again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-26-2010 22:26:41

05 bottle bought at Holiday Wines in Escondido.  Dark black with tan to brown head.  Nose oat and alcohol. Taste is big fizzy mouthfeel and alcohol.  Pungent to medicine to high alcohol.  Bourbon, specifically.  Not viscous at all.  Basement musty.  Bit of a letdown.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 Weird stout, uses belgian yeast strains to make a stout resulting in very fruity stout. KInd of works for it, but just very odd. Wasnt an initial fan.

pours dark brown almost black with a dark beige head, although disappears unfortunately. chocolate, coffee, belgian spicyness, with indeed a dry explosion of black espresso finish, slightly acidic. an ex-ce-llent brew.
11.2 bottle-a dark pour -big brown foamy head (too foamy)- aroma and taste of roasty,licorice,coffee,chocolate,-very carbonated too much 4 me or would receive better rating.

Bottle. Gusher. Lost about 10 of the 12 ozs. What was left poured black with a thick brown head. Nose of chocolate malt, vanilla, lactose sweetness and coffee grinds. Taste of rich Belgian chocolate, vanilla, dry coffee and licorice. Medium body.

330 ml bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu.
Pours a dark brown, almost black colour with a large beigeish head. Aroma of coriander, chocolate, dark coffee and some sweet fruits. Flavour of dark sweet fruits, coffee, toffee, hops and smooth chocolate malts. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a dry finish. Well balanced.
11.2 oz bottle, pours an opaque ink w/ a huge foamy peaty head, aroma is rum, raisins, and light esters, sweet, rich and smooth with a light lactic tang, tons of complexity, delicious
A bit of a OK stout.    Good roasty aroma.  Some light coffee notes to it.  Add a touch of sweetness.  Hazelnuts, I dont think so.  Plain vanilla to me.

11.2oz bottled June 20, 2010.  Pop the cap and foam starts gushing out, pours about 80% head, takes forever to recede, eventually down to a ring and some foamy islands.  Virtually no lacing...oh and the beer itself is a thin dark brown color.  Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, musty, yeasty and herbal, some chocolate and smoke, some dark fruit and anise.  Moderate to good strength.  Flavor is dark fruits, cherries, raisins, figs, black currants, coffee, a bit of chocolate, roasted malts, a hint of sourness, some hops there as well with citrus notes.  Mouthfeel is light with intense carbonation.  The ridiculous head and hints of sourness makes me wonder about a possible infection, but maybe this is the way the beer is supposed to be.  Still pretty good, but not the best Foreign Stout Ive had.  Certainly a unique Belgian take on the style.

Almost black with a massive light brown head. The bottle starts bubbling just by breaking the cap, seams overly carbonated. The aroma have yeast, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and some fruit. Rich flavor with a lot roasted malt, dried fruit and alcohol. Medium sweet and a have lot of fruity acidity that is somewhat disturbing since it so much of it. Very intense carbonation. Ends with a medium coffee bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2015 25th May 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Creamy stout but quite smoky and some worcester sauce sourness going on. Not my favourite Belgian stout! 25th January 2015Old bottle. Hazy deep amber - brown beer, small pale tan head. Palate is airy and semi dry. Decent fine carbonation. Tangy oxidised dark malts. Plummy fruitiness. Trace of dark chocolate. Light tangy finish. Interesting!

330ml bottle from Bierkompass

Pours black with massive white and foamy head. Spicy and strong belgian styled stout. Alcohol warms nicely.
Thanks to darn1207, a little bit of ash, some nice sweetness. A little malty bitterness.
11/5/10.  Thanks, darn1207 for sharing at S3! Sweet fruity stout with hints of ash, brown sugar, chocolate, and coffee.

(11.2oz bottle(  Pours nearly black with gusher khaki head.  Aroma is chocolately, peppery and anise.  Sweet and sour with some roasty bitterness.  Very Belgian like.   Full bodied with creamy texture and roasty, bitter finish (but not overdone).  A very nice beer.

Black with big, foamy, fizzy, brown head / Subdued nose of dark fruit and chocolate / Medium body, lightly tart, but extreme fizzy carbonation to point of discomfort, with good balance and finish / Flavors of prune, cherry, chocolate, licorice, dark roast coffee, and oak / An otherwise good beer marred by the crazy carbonation.  Stir and swirl to abate the carbonation before drinking.
Lots and lots of head which is quite dark and frothy. Banana, coffee and licorice aroma. Smoky. Tons of roasted malts in the flavour. Also coffee bitterness. Dry. More than medium carbonated.

Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a huge foamy dark brown head that lingered and produced great lacing. The aroma was sweetish, malty and toasty with notes of malted milk, cherries and cocoa. The flavor was tangy and roasty with notes of licorice, cocoa, cherry and vanilla and faint hints of smoke and wood. The finish was long, tart, roasty and had lingering cherry and wood. Medium body. Interesting.

New Beer Distributors, NY, NY 11.2oz ($5.60): Pours a black color with a brown head that lasts forever. Massive and powerful aroma. Like Brunch at a five star restaurant. Molasses, chocolate, and a whole lot of the finest coffee. Alcohol flavors well covered. All sweetness and very little bitterness (I mean there is some, but I dont see why a lot of reviewers are harping on it this much). Candy... molasses or sugar. Well-balanced in this regard. A whole bunch of roasted malts that give it a full flavor. Amongst the best of the foreign stouts. A really under exploited kind of stout in my opinion.

33cl bottle from Bierkompass. Poured almost black color with a massive frothy mocha head, very nice looking. Aroma is coffee and roasted malt. Taste  is quite intensive, spicy, peppery flavor with roasted, almost burnt malts, liquirice. Finish is quite dry, with chocolate and wood notes. Really nice, and easy to drink, wish I would have bought another bottle.
Nose of brown sugar, sweet malt, whiff of fridge, feel is broad and warm, carb is medium, taste is sweet wine, weak coffee, late salt.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2011 Very large head which stays quite a while. Almost too much carbonation. Taste is very coffee and caramel loaded. I think it is better if this beer is a bit aged as the taste gets somewhat pushed away by the carbonation. EDIT: 3.1 for the 2010 verion, 4.1 for the 2005 bottle (aged 5 years). The taste has evolved much better than expected. A full palate of coffee and some dark chocolate stand out very much now. Very nice beer.

13-OCT-2010, bottle from "Fish & Beer".
I open the bottle and it explodes. Well, it doesnt but it feels that way...
