...I have it all over my T-shirt, hair and carpet.
I run for the sink, but it keeps running out of the bottle. They should have a lable on this like on cigaret packets: "Warning, ..."
After cleaning I finally pour some into my glas and it is all head.
Nice fluffy light brown head. As it sinks a dark dark brown liquid turns up.
Very roasted, coffee like with a peppermint like chocolate:)
High high carbonation and long aftertaste, although it is a little thin considering the carbonation and ABV.
Overall a very good stout.

Dry coffee aroma, little sweet, little maple wood.  Earthy too, bordering on mushroomy, though not fungal or spoiled, just heavy.  Jet black, fizzy thick mocha head, great lacing.  Very fizzy, like a bowl of rice krispies, Chewy dark roast, strong and stops just before being burnt.  Amazing.  Dances on the knife edge of burnt and bitter.  Aggressive and governed.  This is where I want my foreign stout to reside.

Bottle. Opened with a very energetic pop and then pours with a really big foamy head. Have to show patience as the head settles to even try this one. Dark brown color with a big fluffy head that slowly settles. Jeez, this thing almost makes me feel it is infected. The aroma is a mix of sweet dark fruits, licorice, and coffee grounds. The mouthfeel is light and carbonated. Alcohol is fairly prevalent in the taste along with some sweetness and some biterness in the end. Sweet candy fruit taste that quickly transitions and is really interrupted by the carbonation. 
Really not my idea of a stout and nothing I would want to drink again.

33cl bottle. Black color with a huge lightbrown head. Like every De Dolle a small gusher. Aroma of dark candy sugar, slightly roasted nuts and gentle roasted touches. The taste starts with sweet nuts, kind of hazelnut flavor, chocolate, dark candy sugar and a dry espresso aftertaste. A great Foreign Stout!

Bottle.  Pours an opaque near-black reddish brown with a lasting foamy beige head.  Nose is sweet roasty malts, toffee, coffee, and alcohol.  Full-bodied  - perhaps a bit less so than an imperial stout.  Sweet dark roasted malts, coffee, medium bitterness, dark fruit.  The alcohol comes through increasingly towards the finish, but never too much.  The sweetness hangs around right through the finish.  Finish itself is bitter, sweet, roasty chocolate malt.

Good beer, but not as good as I expected. Poured with a small, tan head and a bit of lace. Color is an almost opaque very dark brown with some sediment bits. Aroma is really big with the licorice, roasty, dark ripe fruit, dark roasted coffee, malt. Flavor is like that plus has some sour tang, toffee, very bitter dark chocolate. Body is a tad thin, good carbonation, sharp on tongue back and sides - almost astringent. Finish has the tang remaining along with a bit of the dark malt in the throat that is fairly long. Not a session for me.
Pours dark brown with a bit of lacing but no head. Aroma is raisin and coffee. Flavour is coffee and burnt caramel, but a bit watery for what Id expect.

330 ml bottle, as De Dolle Special Extra Export Stout, kindly shared by my beerpal Jan Magnus. ABV is 9%. Pitch black colour, big tan head. First a fairly moderate but very nice roasty aroma (gets even better as the beer warms up a little) with some vinous notes, hints of dark dried fruits and leather. The flavour is also vinous, oaky and roasty, hints of raisins, coffee and liquorice. Overall brilliant.

Bottle: tulip glass was a bad choice. Keeping it cold was a bad choice. Head foamed up like crazy. Took 5 minutes just to pour. Arouma is chocolate and molasses. Dark chocolate, prunes. Thick and syrupy mouthfeel, almost coating the tongue. Finishes rooty, woody and dry, somewhat peppery, medicinal/fusel herbal. Balance improves as it warms up... not so medicinal.

Bottle. Dark brown with fizzy foamy off white head. Aroma is full of complex fruits - apple, plum, raisin, berries, mangos, also darker caramels and licorice. Taste is bright dried fruit, caramel chocolates. Dry light bitter finish. Very carbonated and bubbly on tongue. Awesome all around. Enjoying very much! complex but simple to drink and enjoy.

330 ml bottle. Inky black pour with a large tan head. Aroma is coffee, rum, lightly earthy. Something else going on I cant name. Flavor is coffee, earth, clay, chalky. Little bit of booze on the finish. Dry mouthfeel.
UPDATED: APR 7, 2017 How tasty! I really liked this. Another nice beer from Kris and De Dolle.  Quite carbonated like many De Dolle beers. Serving: Bottle

330ml bottle from IPB
Appearance : Black with huge 4 figers thick head. Fluffy and creamy. A bit too much head...

Aroma : Roasted malt, oily with some resinous hops. Slight tartness. 

Taste : Roasty and oily. A little bit acidic with some hops. Finish roasty, a little bit resinous and a bit acidic. A bit mineral.

Overall : Very suspicious nose and taste. The little tartness feels rather off. Same thing with the acidity. I might have had a bad bottle.

pours black with a huge mocha head...head was so large that i had to pour 3 times just to empty the bottle.  nice retention.  aroma is warming with dark fruit, licorice, and spicy hops.  flavor is very roasty with cocoa and coffee notes, a touch of dark fruit.  slight metallic hint and spicy hops at the end.  mouthfeel is lively and not too heavy with a roasty finish that goes away somewhat quickly.  not too bad but not as good as id hoped either.
Aroma of caramel and alcohol. Huge head flavor has alcohol, caramel and fruit.

Very dark coloured beer with a huge fluffy head. Spicy aroma with a hint of sweetness. The first mouthfeel has a very strong sence of chocolade and coffee. A really good taste of chocolade, coffee, lots of carbonation makes it easy to drink. And then this beer finishes off with a perfect dry taste that leaves  you wanting for more. A very good stout! (Bottle 33cl)

Rich brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, chocolate, & some coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, bittersweet chocolate and some dark fruit; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, did not know what to expect at first - but I did enjoy it.

Brown with large brown head. Aroma of wood and roasted malts. Drinks sweet and acidic with salty liqorice coming through. Full bodied and oily. Carbonation is indeed lively - the drink grows in the mouth. The foam keeps coming out of the bottle long after the initial pour.

Wow what a nice stout. Great Beligian style, chocolate, a bit of spice, coffee, and a very very dry finish. Medium to full bodied, very smooth, not really alcoholic tasting, despite the high alcohol content. Warming, though. I need to have this again!

Bottle:
2 finger slow disappearing light beige head.
Smell some malts, chocolate, spices and just a slight hint of mint.
Lovely black color.
Taste is different than smell. Very dark taste and lot of carbonation. Not oily palate at all, but very well (balanced) dark (coffee/chocolate) and bitter beer.
The taste evolves into a more bitter and dry aftertaste and stays pretty dark (coffee/chocolate).
I found out that if you leave the beer in a glass for about 15 minutes it tastes even better! (the carbon dioxide left the glass for most part and the taste is stronger and more particular)
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Dark, alomst black. Big creme, mocca coloured head. Aroma has mocca, dark chocolate, caramel and roasted malts. Taste has espresso, chocolate, coffee, mocca. Lots of mocca. Long, nice, somewhat bitter finish

Opaque black pour, slightly brown/red round the edges. Big frothy tan head, diminishing quite quickly. Aroma of roasted malts, fruits, some dark berries, caramel, alcohol, faint hints of coffee and sour yeast. Taste is of roasted malts, a bit of caramel, coffee, some sweetness, but dominated by roasty bitterness. Not much hop. Roasty and rather tiresome finish. Heavy and overwhelming carbonation, not exactly graceful. Medium body, medium duration, low viscosity. The aroma writes out checks, that the taste simply cant cash, which is a shame.

Bottled. Pours black, nearly opaque, letting a bit of light through in the edges, with a big frothy dark tanned head, quickly fading. Aroma has roasted malts, burnt sugar, caramel, dark berries, little coffe. Aroma is very malty and yeasty. The taste is a big disappointment after smelling the beer. At first, it is heavily over powered by a sickly carbonation exploding in your mouth. After you get rid of that after swirling it to death (hard to get the carbonation out), it only tastes heavily roasted, a hint of coffee, and a huge roasted bitterness. The taste in very one-sided, and very unbalanced. A big disappointment for me.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2010 head: 1/2 inch 
colour: black 
smell: candy sirup , salt , soy sauce , blue berrys , malts, sourness, raisins 
taste: sour, malty start , liquer , hops , red fruits , earthy grassy , spices , oily dry fnish 
very good !

bottle .. Deep brown pour , huge beige head , good lace . Slightly sweet aroma , lots of coffee and chocolate notes with a touch of spiciness . Flavor is very roasty , burnt coffee bitterness , chocolate smoothness and a liquorice bite . Medium bodied , medium to high carbonation . Slight alcohol in the finish .

Bottle.  Not a gusher, but a serious foamer.  De Dolle, whats the fuckin deal guys?  This is a reoccurring problem for you.  Anyways, on to the rating.  Pours black with a BIG khaki beige head.  The aroma is of rich roasty chocolate and some belgian yeastiness and some coffee.  The beer tastes similar, but I think it is infected.  It has an almost brett quality to it under the roastyness.  The overly foamy nature makes it just too fizzy and distracting on the palate.  Overall: this beer just confuses me.  Would like to try a batch from the tap, at the brew house, thats guaranteed not to be infected.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a huge foamy tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. The flavour is roasted malt, good strong coffee, bitterness and chocolate. Medium-bodied, aftertaste is roasted and quite dry.

@Tampa Wkly Gathering @OTH Thanks Blazer06-11.2oz bottle-pours a tan head and mahogany color.  Aroma is medium/dark malt-licorice, wood, dark fruit, secondary earthy hops.  Taste is medium/dark malt-licorice, wood, dark fruit, secondary earthy hops.  Soft carbonation.

Bottle at DLD, no shoutouts as I dont remember who brought it. Pours a very dark black, near opaque and a decent thickness, comes in with a tan slanted head, fairly creamy and moderate, dies to a thicker film and laces pretty well. Aromas are roasted malts, coffee, a touch of anise with some raw cocoa behind. A notable dark fruit element comes into play. Initial is similar heavier side of body, cocoa and roast mix with dark fruits of prune and figs, a touch of anise come is in with faint spice. Coffee and caramel malts work their way in, a decent hopping helps temper the sweetness with the roastiness. The anise doesnt overpower, which I was ok with, if it even is anise. Pretty good.

Huge coarseish brown head. Nearly opaque black body is translucent dark red at edges. Delicate roasty licorice and ginger aroma with chocolate and soy notes. Dry-acidic chocolatey alcoholic ginger taste with vinegary spicy cardamom notes. Light body. Mild mouthfeel. Dry-acidic fruity wooden chocolatey aftertaste with burnt notes. Interesting, but tastes infected. Should rerate. (0.33l bottle, Ølbutikken, Copenhagen.)

Courtesy of Blazer06. Pours deep dark brown with thin tan head. The aroma is sweet with black licorice, prunes, boysenberries, black strap molasses, ripe dark grapes and some chocolate around the edges. The taste is just as sweet with malts, black strap molasses and dark fruitiness leading into mild smokiness too. The carbonation is high pushing up the flavors to a bright level. Tasty stuff but could have less carbonation.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Jet black pour with a lasting tan head. Rich aromas of chocolate, caramel, cream, toffee, baked apple. Flavours of smoke, coffee, chocolate, caramel. Smoky, dry mouthfeel. Long, lingering dry, sweet finish. Very tasty!
About as good as stout gets--finely balanced between malt and hops, sweet and spice, chocolate and coffee, dark and light. Ultimately its not my style, but its a very very good beer

Bottle at redlight redlight. Pours jet black with a thin rolling tan head. Bitter chocolate, molasses, and roasty hazelnut. Lingering mouthfeel with a solid sting to the tongue. Tastes lightly sweet with a bitter back end like a baking chocolate or raw cocoa. A little warm and has a slight alcohol taste not bad considering the 9% abv. Overall a very good stout.

Bottle. Murky brown with a beautiful creamy laced head. Strong nose of coffee, chocolate and dark fruits. The flavour is also roasted coffee, dark chocolate and dark fruit. Soft carbonation. Stewed dark fruity finish. This is a beautiful beer and no signs of the abv showing through. Excellent.

Thanks blazer06 for the share.  Pours brown with a tan head.  Nose is roast, chocolate, slight earth, and licorice.  Flavor is similar with a hint of vinegar.  Light to medium body with lively carbonation and a tart finish.

Like Guinness on Belgian steroids--foam exploded in my Imperial nonik glass with the first few drop I poured... this one had to settle for 5 minutes or so. Just a beautifully rich every so slightly sweet flavor - chocolate and roasted malts! Pick it up if you find it!

courtesy of Blazer06.
pours dark brown, tan head.
Aroma, definitely has this Belgian yeast nose, hints of smoked malts and chocolate/caramel.
Flavors, similar to aroma,just a tad more sweet with some nice sugar notes, hints of smoked malts, lingering yeasty palate with a nice chocolate / caramel malt finish.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 Poured a opaque, very dark, reddish brown with a massive, massive head... took about 5 minutes to get the full pour. Head was beige/brown - even after the initial head finally went down, a thick 1/2 inch layer stayed until the end. Aroma: chocolate, raisins, sweet, burnt caramel, faint roasted malts and some sour notes. Taste: Roasted malts, mild sweetness, chocolate with a note of sour milk. Aftertaste was roasted malts, a note of sour milk and a sharp (but short) bitterness. Very good body and depth. Thick, creamy mouth feel. Mild carbonation. Overall: Very good.  De Dolle always finds a extra "something" to make their beers unique. Im glad they do!

Pours a very very dark opaque brown with a massive amount of huge bubbly brown head - literally 3/4 of the glass is head off the bat.  Aroma is subdued roastiness, slightly soured milk, sweet burnt toffee, and a slight apple tartness.  Flavor is surprisingly sour.  Almost reminds me of some tart chocolate covered cherries i had a few years ago.  Roastiness is definitely there as well, some boozy warmth and a lactic yet dry finish.  Overall, very different - worth a try.

330mL. Slight gusher. Pours a clear, dark amber with a very healthy light brown head that has okay retention and little to no lace. Sour nose- sort of salty, funky with caramel, dark chocolate, liquored cherries. As it warms the aroma moves to beautiful roast, light Flemish oude brune sourness, old world tar, musty Middle Ages burnt village. Nice dichotomy. Taste is a little tart, grainy, salt water. Could be a good oyster stout. Bit of lacto in the back of the throat. More of a slightly funky Abbey Dubbel, brune, but would be awesome as an oyster stout paired with seafood.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick light brown to tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, alcohol, bread and licorice. Flavor is coffee with chocolate, quite bitter and slightly sweet. Very long bitter finish, very lively carbonation and a creamy texture. Very nice brew.

lots of head, condensing down to a film. Strong chocolate and coffee aromas with a bit of sour fruit. Odd sweetness for a stout. Along with the typical roasty chocolaty flavors in sneeks a prominent sour apple/cherry flavor. Oily mouthfeel and lingers long on the tounge.

pours black with a very large khaki head, above average carbonation, and some lacing.

smell is of roasted malt, cocoa, and weak coffee.

taste is sour, carbonation, roasted malt, chocolate, and weak coffee, ends somewhat dry and bitter.

Its already been said. Pours a deep black with quite a tan head - good retention. Licorice, coffee, sour cherries, and green apple in the nose. Taste is first sour fruit, followed by some sweet chocolate and then bitter coffee finish - surprisingly dry. Even though not a traditional style - its another exceptional effort from De Dolle.

bottle poured into a snifter... pours a solid black with a huge 4 finger rocky tan head.... after a few minutes it condensed down to a quarter inch which lasts a bit... very sweet aroma filled with coffee, candy sugar, chocolate and sour cherries... medium body with a very smooth quality - low carbonation over the tongue - huge sweet bomb - more cherries come forward in the front and through the finish... big chocolate notes fill the back along with a slight sour twist... very unique stout.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2015 Bottle - July 2006! Thanks to De Dolle Des! Baige lacing. Opaque colour. Aroma is cedar. Brett and aged cheddar. Oak, wood. Typical Belgian aromatic sugar flavours.  Taste is leather, blackcurrants, caramel, redcurrants, chocolate, tar, motor oil, Canadian syrup and brett. Lovely and funky. A tad earthy but who cares? Me not. Note it turns out it hasnt got brett but it sometimes becomes bretty because of the sugar used. This particular batch I felt was bretty but it wasnt ott. It was just good. It wasnt infected or a throwaway beer. Its the best stout Ive had from De Dolle.

Pours a very dark brown color with a very thick and dense dark beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, dark fruits and spices.
Flavors of roasted malts, black chocolate coffee, liquorice, nuts, a hint of dark berries, caramels, and some spices.  Good carbonation, very bitter dry, with a cream end in mouth.  Very powerfull taste, a havy punch, not so easy to drink, quite thick, full body.  Great complexity and great ballance of flavors.  Really wonderfull stout.
Bottle. Nice very dark colour, a very big head. Good taste with a bit of a bitter aftertaste. Complex but balanced.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2016 Brown lasting foam. Black color. Small roasted aroma with some violets. The taste is roasted with belgian yeast carracter and a small acidity. A 2 year old bottle. New tasting at Pressklubben Stockholm. Short brown head. Very dark color. Complex aroma with chocolate and strong coffey. A bit belgian taste with a roasted malts taste. Medium to big body.

330 cl. bottle.  High expectations for this one.  Even though the bottle had been sitting for hours, foam explodes out top and all over my pants.  Well, ok.  Pour is quite nice, very dark brown body with big foamy milk-chocolate, rich nutmeg brown head.  Aroma of dark roasted malts, coffee, burnt sugar, cinnamon, plum, nuts, maybe cashew, licorice.  Flavor is a great blend of chocolate tones and coffee, with a nut character to it.  Very very nice stout, but watch out when you open it, i probably lost a quarter of it.
330 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a nice beige head aroma roasted malts caramel fruit and hop taste caramel spices fruit and some hop

Creamy very dark almost black reddish beer. Hoppy sour smell, with hints of strawberries, cardamom and chocolate. Burnt feel. Sour bitter taste with a smooth creamy mouty palate. Very dry. Hints of peach, an interesting combination of stout and abeey beer.

Slight sweetness yeasty.  Black with nice tan, fluffy head.  Lighty sweet (candy sugar) with a Belgian yest middle and a coffee roast finish.  A bit of pineapple in the yeast.  A very transitional and interesting beer.

Bottle: Extremely gushing, big loose "dirty" tanned head, that quickly collapses, hazy, dark-amber coloured; sourish-fruity and sweet roast-malty nose; solid sweet-bitter flavour, full bodied; lingering, warming, roast-malty sweet finish. Weak aroma, but all in all tasty...
Dark brown coloured beer with small off-white head and lots of carbonation. Malty roasted aroma with a hoppy touch. Full sparkling palate. Finih is bitter roasted and smoked. Good one.
dark brown black coloured body with a off white head a roasted malty fruity chocolat aroma a roasted malty fruity chocolat bitter taste with a spicy bitter finish

Bottle - 330ml. Dark brown cloudy body topped with a huge brown foamy head. Complex malty/hoppy aroma with fruity (plum, cherries), yeasty, and brown sugar hints. Robust taste carries roasty, plummy, and some chocolate notes. That blast of flavors ends with a long, warming bittersweet/roasty finish. Awesome!

Bottle at Winking Lizard Crosswoods. Darkest brown pour with a huge tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and Belgian yeast that is a bit tart and banana-ish. Flavor gives you the yeast up front, followed by sweet chocolate and a bit of roast on the back end.

Drank at Firewaters in AC.  Pours a dark black body with serious foaming tan head.  Aroma of a dark chocolate with muted undertones of raisin.  Taste is a little bitter but hearty like a stout should be.  Very nice beer, that has a medium body feel. One of these filled me up pretty good.  Alcohol is there but not as noticeable on initial taste, you sense it moreso on the backend.  Very nice beer, and good selection by Chalsk.

Bottle. The last style I was missing. Dark brown with enormous brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, licorice and coffee. Taste lots of roasted malts, some coffe as well,quite rough mouthfeel and not really pleasant. It´s a sort of beer I don´t appriciate, but I guess it is a intended. I don´t quite understand why this beer shold be placed in a style of its own (the name offcause ;-)). It reminds me much of Ølfabrikken Porter or some Imperial Stouts I´ve tasted.

Pours an almost black color with a big creamy head that descends a bit. The aroma is fruity with some raisin and some plum with a bit of rostiness and some some nuttiness. The flavor is nicely tart with some raisin and some burnt toast. There are also cherry and espresso flavors.

12 oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a gigantic frothy light tan head, almost all head no matter how I pour it. Aroma raisins, chocolate, raisinettes, dark fruits, brown sugar. Flavor starts with a heavy dose of dark fruits, candy sugar, very tannic, almost a tartness to it. Finishes dry and fruity, kind of picking up an english ale flavor of fruitiness. Medium body and a sharp carbonation. Kind of disappointed with this, my first de dolle. Maybe its good and I am just not a foreign stout guy

pours lively with large head,nose is grainy with notes of dark chocolate and coffee,flavour starts sweetish then quickly becomes dry with chocolate and coffee flavours and a slight hint of sour,full bodied and with a long dry finish

Bottle @ Ebenezers. Very dark brown pour, fluffy beige head. Aroma holds definite Belgian notes, with pear, apple, plum, yeast, and more dark fruit that comes out as it warms. Flavor holds notes of applesauce, raisin, spice, and chocolate. Very fruity, not as classic a stout as expected. Palate is medium bodied, with a bit of dryness in the finish, solid overall.

Super dark black pour with a tan lasting tan head. Absolutely beautiful. The aroma is sweet in the front with notes of pear, apple, and raisin being most evident. Slight caramel, molasses, and chocolate make their way in as well.  The flavor is exceptionally fruity- like chocolate applesauce. Lots of spices, but the fruit prevails on this one. Chocolate and a slight roast present near the end, as well as a nice yeasty dough note. Palate is very effervescent while maintaining fullness. Interesting for sure.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2010 Bottle @ home, thanks Vaiz! After recuperating from the explosion of opening this beer it poured cloudy dark brown with slight red glow and a medium head which dissipates quickly. Yeasty fruit aroma, very sweet with hint of liquorice and coffee.
Strong liquorice flavour with hints of coffee and caramel. Long aftertaste of liquorice and some yeast.

Sweet, malty, chocolate aroma.  Nice thick appearance with foamy head.  A nice bitter taste, with notes of chocolate and licorice.  A near full feel on the palate, but not full.  If I was into the stouts, I think this beer would be tops.  Really attacks the palate with the various textures and flavors.  But I do not love the chocolate, coffee, licorice type beers.

Bottle. Poured black with thick foamy head, rather too much foam actually.  Powerful aroma of milk, coffee, leather and a strong roastiness. Full flavour, coffee, cocoa and roast.  Lasting milky and tart finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Pours like a coke, with a lingering head. Aroma is fruity, cola, leather, earth. Flavor is earthy, dust, roasted malt, dark fruitiness. Finishes very nicely, with roasty stout, fruit and sourness converging into an awesome ending. Very good.
Pours deep black with cocoa head. Huge aroma in my Sniffer of cocoa and deep roasted malt. Flavor has some definite tang but come nice roastiness as well.

Almost black with an enormous beige and rocky head that settles in an uneven fashion and leaves lots of lacings.

A very interesting smell. Roasted malts are prominent but not dominating. Lots of yeast, planting soil, slightly tart fruits and a strange spicy notes. A note or iron and perhaps just a faint hint of funk.

The taste is rather different for a stout. Sweet roasted malts, a note of burnt coffee and tannins, and a mild fruity tartness dominate. Notes of earth, yeast, wood, spices and sweet dark fruits. The finish is bitter with a complementing tartness, a prominent note of iron, and wood. I really like this.

Medium to full body and lively carbonation.

Tart stouts can be something of a hit or miss, and this one really hits the mark. It has a good balance between roasted sweetness and fruity tartness and its an interesting encounter from start to finish. Lots of character and a complex composition.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Bottle via trade with probstk. Nice grape aromas quite winey, some malty sweetness, light coffee, even mushrooms; very complex!. Quite winey taste,  very sour for a stout, lots of grapes with a nice chocolate/espresso bitter finale. The palate is a little weak; quite water and highly carbonated. Very unique.

Pitch black with a huge, very fine, very frothy, tan head. Aroma: chocolate, dark fruit, roasted malts, caramel. On the sweet side. Like an abt but more roasty. Flavor: roasty and stout-like, wood, bitter chocolate, coffee, caramel, plus a rather Belgian fruitiness. Rather light and thin in body; heavily carbonated too. Very flavorful and quite complex. Woody, roasted finish. Good stout, though I like their Belgian styles better.

12 oz. bottle from Greens.  Pours very dark and cloudy with a bubbly tan head.  Almost opaque but not nearly as thick as your average American or British stout.  More funk and earthiness in the nose than Im used to in a stout.  I find this pretty intriguing when complimented by some of the more traditional stout aromas: roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, even some hazelnut.  The flavor and palate is an absolutely wonderful union of all these aspects.  Maybe the best foreign stout Ive had.

Pours dark inky brown, black in the glass, with a lasting three finger tan head, fine lacing.  Strong grass and coffee aroma, with notes of chocolate, toast, cherry, and pine.  Zesty, crisp, lightly dry, medium-bodied; Ive had thicker porters.  More floral and grassy flavors, coffee, toffee, toast, chocolate.  Medium bitter finish, balances out nicely.  A really nice brew with a surprising amount of delicate hop notes that really stand out -- unique for the style.

Oily black looking with a huge brown head that basically climbs out of the bottle and if youre lucky into your glass. Looks like a stout that could only come from Belgium. Aroma is sharp roasted malts with notes of coffe and dark bitter chocolate. Flavour is more complex with notes of dark dried fruits, sharp slightly acidic coffe which adds to the drinkability. Body is extremely slick and not as fizzy and lively as the head would lead you to belive. Very flavourfull, alive and intense.

250ml Bottle from the Festival Bar at the Old Hall Hotel, Buxton 21/11/2009
Big fruit aroma. Small beige head. Black roasted very strong in alcohol and fruity with a little dryness in a crisp and bitter chocolaty roast finish.

Sampled this after a De Dolle Oerbier Special Reserva with mitchgt.  From my notes: reddish brown pour with a massive bubbly tan head and good retention.  aroma of dark malts and chocolate.  tastes of roasted malts and tobacco mixed with a light sour bite. hint of alcohol warmth in the nose and taste. surprising low carbonation on the tongue given the large head.

Pours a deep, dark chocolate brown. Scant traces of mahogany appear at the edges when held in front of a powerful light source. Most impressive. Big chocolate colored foamy head that fades quite slowly. Excellent retention and some decent lacing.

Sweet, beautiful malty goodness! Pineapple and dark fruit notes. Currants and black cherries. Roasted coffee. Caramel. Toasted nuts. Brown sugar.

Burnt malt and coffee beans intermingle with chocolate notes. Currants, figs and dark cherry tartness mix with green apple peel crispness. A sour presence, not unlike a flemish ale. Fortunately, I love flemish sour ales. 

I would love to rate this higher for mouthfeel but, unfortunately, I find it to be quite weak and waterey. Way too thin for the style, IMO. Everything else about it indicates that it will be thick like molasses. If only.

Very drinkable. Very tasty and good. If it just had a bit more body, it could be perfect. Which means that I will keep searching.

Very dark brown , almost black with nice intens beige head on top. Slight yeastyness with a refined roasty character. A medium body with a fine peppery touch, also a slight fruity twist to it. Touches of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts are well in balans. Aftertaste is elegant, roasty and it hides very well its 9%.

Bottle, Carringtons, Chorlton. Deep dark brown pour with a plump head that lingered for a lil while. Enticing aroma that made me think this was going to be a good thing.  Liquorice, dark fruit, dark chocolate and roasted malt predominating. Lively mouthfeel, but loads to admire in the flavour which revealed more of its complex character with each passing sip. Lovely bitterness in the finish. A very fine Belgian stout.

33 cl bottle. Beige head with dense foam. Sweet aroma with a hint of liquorice. A roasted malt flavour with coffee tones. The rush in the mout ens with a bitter wave and the  coffee tones stay a bit longer and get caught up with a soure tone.

After decapping the bottle it started gushing

Bottle from Knightly.  Not quite black, a deep brown color (although looks black once in the glass) and pours with a thick tan head with nice retention.  The aroma is charcoal, leather, vanilla, wood, definitely some campfire smokey scent in there.  Flavors are peppery and roasty but easy drinking and even a tad thin.  The flavors do pick up with a lot of whats going on in the aroma, tobacco, wood, smoke with the addition of chocolate, black coffee, and caramel.  Not all that complex.  Id say this one is good but not great.

Bottle. 

Beautiful dark color with a brownish rather thick foam. A lot of coffee in the aroma also vanilla, burnt malt, caramel and licorice. The taste was dominated by coffee, not so much chocolate as you might have expected. Clearly a tasty stout that was enjoyable to drink.

pours out super thick and black like an overpowering dark roast coffee with a very thick lumpy tan mocha colored head that produces thick lacing. the body is black as night with no light passing through whats so ever.  the aromas are kind of sweet with hints of coffee and dark chocolate with a tiny hint of the spicyness from the hops and alcohol.  i can also scoop the head out and literaly eat it with a spoon, its that thick(and i really did it).  it is really full bodied and has a nice hoppy hit in the begining with a roasted coffee and chocolate body coming through as the main flavours with a little bit of sugar.  it finishes with bitter sweet caramel and pale malt and has a wonderful aftertaste that is meant to be savored and i do savor it.

Bottle from Ölbutikken, Copenhagen.

Vionous aroma with more similaritys with a barley wine than a stout.

Dry chocolate taste. 

A dissapointment from De Dolle.

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Pours deep brown with a tall, mighty, frothy beiege head. Aroma of spice, espresso, roasted malt, vanilla, chive, and hints of pepper. Full body with a sturdy, bold moutfeel. Powerful, warm finish. Excellent stout.

Thick toffe color pillowy head. Dark chocolatey brown color. Aroma of dark chocolates and dark candies  hints of hazelnuttiness vanilla and caramel sweetness.  Lots of fizz at front very dry nutty flavors little tartness in there as well as it warms it finishes a little smoother and sweeter with the vanilla and caramel notes coming out

Dark brown/Black pour with very lively pillowy beige head that lasts forever.  Aroma is Dark malt, chocolate, hazelnut and yeasty, a bit of vanilla as well.  Flavor starts off with vanilla and a bit of booze and melds into a nice chocolate roastiness.  

Note: as this warms more flavors come out including a subdued tart sourness and some tobacco

~ Purchased this 11.2 oz bottle from New Beer Distributors in Manhattan, NY. Appearance is dark brown with a modest head that just doesnt want to go away. The smell is intense. Dark fruits, spices, yeasts, hints of chocolate and vanilla - its all there! Taste is outstanding. Body is medium and carbonation is on the high side, but thats a good thing because it gives me the chance to pick out all the wonderful flavors. The 9% ABV is masked quite well, but you still get that warm fuzzy feeling from the alcohol.

I feel I am not worthy to drink such an elegant, complex beer such as this! 

World-class! ~
bottle, deepm brown with everlasting tan foam, aroma of coffee and black licorice, flavor is well done roast coffee, buttery caramel as it warms, nice toasty creamy finish

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brwon beer with big beige head. The smell is malty, some chocolate and coffee. The taste is coffee, light caramel, nutty and chocolate, some spices and dark fruits in the background.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a dark brown colour with a huge head and good carbonation.
Smell is very present, has some good nuts there and got nice malts there too.
Taste is a pleasant balance of sweet fruits and spices, good palate makes this beer just right.

(bottle) pours a pitch black colour with a tall rocky off-white head. aroma of toasted malts, floral hops, with big notes of caramel and a hint of roses. flavour is mostly  toasted malts, alcohol and herbal hops, a bit lacking in the drinkablility department. heavy-bodied with light carbonation and a big, roasted-bitter warming finish.

Great aroma- a lively beer. Had to pour slowly due to the foam. Dark black pour with a brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweetness, tasty anticipation. The head is rich, thick- composed of 1000s of tiny bubbles with the top of it frothy like a rootbeer float. % min. later, still pouring.Roasted malt, licorice, sweet flavor, a little dry at the end. It was definately worth the wait. Spotted lacing. Leaves a wonderful flavor in the mouth after each sip.

Pours a deep, barely transparent sable that is chocolaty brown near the bottom of my glass mug. Head is quite thick, light tan and rather persistent. (The head was HUGE with my first pour!) Aroma is smoky with strong coffee and unsweetened chocolate tones as well as hints of malt, hops and even a touch of fruit. Mouth-filling flavor is like fine roast coffee with citrus and nutty hints and touches of unsweetened chocolate and caramel, simply lip-smacking. Texture is thick, smooth and fizzy. A winner!

Chunky dark brown with a creamy tan head.  My first impression was it was a bit odd to jot down yeast as the first noticed aroma in a stout.  Complex and interesting, this was a nice experiment.  Aromas of yeast, chocolate, licorice, molasses and dark fruit.  Taste of chocolate, alcohol, roasted malt, dark fruits, raisons, alcohol and some candy sugar.  Full creamy mouth feel with a mild dry finish and a alcohol bite.  Perhaps a bit too boozy, but overall an interesting mix.  My 1400th RB rating.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2009 Bottle, poured into snifter. Dark black, brown edge, bubbles and foams up like it thinks its a coca-cola and wants to overflow. Nose is soft coffee, toffee, chocolate and biscuity. Flavor is most suprising! A sharp fizzy bitter malt bite hits the tongue as if to say, "I dare you to keep drinking me". Definitely espresso and a rough hint of licorice. Almost a fizzy cola backing to the palate. A very odd taste, and interesting to say the least. It would have to grow on me, and I dont know if it will get the chance to. (as if I were predicting the future, shortly after I finished this rating the second half of my glass found itself leaping from my glass towards the unsuspecting carpet below, I have no idea how this even happened, and now I guess this beer will indeed never get the chance to grow on me, in fact I am quite pissed at the carpet stain it has left behind)

THOUGHTS: Incredible. It was somewhere between a Baltic porter and a foreign stout with some sour ale thrown in for fun. One of the longest lasting heads Ive ever seen on a beer. I was very surprised by how sour it was. A very nice beer, but it would be even better if it were slightly less sour.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was opaque black in the glass with a large to huge, thick foamy, tan head that very slowly diminished, keeping almost the whole thing and leaving fair lacing. The aroma was a little weak but very nice. There was moderate milk chocolate and cocoa, and lighter roasted and coffee malts, light to moderate yeast, a little sour fruit, a little tobacco and slight licorice. The initial flavor was sweet, sour, and slightly bitter; while the finish was fairly sweet, rather sour and a little bitter with and average to long duration. There was roasted malt, cocoa, milk chocolate, sour coffee, sour fruit, yeast, a little chocolate syrup, and a little licorice. The sourness decreased a little near the end. The medium to full body was creamy then very dry with rather fizzy carbonation and a heavy to harsh astringent and light alcoholic finish.

Very dark brown black with a lovely caramel coloured head. Aroma is malts, alcohol and a little spice. Flavour coffee and chocolate which really grew the longer it was around, abv is noticeable but not always a bad thing. Quite tasty indeed for a belgian stout. Good work.

Bouteille de 330 ml, acheté à Bauer Wine and Spirits à Boston le 8 juillet 2009. Noire pure, bon collet. Arome de café noire malté très torrifié, des notes subtile de cacao. Le goût et pas mal la même chose, mais un peu plus sucré, finission de café amère. Ça raproche pas mal à limpérial, mais cest une bière très vivace dans la bouche avec un côté de douceur!
Ottima, stout ruvida e aggressiva che regala momenti di stordimento sensoriale nellassalto di caffè amaro che coglie ad ogni sorso impreparati.

330 ml bottle. Black. Beige head that clings to the glass. Clear. Roasted aroma with hints of raisin. Intense sourish roasted malt flavours. Feels very thin. Sharp and unbalanced. A lot of sharp alcohol notes. Not good at all. Feels oxidized as well and there is a lot of acetaldehyde. Terrible. Tasted at 9C. I’m sure it was a lot better when I tried it 10 years ago.

Pitch black beer with a small settled brownish head. Very carbonated. Aroma of caramel and ground. Flavor is softy sweet with a bitterness that comes quickly after that and starts to dominate, which I dont like that much. Overall a very good beer.

Black with a really lively head that took 15 min to settle. Awesome looking beer. Nose is tobacco and roasted malt, with a hint of yeastiness. Flavor is pretty interesting...a little anise and slight funky cherries to start, massive carbonation gives it a seltzer water mouthfeel. THe high carbonation is a little much early on, but as it warms, more of the chocolate and sourness come out as well as the dusty de dolle signature yeast. As Ive come to expect from these guys, a very unique and very well constructed beer.

Pours black, with a large lightbrown head. There is also some small white dots. Aroma is blackberry, light tobaco and light chocolate. Flavour is light sour, light chocolate, light alcohol, some blackberry. Very vinous.

Dark as dark can be, with a nice head that hangs around a bit.

The aroma is a bit roasty, subtle choc. nibs and a bit sour. 

On the pallet is a bit of a surprising sourness, faint roast with a touch o black licorice, finishes a bit sour again, then sweet with a bid of cardamom.

A little lean on the body, it does seem to sticky up a bit after a couple of quaffs.

I wasnt too excited at firts, but found myself going back for more, again and again. I enjoyed it.
Bottle at The Raleigh Times. Chocolate smell, tart tangy finish. Very weird, very dry. Not crazy for this Belgian yeast/chocolate stout hybrid.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a big creamy, foamy tan head.  Slightly sour aroma with a toasty roast malt backbone.  Full roast malt flavor of chocolate and roast malt up front, with a rich milky note.  Very fizzy, foamy feel with a slightly tart finish.

Bottle at De Dolle Brouwers.  Black color with a huge tan head.  Aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate, and fruit.  Flavor is roasted malt, espresso, chocolate, berries, and licorice.  Ever so slightly tart on the finish, but this is not a bad thing.  Palate medium with high carbonation for the style.  An awesome stout.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2009 Bottle - Oh, De Dolle. Your beers surprise and delight me every time I pop them. I only wish you were more accessible and cheaper. Of course, you have to pay to get quality. But I digress...

Pours black with a massive brown head. This sucker nearly gushed on me as it opened with a huge pffft! Smells of molasses, vanilla, lactose, brown sugar and raisins. Its smooth and sweet with just a little heat. Tastes mostly the same, though its a bit hard to pin down. Theres some whiskeyish heat in there, but not much for 9%. Medium roast with an odd sour/lactic characteristic that really grew on me. It doesnt taste off...just different. Theres a little coffee and chooclate in there, and though its creamy, its a bit watery. Overall though, a fantastic beer. I need more De Dolle.

Bottle.  Pour is dark murky black with huge tan head.  Aroma is wet wood, musky, earthy, hints of dried fruits, faint chocolate, a hint of espresso, and licorice.   Flavor is funky and sweet up front with earthy tones.  Hints of berries and dried fruit in the middle with a coffee background.  Finish is sweet and sourish with chocolate and a light alcohol burn.  Interesting stout with a lot of character; kind of like a tripel/stout combo.

gusher! opaque brown, thick foamy tan head.
aroma is sweet and sour bread. just sour malt, i dont know about this one.
taste is similar with odd artificial black licorice sourness in finish, but otherwise tasty. sweet.
medium body, over carbonation. 
i dont know, maybe it was bad, i mean it really exploded, and the odd finish was not good.

aroma is of light raspberry and sweet roast.  coffee notes are minimal at this point. pour is quite lively with a very airy head for the style. flavor starts with slightly muddy fudge notes and ends with more raspberry and black cherry. booze is nil. palate is sharp and lively with spicy hops and ends mostly dry. overall a nice alternative to dry irish stouts.  without the overwhelming flavors of an imperial stout but still packs the same punch. fairly straightforward yet satisfying beer for de dolle.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2009 I drank this from a bottle into a chalice.

It pours with a dark brown color with an airy tan head.  

It smells sweet but yet there is a touch of bitter coffee in there as well.

The taste is chocolate and berries with a medium dry body.

Very good stout.

Enjoyed from a 11.2 oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The sample pours a dark brown to black with a very long-lasting tan head.  Notes of malt sweetness, Belgian esters of plums and raisons, and some bread come through in the nose.  The palate initially brings a note of malt, perhaps Special "B," followed by the characteristic characters of a foreign export stout- roasted malts, dark chocolate, and some assertive hopping.  The palate finishes with the sorts of esters one would normally get in a Belgian-style dubbel.  The only thing I found to be a negative was the level of carbonation, which was on the level of a tripel; so much so that the bottle overflowed when opened, causing the loss of at least 1/4 of the contents.  The alcohol was well-hidden, contributing a simple warming in the throat.  Overall, a great beer and excellent variation of foreign stout.

Bottle 33cl from crackedkettle.com. Very dark mahogany with a huge beige head. Apple, yeast, candy sugar, lemon peel and cress in the nose which is surprisingly sour. The taste is sourish aswell. Dry. Yeasty. Medium bodied. Lively carbonation. Fizzy. Nice lacework. Roasted malt is most present in the finish which is very dry. Interesting and atypical.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2012 Pours dark brown with a thick creamy tan head. Toffee and chocolate aroma. Very bubbly in the mouth. Taste of choc and berries. 8473 13, 3.5... Another bottle. Black, creamy brown head. Aroma of soy, molasses, leather, ash, earthy. Taste is also earthy with soy, leather, bitter roast coffee, some sweet berry and dark fruit, molasses, very thick texture, smooth and silky carbonation.
Botlle. Deep brown with a small creamy cappuccino coloured head. Aromas of milk chocolate, tobacco and sweet malt. Taste is roasted, malty, a bit sour, chocolate and malty sweet.
Bottle. Bottle immediately foamed when opened. Dark pour with head that lasted.Very enjoyable stout with flavor and aroma that match.
Split with JRedmond.  Pours dark brown w/ light brown head.  A good brown ale with a slight smokiness and tang.  Belgian influence noticable.

6/2/09 notes: bottle, poured into a snifter.  Appears dark brown, with a MASSIVE, distinctly De Dolle, tan head.  Aroma has more trademark De Dolle estery yeast, along with some interesting green apple, Fuji apple, and dark chocolate.  Upon first sip, one realizes this is no ordinary Impy Stout, or not one that Ive tried before.  Front palate yields sour apple dashed with bakers chocolate.  This is complemented by chocolate covered cherry.  No real coffee or roasts present here.  Palate features pearly carbonation, and a prickly feel initially that moves towards a lingering, soft finish.  Overall, this beer is absolutely unique, in a way that I love!  There are unexpected elements to this flavor, kind of a sour ale crossed with a stout.  No ABV detected in body.  Awesome!
Bottle split with Pwn3d. Pours a dark brown body with small light brown head. Aroma is nut and roast. Taste is nicely carbonated - reminds me of a Unibroue.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2009 Colore nero profondo, impenetrabile e corposo. Molto abbondante e spumosa la schiuma, ottima persistenza.Profumo molto complesso alcoolico con note di caffè, liquirizia, legno bruciato e liquore di caffè. Sapore asciutto e denso, con forte impatto di liquirizia e caffè torrefatto. Finale alcoolico e durevole.

Sampled at the Alexi Distributors event at Limelight. Thanks Jim Bird! Murky brown pour with creamy brown head.  Nose is a little tart cherry.  Not too much roast, with a tart finish.  Very prickly carbonation.  Overrated.

Higly carbonated with a lightly astringent mouthfeel. Aroma and flavor of cocoa nibs and alcohol in a suspension of roasted malt. Sweet coffee stirred with a stick of chocolate. Odd little beer, but nice enough.
pours black with small head. aroma is sweet malts, chocolate, coffee, a little soy. drinks with coffee, malts, yeast, sugar sweetness. very nice

33 cl Bottle Thanks to Edo (Bierkoning). Almost black with a huge foamy brown head. Sweet malty aroma with roasted notes,coffee and chocolate. The falvor is even more complex as it also includes ripe red fruit and some licorice. The alcohol is very well hidden. Nice one.

Bottled in Cafe Frape. Color is black, with huge foamy soft head. Cofee and roasted malts in the nose. Aroma is coffee, toffee, malts and chocolate. Flavour is dry, with chocolate and lots of roasted malts. The alcohol is very well hidden, thebeer has the body for it. Very well composed and complex beer! Magnificent!
bottle, black colour, soft yellow head, smells malty, taste: roasted malt, coffee, very sweet, bitter, dried plums, hoppy. Very nice balanced stout! Lovely!

Bottle. A very nice aroma, roasted malt, coffee and some cacao, also chocolate. The head is very large, brown and foamy, the duration is very long. The body is black. The first taste is fruity, then it gets malty, also some chocolate in the middle, the finish is a little bit sour with a long duration. The body is medium strong with a lot of carbonation and a very creamy body. A great Stout!

Deep dark brown with tan head. Sweet, fruity, hot, ripe aromas. Fruit cake, acidic coffees, apples, and dates. Nice carbonation level is soft and not too high. Great panoply of flavors are sour, sweet, and roasty together. Love the brewery, love the beer.

Pours a pitch black color with a huge, foamy mocha colored head that settles a to a thin blanket on top. The aroma shows notes of dry, dark chooclate, oak, espresso, and a funy sour yeast character. The flavor is dry and roasty as well with dark espresso and chocolate coming through with hints of oaky vanilla thats adds smoothness. The sour yeast is present throughout and adds an interesting character to the brew. Medium bodied with a lot of carbonation for a lively mouthfeel that finishes dry, and slightly sour. Pretty nice foreign stout.
Poured dark brown, sweet and robust,  roasted malts,  chocolate,  very vinous, little licorice.

[1937-20090110] 11.2floz bottle. Licorice anise aroma has heavy malt and sugary sweet wood chips. Dark dark brown red body with a medium-lasting creamy dark brown head. Sweet heavy roasted malt flavour. Full body. Enjoyable.
(w/ DuctTape, jerc)

Bottle shared by Fidel, pours deep brown with a towering, tight bubbled, dark tan frothy head. Nose is chocolate, licorice and a sugary influence. Flavor is the same with the addition of dark vinous flavor. Subtle bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel.
Very dark and browninsh pouring, Big head. Maltya and Sweet aromas makes a complex scent. Full bodied and malty taste. Not like Stouts usual strange and good.

11.2oz bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours a deep coffee brown with an ENORMOUS beige head that seemed to stick around forever.  Nose of dark toasted malts with a hint of booze as well as chocolate and coffee.  Flavor was much of the same with coffee flavors and booze being dominant. Didnt really do much for me.
.."crazy" from the crazies .. . possess dust, wood, cherries and lacto flavours .. . complex and strange . . nice stuff but abstract and DnB remix quality .. .

Bottle. This might be the classic belgian stout.  Huge tan head atop a dark brown body.  Nose is roasty, light cocoa, a bit nutty, earthy, and some light smoke. Flavors mainly mimic the aroma with the signature de dolle yeast shown in the finish. Alcohol hidden pretty darn well.  Enjoyable.

Draught @ Zythos march 7th 2009. The head of this beer was so sturdy, you should eat your way through to get to the beer. This scum is very bitter and endures for ages. Thats why I didnt take my first nip until much later. Finally, absolutely no sweetness found, though it could be masqueraded bij the hops. The palate is rated on a mediocre 3 because it seems not complete. A pity.

Dark crimson color with good head and lacing. Licorice and roast with some fruit in the nose. The flavor is sweet, malty and chocolaty followed by a roasty, moderately bitter middle with accompaning coffee and caramel note. Great brew.

Bottle, thx Kingcecil. 
Pours dark ruby with a huge tan head. 
Aroma is caramel, coffee and dark chocolate with notes of prunes and liquorice. 
Flavour is roasted malt and coffee with spicy notes and a strong dark chocolate aftertaste. Nice!

Bottle. Pours a nice black/brown color with a big head. Aroma is filled with sweet notes of dark fruit and some plums and caramell. Also som chocolate in there. Taste is about the same as the aroma with a bit thin mouthfeel.

(33cl bottle, sampled at room temperature) Almost black colour with a giant and stable brown foamy head. Sweet and strong roasty malty aroma with licorice and a very subtle berry-fruity touch, accompanied by lighter notes of coffee and gingerbread, also shy traces of alcohol are detectable. Burnt bitter and moderately sweet flavour, full bodied with an almost crispy carbonation, which is rather disadvantageous here. Full roasty malty base with licorice, coffee, traces of chocolate and dried fruits. Drying out effect towards the end, but still moderately sweet and roasty bitter finish with a moderate alcoholic burn and traces of herbal hops. Complex and moreish Stout (26.II.09)..

The head explodes in the glass and takes forever to dissipate.  An almost black beer.  Molasses aroma with chocolate.  Chocolate dominates the aroma.  Nuts, hop, and dark fruit flavors as well.  Feel is quite effervescent.  Very nice and a fun drinking experience.

33cl bottle from hop duvel in Ghent.
pours dark brown with strong foam head, aroma is dark roasted malt with chocate. very solid beer like you have eaten and drunken at the same time. some touches of bitter hop but well hidden.

Bottle.  Pours dark black with a creamy head.  Aroma is of dark chocolate, some slight sweetness of malts and booziness. Taste is big on dark roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.  Some sweet notes to it, nice finish.

bottle: pours a dark oily black with a thick creamy tan head that stays. aroma is a little odd to start with a tartnes and good chocolate the tartness may come from the slight cheery i get interesting and enjoyable. flavour is a dry esspresso and dark bitter chocolate finishes very dry and roasty another interesting beer from de dolle.

De Dolle owes me a carpet cleaning and two keyboards, just from the past six months or so. Fucking gushers. 11.2 ounce bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a black color with a large head, good head retention and sticky lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, coconut, chocolate, pineapple. Taste seems to be a little more like a stout than the aroma... roasted malts, chocolate, coffee. Medium bodied.
Black in color.  Beige head.  Small bottle.  Lots of chocolate and coffee.  Musky.  I find it a little sweet, fruity, and spicy for a stout.  Not my favorite, but well done.
Pours nearly black.  Surprising amount of carbonation produces more head than most beers of this style.  Sweet, fruity aroma.

33cl Bottle from De Bierkoning. Almost black colour, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, liquorice, a hint of sourness. Flavour is roasted malts, liquorice, dark chocolate, some sugar with a good bitter moccha/espresso finish. Strong carbonation, preventing this beer from being highly drinkable. Nice flavours though.
Bottle. Very fruity, dark fruit malty huge overpowering head. Aromas of yeast, bitter chocolate, and barn. Nice filling tast, nice end.

Pours a cola color with an incredibly carbonated, effervescent, rich tan head. Would I expect any less from a Belgian yeast? Smells effusively of dark chocolate with some sweet licorice and espresso notes atop gently toasted malts. Earthy hops also come through well in the nose. The flavor is something altogether different, very sweet and fruity up front , and the roasted malts have a more burnt character on the tongue. Bitter coffee lingers on the finish. Has a very dry and bubbly mouthfeel, uncharacteristic for a stout yet typical of Belgian beers. Overall, a unique beer, but off the mark of what I desire in a stout. Too much bitterness, sweetness, and carbonation.

Fruity, rich and slightly sour stout.  Nose of chocolate, prunes, toffee, roast and caramel.  The mouthfeel is quite full, slightly thick, and carbonation is medium.  Additional smoke, coffee, raisin and licorice in the flavor.  Ends rather smooth and slightly bitter, but mostly roasty and slightly warm. Not your traditional stout, really more of a farmhouse Belgian Black Ale.

Bottle.  Roasty malt aroma, relatively mild, with some fruitiness.  Dark brown body, large tan head.  Very fizzy carbonation gives a mouthfeel that is deceptively light.  Flavor is mostly roasty and not very complex.  Brief finish.

burnt coffee aroma, some malts. after pour mellows a bit to some heavy barley wine notes, raisin, dark fruits, prune maybe seems strong in alcohol. dark dark brown color, but definitely brown. Massive carbonation explosion upon opening, but perhaps was just my bottle. Duvel level head formation. palate is fizzy as commensurate with pour. taste is highly bitter, somewhat coffee stoutish. Still a hint of high ABV, but the more subtle flavors of the aroma seem missing.

This is completely disgusting. 

Pours a brown color with a monster creamy light brown head. What was awesome was I drank this outside at -1 degrees and the head was freezing into meringue like gobs within minutes. Nose is grapes, battery acid, and as the guy below me said a weird salty sour nose. Taste is just just tart and bitter and kind of smokey but also fruity. Its a total mess. I dont know if this batch was screwed up but I dont want anything to do with this beer again anytime soon.

De dolle is officially on notice.

bottle from ølbutikken.
pours brown, is black in the glass, giant thick brown smooth head.
strange salty/sour aroma. not what id expect in a stout. faint chocolate. perhaps the salty aroma is from licorice?

flavor sour, mixed with the ordinary stout flavors. tart. licorice. slight smoked stuff in the aftertaste. warming up it seems to be more balanced. the salty lime taste lingers in the background and makes it all a bit surreal.
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 Pours out black with lots of brown foam, overflowing. Sweet roasty malty. Lots of chocolate, coffe, and molasses. But with a lot funk. Some tartness. Great twist on style.

Reviewed 12/16/2008 (bottle):

Foams over unattended. Pours a dark black body, cant see through. Big creamy, smooth head, tan head. Good lacing. Toffee sweet malty aroma. Strong molasses and some alcohol, but not much. Molasses flavor, hot aftertaste. Some light coffee, and .roasted flavors. Somewhat dusty, ashy. Creamy mouthfeel, fizzy and almost harsh. Pretty tasty.

Im truly impressed by this one. The pour is absolutely beautiful. HUGE head - it went almost an inch over the glass and stood still, like an incredibly well-foamed cappuccino. Black in color with a light brown head. The aroma is very mild, and belies the powerful flavor. Notes of cacao, coffee, molasses / dark brown sugar, and a bitter aftertaste suggesting a much hoppier brew. The coffee really comes through at the end, too. Palate is dry and clean, but the flavor is deep and rich. Wonderful.
The gem in a stout tasting. But is this really a stout? Lots of malts and musky flavor. Sweet. But a stout? The Belgians do it differently.

Deep bown in the pour and black in the glass with perfect beige coloured foam. Aroma is coffee like and slight hoppy with some hints of roasted malts and black chocolate. Taste is clean with lots of roasted sensations, touches of coffee, chocolate and soft hops. mouthfeeling is medium to full and longlasting. A great Belgian styled Stout.
Deep pitch black with a huge tan head.  Aromas of chocolate, hops, licorice. Smooth medium bodied mouthfeel. Sweet malty and coffee like. Long interesting lasting flavors. Very good brew.

Black stout with a thick creamy moka head. Wonderful vinous chocolate with earthy rather Belgian style. Sour chocolate in mouth, with good hops notes and some coriander. Rich and enjoyable. Tasted Spring 2006.

Pours a dark chestnut/chocolate brown with no light penetration. 3+ fingers of head. HOLY WOW THAT’S SOME HEAD!  Huge smell of prunes, chocolate, a hint of molasses and some licorice. Has that Belgian "Funk" as I call it. I’m not sure this is a stout. I don’t care, smells great! Deep rich chocolate and molasses covered prunes. This is a brew that has been blessed by the gods. There are hints of mint and licorice along side with a hint of anise and some bitter chocolate. A+ Taste! OMG this beer makes me want to guzzle, but I think twice and enjoy each and every sip. This beer is creamy and smooth. it’s a lot like cream itself except it is beer, a really really great beer. Another hit by De Dolle! Very drinkable! I am in love with this beer and I strongly believe that a little cellaring time will only enhance this mystical brew! Thank you De Dolle!
Chewy, chocolatey, bitter, thick stout in the American style.  Reminds me of Bell’s Expedition Stout.  Should age very well.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown/brown with a fizzy carbonated 1 inch head.  Aromas of roasted malts, cocoa, and a bit of espresso.  Flavors are dry, bittersweet cocoa, roasted malts and a touch of hops.  Long fizzy finish.

smells like a funky stout.  not like other belgian stouts I have had.  very malty smell.  lots of chocolate - and FUNK.  crazy lacing, underlying earthy herb type taste.  puckering.  and interesting beer that everyone should try.  but onlly buy one bottle

33cl bottle from Barley Wine. It poured a pitch black colour with a huge
beige foamy head that settled down slowly in the glass leaving about a
finger height roof. The aroma is acidious but is also heavy on the coffee.
The flavour is also acidious and reminds me of a sour ale. The flavour
tastes of coffee, roasted malts and a hint of vinegar(!?). It has a
lingering aftertaste.

Pours a dark dark black with four enormous fingers of silky, creamy chocolate colored head that does not go away.  Aroma is roasty malt, chocolate and alcohol.  Very strong roasted body, sweet chocolate, slight dark fruits, then pretty big bitter coffee and hop finish.

Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pours a chalky black. Pretty good chocolate and coffee nose. Flavors a bit watery but chocolate and coffee are there with some yeast and caramel. Not too bad of a beer.

Poured dark brown, almost black, with a ridiculously large tan head.  Chocolate and toffee aromas, but the flavor is dominated more by the coffee.  Full-bodied with a lasting finish, but not a great finish.  I was hoping for more.

Pour cautiously as this giant beautiful tan head explodes up the glass and lasts. Dark brown brew emminating aromas of roasted caramal. Very smooth, roasted coffee and semi sweet chocolate. Mostly malty raison and dark fruit but slight bitter, gentle warmth.

Bottle. Gusher upon opening!! After cleaning up the mess it poured black with a tall creamy tan head that settled to a thin layer and left good lacing. Roasty coffee aroma with chocolate and faint spice backing. The flavor finds chocolate and coffee with a roasty undertone. Medium body, lively carbonation, bitter coffee aftertaste.
Bottle.  Pours a black body with a creamy tan head.  Roasty bitter coffee, chocolate malt, nutty, with spices.  A solid stout, even from across the pond.

Pours dark brown/black with a huge brown head. Aromas of burnt malts, coffee, chocolate and alcohol. Roasted malt and coffee flavors with a good amount of sourness that really surprised me. Medium to full body with spritzy carbonation and a dry finish.

33cl bottle. Pours deep opaque black with an absolutely immense brown head. The head faded unevenly leaving interesting crevasses and pockets of air as it slowly went down. It fades slowly into a persistent thin disc of brown that has variations in shade (tan to brown) with interesting concentric circles and spots. Mesmerizing. The aroma is intense: chocolate, subtle sourness, dark fruit and raisins, alcohol, and standard De Dolle house yeast character. The flavor starts with subtle acid and lots of dark roast and dark fruit flavors. Acidity/sourness grows slightly as the beer remains on the palate - but never gets intense enough to label this a sour ale. There are notes of wood and subtler notes of treacle and licorice in there, too. The beer finishes rather full on the back of the tongue with a great level of malts, roasted grains, burnt toast, and persistent subtle acetic quality (like a drop of balsamic vinegar). The back of the mouth tastes a lot like a mix of red wine and espresso with some caramel toffee thrown in for sweetness. The mouthfeel is lively and much softer than expected given the huge head that poured out of this bottle. I guess the carbonation is quite delicate and bursts forth upon pouring, leaving only a balancing level of suds that help make the body creamier and lighter while providing only the slightest of tingle to the tongue. The body is rather full. The beer is quite filling, too - and warming with alcohol (though the flavor hides the alcohol amazingly well). Overall, a very complex and interesting stout but a tad bit unfocused. It would likely show great improvement after some aging (I picked this up just a few months ago and can only assume it is a fresh bottle that is young from the brewery).

Watch out, bottle exploded on me all over my tv remote and white carpet.  Pours a viscous very dark brown with a little beige froth.   Big sticky licorice, prune, rye bread, deep roasted malt aroma that blends well with the obvious high ABV.   This stuff is very bitter tasting.   Bitter bitter bitter burnt rye bread, actually very dry too.   Light licorice, coffee and chocolate.  Medium syrupy body that is highly carbonated.  Dark.

11.2 oz bottle. Slightly tart, vinous and seemingly roasty aroma. Bittersweet Belgian chocolate. Wisps of funky De Dolle yeast. Watered down espresso. Prunes and raisins. Not overly bitter roasted malt. Interesting mix of malt and tart yeast. Pours nearly opaque dark brown with a fleeting thick khaki head. flavor is fairly anise heavy. Bitter chocolate. Roasted malt. Some very earthy and slightly dirty hops. Espresso. A vinous yeast presence throught keeps things at least semi interesting. Medium bodied with distracting and mouth filling carbonation. Finishes rather short, roasty and a tad tart. 

The bottom of the bottle with the yeast is worlds better than the top 7/8ths. Carbonation is toned down, yeast shines through, anise is tamed. The funkiness of the yeast work wonders with the roastiness of the malt. A warming alcohol presence lingers on the finish. Bonus points for the yeast pour, but the majority of the bottle just didn’t do it for me.
Bottle. Black. Incredible "brownish" head. Smells like sour choclate (in a good way). Complex flavor. Dry. Lots of choclate. Little whiskey.

33cL Bottle. Light soft cotton, silk, toffee, and chocolate aroma. A really dry, dusty roast note. Maybe a bit of tangy, some Belgian esters, and a nice bit of truffle-liquer. Pours a murky dark brown, with a tall, sparse rocky khaki head. Oooh. Complex. A real rollercoaster of flavors. Starts of airy and explosive with signature belgian yeast profile, a bit spicy and backed with fruit. Then into the chewier caramelized malts, toffees and espresso beans. The darkness ramps up. The some mature complex alcohols and ruby red fruits. Finally, a quick flourish in brief hop and yeast juicyfruit. All of this over a rather light and delicate body. Well balanced, yet rich satisfying complex and delicious. Sorry Tsunami Stout, this is just too good. There really isn’t much wrong with this beer, it’s right on in many dimensions.

Pours a deep rich brown with a huge tan head.  Aroma is nutty, malty, with some chocolate and toasted nuts mixed with a hint of coffee.

Flavor is smooth as silk with just a hint of roasted coffee bitterness and just another little hint of alcohol.  This is a very nice stout.
Dark brownish colour. Pale brown head. Some sournes in the taste. Also some bitter chocolate aromas. Also some prunes in the taste. Tasted at Pikkulintu.

Bottle from Chevy Chase, purchased in ’05.  The years have been very kind to this gem.  Pours a barely-red-tinged black, big bubbles but mild lacing.  Aroma has started developing more of that traditional De Dolle acidity that mingles with the caramel, figs, and some roast.  Alcohol is there too, but only a mild spicy backnote.  Body is full, luscious, like drinking milk chocolate.  Big strong dark fruit up front, carbonation helping it from being too heavy.  Flavor coasts through the range of malty complexity, stopping at chocolate, a bit of sherry, and finishing with a bittersweet, toasty, booze-laced finish.  A world-class beer.  Just fantastic.

33cl. bottle...pours dark, opaque brown with a tan,  soap-foam head...Aromas of vinous fruits, yeast, bitter chocolate, cocoa, light coffee. Lots of cola like flavors, mixed with dark bitter-sweet chocolate, roasted malts, and a strong espresso presence. It also had a fruity sweetness not unlike toasted figs or dries dates. Highly carbonated, somewhat acidic, and a lingering bitter aftertaste. Excellent!

bottle by way of yobdoog... opaque black body with a hot cocoa colored head. it’s fluffy and leaves a bit of lacing as it comes to permanent rest as a film. chocolate-y aroma with whiffs of ash, black raisins, coffee, lactose and some spiciness (from the yeast?). the flavor is kinda christmas cake-y... yeast, licorice, dried fruits along with chocolate, charred wood, coffee, figs, floral yeast and raisins burnt on the grill completely dried out and hollow. you know you shouldn’t eat them but you do any way. tart dry finish leads to coffee in the aftertaste. medium body. acidic carbonation... and a lot of it. relatively easy to put away @ 9%.

Very dark, with a medium tan head that is very carbonated. Aromes of sugar, cola, cocolate, malts. Not the worst belgian stout, but I just don’t like the carbonated, sweet, belgian style. I will stick to amcerican and endglish-irish examples. I do like the label that is a blatant ripoff of Harvey’s Imperial Stout, I just wish it were half as good.
Black with the peculiar huge Dolle’s head. Very strong aromas. The typical slight acidity that characterize brews from that brewery. Spicey. Chocolatey. Coffee. Luscious.

(Belgium) Pours  a sweet black color with a beautiful foamy tan head.( appx 2 1/2 inches) The aroma is of dark malts, chocolate, coffee, and spices. The mouthfeel is thick and yummy with a dry bitter finish. Taste is of roasted malts, coffee, hops and espresso. This was a full bodied stout from De Dolle that will not disappoint. :)
Black pour and a tan head.  Aromas of raisins, malt, and some chocolate.  Flavor is toasty and chocolate and some espresso.  Not bad, but not the best ever.  Still very enjoyable.

Pours a very dark black with an off white head. Aroma is of fruit, berries, dark roasted malt, very complex. Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, maybe some coffee, some bitterness in the finish. Over all not my favorite of the De Dolle line but still very drinkable enjoyable stout.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a pitch black beer with a frothy off-white head. The arome is fruity with blackberries and tobacco. Lots of complex aromas based on dark roasted malts. The flavor follows the nose with some alcohol, some acidity and fruits. The beer is a little overcarbonated, but overall a very nice belgian stout.

This one exploded on me as I popped the top, so there was only about 5 oz. left to drink.  Not crazy about the aroma, but the taste is good - strong note of grainy coffee, plus roasted malt and hoppy bitterness.  Some alcohol warmth.  Smooth palate with a lingering bitter finish.  Will rerate when I can drink an entire bottle.

First snifter is nothing but a beige head. Though EES calms down a bit and I can eventually find some liquid at the bottom (its dark brown with hints of red), the head is excessive throughout. Nose is roast, dough, alcohol, and lots of sweet dark fruit. The flavor is very similar, but burnt and bitter with less sweetness and more roast. Palate is thick and creamy. Not very complex, and coffee stouts are slowly fading from the "favorites" list, yet this is still smooth and rather cohesive.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of alcohol, chocolate, must, coffee, malts, hazelnut, and licorice.  Very complex aroma.  Huge gusher.  Poured black in color with a massive, foamy, brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Flavor of smoke, roasting, chocolate, coffee, cocoa, and a hint of licorice.  Medium to full body.  Creamy, then chalky texture.  Soft carbonation.  Smokey, malty finish.
Bottle. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and maple syrup. Roasted flavor that is both sweet and salty. More coffee, some fruit. Nice.

Bottle.  Pours black with a huge, thick, creamy head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, roast and coffee, dark fruits, apple.  Flavor of initial bitterness, lots of roast, nuts, and charred notes.  Just slightly a little more bitter than I’d prefer, but this was a good Belgian stout

Poured a black-brown body with a dense brown-grey head.  Nose of nuts, coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, and brown sugar.  Yeasty caramel presence halfway in.  Beautiful subtle lingering bouquet of complex flavors.  Dry mild bitter and slightly tart finish.

Dark brown pour with a fluffy tan head.  Hazelnut, chocolate, currant, licorice, and sourdough aroma.  Kind of a hybrid tart/sour flavor mixed with more typical stout like features.  A pretty good mixture, but the sour just doesn’t quite work here.  Not bad, I guess it’s just not my cup of tea.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2008 11,2 ounce bottle in Duvel glass.  Black with huge (way to much) brown head and lace.  Earthy dark chocolate and yeast and cookie dough aroma.   Chocolaty sugary dark fruit flavor with surprising bitter bite.  Lingering sugar and bitterness.  Medium full body and medium-high carbo.  Really too much carbonation.  Fairly complex with a mixture of pleasant and harsh flavors.

I made the mistake of not giving this enough time to cool down.  Opened this up and it immediately gushed out of the bottle and all over the kitchen.  Very highly carbonated.  Flavors were very dark and musty.  Quite dry and complex, kind of similar to flavor notes found in scotch.  I want to try again with a well refrigerated bottle.
Black pour, huge tan head.  Very sugary, huge espresso, dark chocolate and candi sugar malt.  Dry and bitter finish.

pours muddy dark black with a large rocky light brown head.  Aroma is moderatly malty of dark bread , grain and roasted malts.  lightly hoppy of pine and lemons, heavily yeasty , barnyard, grapes, apple and port.  Flavor starts balanced nice roasty flavor on the sweet side with an interesting yeast flavor finishes more sweet but same malt profile.  medium bodied, creamy and fizzy.  Way to much co2 for style.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex dry Stout, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, good brew

bottle. Lots of carbonation, my filled with foam very quickly, no big deal, just saying. Pitch black, big head of course. Nice roastiness to it. Warm alcohol straight up, suprising for 9%. A little bitterness in the finish as well, quite good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Well, wasn’t expecting that at all.  I managed to read the word stout, but it didn’t look like one when poured.  Dark brown in color with hardly any head.  First taste is musky and dry, but hugely carbonated.  A very nice sipper, as it would take a few of these to pick out all the flavors.  Thanks to BillVanE!

Wow what a different beer. Extreme crispness that is sour and lip smacking, which is bizarre for a black, higher abv imp stout. Lots of fruit-skins in this one. Plum skin, cherry skin, apple skins, but the blackness of the beer comes through with roasted chocolate midway through the sip to mute the sprites of tart fruits. This one had a particularly harsh carbonation to it that would prevent me from drinking many in a single evening, but the price and abv would do the same as well, right?

12oz bottle. Been curious to try this, stouts from funky brewers can be sometimes astounding and sometimes wierd and offputting. Nose on this one is amazing. Reminiscent of the Expedition Stout but with a light tart citrus note. Very chocolate with coffee roasty notes. Awesome near black pour with a huge impressive chocolate colored head. Huge retention and terrific lacing. Taste wise I think this is amazing. Up front you get chocolate then tart sour cherry but very light which carries away some of the bitterness the finish is roasty and chocolately with a sweet note and lingering chocolate on the palate. One of the best stouts I’ve had. Up there with Expedition. The one cavaet. This doesn’t have the flavor profile of an imp stout, so the 9% alcohol comes through maybe a little more than it should, if this had been 7/5 or even 8% I think the balance would have been perfection. As it is this is a fanastic beer.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours pitch black with a big, dense brown head and a sweet malty aroma. The taste is initially creamy, malty sweet, but bitter elements come kicking in really soon and give this beer a great bite. A great beer but not De Dolle’s best.

Massive head.  Caramel notes with roasted chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is strong in your face with high carbonation and spice and wood.  I catch some sourness in the finish but it goes nicely with the strong upfront wood and roasted notes.  Finished dry with a slight sour aftertaste.  This is a good brew even after having a Black Albert.  Another quality brew from De Dolle

11.2 oz bottle 9% ABV. Pours black with a huge rocky tan head that fell rapidly. Dark roasted and chocolate malt aromas with a touch of wood. Roasted malt dominates flavor with notes of coffee and licorice and some woodinesss. Interesting sour and spicey yeast notes. Body feels light with very high carbonation. Wonderfully complex.

Aroma of dark fruits, figs, raisins, chocolate. Heavy carbnation at first taste, sweet, coffee and chocolate. After carbonation settles, very balenced. Cant find one element that is too overpowering. So enjoyable.

Excellent chocolate sugary nose. Huge head, nice pure beige color though. Taste full of subtley layered flavour. Coffee, malts, hops, chocolate, and red candy fruit. A little explosive, but definitely a fine beer.

Massive gusher... a veritable beer bomb.  Dark black pour with bubbly dark tan head in abundance.  Lovely complex nose... bitter chocolate, hops, Belgian yeast and sugar, roasty malt, a little smoke, a little burnt coffee.  Flavor didnt really follow through in impressing me, partly because the aroma was so nice.  Pleasant bitterness and some fruit on the tongue.  Some lactic acid sourness, but not much.  This beer starts off subtle and slowly reveals itself; its a good one...

Opaque black pour with a nice long lasting tan head.  Nice lacing on the glass - a beautiful looking beer.  Malty aroma with chocolate notes.
