Lots of fruit as well-apples and grapes, some sourness and lactic acid as well.  Flavor is dominated by bitter malt with chocolate and a touch of acidic sourness as well.  Very dry with a fruity grape winelike character.  A unique beer that I really enjoyed.

Vintage 2003

Pours jet black with a creamy, dense, tan head of one-inch.
Several arching smears of lacework reveal as the beer drinks and a solid surface coat sustains.

Roasted malts, nougat, cloves and citrus lead off the nose. Mildly sweet and plenty chocolaty, with a substantial orange marmalade essence. A hint of red wine follows through. Dark rum and raisins. An interesting blend of fruit, chocolate, and vineousity.

Creamy and velvety mouthfeel. On the thick side of medium and a bit chewy.

Milk chocolate, citrus-spiked rum, and sugar-dusted bubblegum lead off the pallet. 
Some mild vineous notes follow through along with dried cherries,plump raisins, clove-spiked bannana, and estery yeast.

Finishes warming and sweetish with some lingering chocolate.

A really interesting take on a stout, and the De Dolle yeast really shines through. Tastes more along the lines of a strong dark Belgian rather than a stout. A lot of complexity for a five year old brew

11.2 oz bottle. Poured a dark chocolate brown almost black with a long lasting slightly brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and caramel. Flavor is rich, its bitter sweet and nicely balanced with an added alcohol spiciness. Mouth feel is slightly dry and nicely carbonated. This was one of the most satisfying stouts Ive had the pleasure of drinking.

Glass: snifter, tulip
Purchased at: Canals Discount Liquors, Burlington, NJ (Thanks, Mike!)
Price: $4.27
Size: 11.2 fl oz
ABV: 9%
IBU: n/a
Estimated Calories: 200 C
RateBeer Rating: 96

Aural: opening is a long chore. carbonation is overstimulated, pour takes five minutes.

Aroma 8 out of 10
Intensity: strong
Balance: sharp
Impression: a bit off

Malt Flavor: alcohol toffee chocolate roast
Hops Flavor: earth resin
Other: a bit chemical
Notes: alcohol dominates the aroma

Appearance 5 out of 5
Color:  black
Clarity: opaque
Head Retention: persistent
Notes: Deep black body under a great tan head.

Flavor 10 out of 10
Intensity: strong
Balance:  sweet and bitter

Impression: nice
Malt Flavor: burnt caramel toffee chocolate roast coffee
Hops Flavor: earth resin
Other: licorice, espresso, dark, roasted, rich
Notes: A taste that more than makes up for other failings.

Palate 5 out of 5
Mouthfeel
Sensation: creamy slick drying warming
Body:  full
Carbonation: faint
Finish
Length: long
Intensity: strong
Balance: bitter
Notes: A very nice finish, and a unique flavor in the taste.

General Impression: 16 out of 20
Craftmanship: medium
Freshness: seems a bit stale
Personal Taste: liked
Notes: Again, having trouble with a De Dolle bottle opening, which is highly disappointing, considering the cost. Luckily, Ive mastered the art of opening overcarbonated/yeast issue  beers.
Address : <http://beercritic.wordpress.com/>

Huge tan head atop dark brown body w/ maroon tint. Fairly opaque, leaves a nice lacing. Nose of rich malts, chocolate, sweet dark fruits, candi sugar, hints of bananas and bubble gum. On the tongue, a huge sweet maltiness with vinous notes, candi sugar, slightly spicy yeast, chocolate, finishes w/ a nice roastiness. Nice full mouthfeel, slightly drying. This is such a great beer.

Huge thick brown full lasting head. Black colour. Aroma is malty with coffe, roasty, light nutty and raisins notea. Flavor is malty with dark fruity tones, ending in a long roasty finish. Medium bodied.

A great stout. Pours with a huge, rocky brown head, covering an extremely dark brown body. Aroma is of toasted malts, coffee, brown sugar, molasses, plums and hazelnuts. Taste is of strong dark coffee with some butterscotch. Alcohol is well hidden in the taste. Mouthfeel was smooth with light carbonation.

Probably the most impressive head I have ever seen. Even with a careful pour the head seemed to rise forever. Minuscule bubbles of carbonation kept rising forever. The body was black and the head was brown. Smells like bitter cocoa and coffee. Taste was cocoa and coffee with a bit of hopps in there as well. Mouthfeel was impressive also. Didnt feel as thick as I was expecting and the carbonation was perfect.

(Bottle at Brug Beertje on 2008-05-19) Black. Huge brown head. Yeas and roasted malts in taste. Full and bit fruity palate. Taste: roasted malts, yeast, hops and some sweetness. The 1st Belgian stout Ive tasted that tastes like a stout.

Pours black with a very large tan head. The head was so big it took me about 6 minutes just to get the 11.2oz bottle into my 14oz snifter. Spicy Belgian yeast dominates the nose, some espresso, bitter chocolate, and anise were noticeable as well. The flavor is of very strong espresso, burnt wood, and an unidentifiable earthy flavor. A big bitter finish and very lively mouthfeel round out the experience. This beer is definitely one of a kind and should be sought out by stout and Belgian lovers alike.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 Flaske 0,33l på t Brugs Beertje 3 Mai 11. Svart. Medium høyt mokkafarget skum. God aroma av lakris & svisker. Smaken utvider aromaen med innslag av litt sjokolade & kaffe. God fylde.

Bottle 0,33l at Reading Beer Festival 2 May 08. Black colored. A creamy tanned head. Aroma of ripe grapes. Good looking. Sparkling. Dry flavor dominated by coffee. Sourish bitter finish. 6 - 4 - 6 - 4 - 11

330ml bottle shared with Finn at the Reading Beer Festival. Huge creamy, beige head resting on top of a dark-brown body. Smoky, sweet chocolate to the nose. Cocoa flavour added with liquorice, prunes and roasted malts. Some bitterness with yeasty tartness and alcohol in a long lasting endnote (02.05.2008).

This is a truly wonderful take on this style.  Has a rich roasted coffee aroma, with some molasses and licorice and just a hint of dry earthy chicory.  Roasted almonds and creamy, bready maltiness.  This is a really delicious taste experience.

geproeft in t Rusteel te Gullegem. Het zwarte bier heeft veel overvloedig rotjesschuim maar weinig aroma. Er is een ietwat platte koolzuurprikkeling. Een bittere basissmaak met een droog maar zwaar mondgevoel door de hopbitterheid.De bittere nasmaak blijft heel lang hangen

A very black colored beer, with a huge beige head. An aroma of coffee and chocolate. The taste of dark roasted malts and a lot of smoked notes. Very dry and bitter in the back, with a long after taste. Good beer but not my favorite.
VERY dark, VERY think with a huge bready head. lots of alcohol and chocolate. From bottle Ledgers Liquors in Berkeley.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 Bottle. Pours a deep ebony with hints of auburn around the thinning edges when up against a light. The enormous head is a medium tan. I have never seen a head like this before. Even poured gently, it creates a ridiculous amount. There are some strong dark fruit notes in the nose with some weird  abrasive tinges that reminds me of tequila, and I absolutely hate tequila. Other aromas like some cocoa and toffee are noticeable. But man, that tinge is strong. As soon as the brew hits the tongue, head just explodes again. Its very carbonated and slightly oily. Sourness is instantly apparent as some espresso notes appear. Sourness seems to not to be as attributed to many fruits. Its more like a candy sourness, like a warhead. There are notes of darker fruits in here as well. The intense carbonated action on the tongue is a bit distracting, though. As the brew passes the tongue, a sweet toffee complements the explosion of cocoa and roasted coffee notes. The finish is mildly dry. The finish is strong and actually quite good. This is interesting, but there are so many things in this brew thats just bugging me.
pitch black with tan head.  flavor is strong with candy sugar and roasted malt with very dry finish.  great style and great beer

Pours a deep black with a small head with good retention. Nice aniseed aroma, candy, complex and roasty. Tastes of coffee and dark cocoa, slightly roasty with a porter-like sweetness. Thick and creamy body but slightly overcarbonated. Not completely blended or balanced, but a compelling beer all the same. Many thanks to Boutip for the trade!

Bottle, courtesy of me.  Pours pure black with tan head.  Strong roasty malt aroma, toffee, caramel, chocolate.  Alcoholic nose.  Flavor is heavy on the malt, more roasted and burnt flavors than other stouts Ive tried.  Almost a sharpness to the taste, but balance by malty sweetness.

courtesy of Bhops.  black pour with a 1 finger thick cream head.  thick roasted malts and alcohol on the nose along with some chocolate.  very easy on the palate and the roasted malts are not quite as noticeable as i was expecting. very good brew though.
Pours black with a gigantic tan head. Nice malt and chocolate aroma. Complex flavor of coffee, dark fruits, and alcohol. A strange beer but definitely worth drinking.

11.2 oz bottle, been around a while.  Pours with a typical (although not as wild as others) large head, a creamy beige, over a near-pitch black body with faintest ruby highlights.  Nose is rich and slightly musty, strong notes of chocolate, tobacco, rum raisins, and a noticeable yeasty sourness.  Brandy sharpness on the palate, with a nice roasted undertone, along with more currant sweetness and a mild grassy hop character in the finish.  A highly unusual yet enjoyable stout.

11.2 oz bottle, 2007. Pours dark opaque brown color with an active large micro bubble khaki head. Nose is of dark chocolate, red fruits and dark malt. Initial mouthfeel is light bodied,with lots of microbubbles. The first sip soars over the mouth with deep initial presence. Mollasses, dark chocolate are the first to be noted before splashing into the deep roasted malts. Mid palate display the red fruits from the aroma. Finishing with chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Minor bitter hop presence. Carbonation as you went on started to become a little harsh. Mild stickiness after the finish. Palate duration is above average. Alcohol is masked decently well. Good head retention. Enjoyable.

Pours dark chocolate brown with a thick dark tan head.  aroma of dark chocolates, malt, caramel, and coffee.  Initial taste of chocolate and coffee sliding into a medium bitter coffee finish.  Has vineouss notes as well.  High carbonation. Finish lacks bitterness, but the complexity of flavor more than makes up for it.
Thick black body under a big stable head. Roasted aroma of chocolate and coffee. Candy and coffe taste with a nice carbonation. Sweet and roasted finish

Insanely high carbonation; my pint glass has about an inch of beer and 7 inches of head. After that settles, I pour with painstaking slowness to get it down to about 2 fingers of head. Great retention but surprisingly no lacing.

Aroma is of cocoa powder, peanut skins, and prune juice.

Flavor is of brown sugar with a big prune influence. Quite similar to the aroma actually.

Mouthfeel is waaay too heavy on the carbonation, makes it hard to drink.

deep and dark brown that is nearly the absense of color.  what hit me first about this beer is the strength of the hopping,  different for a stout.  nose is simple drip coffe, candy, and hops. drinks smooth and with a hop kick to a finish.  great approach to the style.

Bottle. Poured dark. This beer has some serious carbonation, Nice burnt notes to go with the chocolate and coffee. It has a nice belgian style sweet finish to it. I found this to be an interesting combination of two styles. Nice beer.

Pours a very dark black with a massive tan head! Strange aroma of sweet roasted malts, black licorice, chocolate, and a rubbery sour smell. Wow, even for a stout the Belgian yeast jumps right out with a strong citric, acidic, sour finish. Strange pairing with this chocolatey coffee initial taste from the stout... Nice full body with a little dryness on the finish from the alcohol. Sips a stout, swallows a Belgian.
I thought this was gross......for the most part...it had a weird wintergreen flavor that I found super distracting......maybe I had a bad bottle.....looked great though

11.2 once bottle. pours black with slowly shrinking tan head. Aroma is roasty with notes of chocolate. Flavor is sweet malt, chocolate and carmel. Finishes sweet. Good balance for abv but will not go out of way to buy again.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 Re-rate 6/26/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Thanks zvikar. Black with a big light brown head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, roastiness and dark fruits. Roasty dry-ish flavor with dark fruits, coffee and burnt notes. Medium-bodied with strong carbonation. 6/4/7/3/14=3.4

(3/7/08) Bottle at t Brugs Beertje in Bruges. Black with a huge stable light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, a bit of coffee and some yeast. Roasty and very bitter flavor with burnt notes, some hops and spice. Medium to full body. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Diskmuide, Belgium
Bottled
Lots of coffee notes with chocolate and crystal malt
Bitterness turn licorice
The esters from the yeast makes a nice cocktail
Black with a dense head. Sweet aroma with some strange notes of preserved cucumbers. Acidity flavours with roasted malts, coffeee and prunes.

Pours with an explosive foamy head that gets out of control quickly!  Color is black.  Aroma of roasted malts.  It is hard to smell with foam up your nose.  Flavor is hard to define.  Sweetness, roasted malt, bitterness, nuts...all rolling around on your tongue.

3/22/2008:  De Dolle Special Extra Export Stout pours an extremely murky brown/dark brown color and has a large fluffy tan head the collapses slowly.  The aroma is quite pungent and contains some kind of fruit/berry (blackberry mixed with dark cherry?) covered in chocolate and caramelized sugar, cream, and some yeastiness.  Actually, maybe it isnt so much berry as it is a very deep, dark red wine (Merlot?) characteristic which a smidge of butterscotch/tanin-like quality.  The flavor begins slightly sweet with semi-sweet and dark chocolate and deeply caramelzing malt and then transitions to a fruity, port-like flavor with some hazelnut-wine and earthiness coming though and then finishes dry with notes of chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee.  The flavor has many complex layers and the alcohol content provides a nice warming quality.  This beer has a medium body, an average level of carbonation, and a good lingering flavor of hazelnut wine fortefied with neutral grape spirits (kind of reminds me vaguely of "Oro" made by Samson Estate Vinyard in Washington state) with bit of beer-like bitterness.  Overall I am failry impressed with the complexity and depth aroma and flavor of this beer.  It is a great beer to sit down, sip slowly, and enjoy!
33 cl./11.2 fl. oz. bottle (9% Alc./Vol.) from Rivers Bend Wine and Spirits in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating #643 for this beer...

Bottle. Looks deep mahagony black with a creamy, frothy three finger head that dissipates to a small head that lingers. This one has a pretty complex aroma i think. Seems there are some dark fruits and chocolate with roasted malts and licorice. The aromas are pretty muted though mostly dark fruits and some alcohol. Prickly and bitter....hmm. Strange. This doesnt seem very balanced at all. Each sip is slightly different from the last. Sometimes I get some nice chocolate flavors and then the next sip is really hoppy/bitter with the next sip being somewhat tart and yeasty. Slightly warming.

Bottle. Pours with a big, foamy beige head, too big actually, and a black body. Chocolate, roasted malt, sugar, berries and a touch of yeast in the aroma. Rather dry, effervescent, slightly warming in the mouth, with flavors of chocolate, dark sugar and some burnt malt. Even though theres this warming sensation, the flavors of alcohol is well hidden. A nice Belgian stout. (080118)
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a light brown head. Aroma is alcohol, sugar, roasted, candisugar. Flavour is smoked, oked, roasted, sugar, roasted coffee. Very nice beer.

Abundance of carbonation is apparent upon opening because it slightly gushed over the lip of the bottle.  The beer poured a black with a large tan head that was unstable and thus dissipated.  Aroma is bitter chocolate and licorice, upon the first sniff it seemed to be estery and spicy, with rich roasted notes as well.  But the aroma was never quite the same.  Kind of vinous with alcohol and licorice.  The flavor is okay, but I expected better.  Its lacking the maltiness and richness.  Flavor is just kind licorice and bitter chocolate, but because of the carbonation, it can never quite sit on the tongue right to allow the flavors to sit right on your tongue.  This being said the mouth feel is over carbonated for a stout, and is thus thin, again making the beer lack a rich feeling.  My least favorite De Dolle beer, but its still not awful.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2011 Bottle (ZBF2008) (6:5:7:3:13=3.4)
Black, small beige head. Toffee aroma. Rich burnt taste - very aromatic hops and winey too. Massive burnt aftertaste.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
Aroma is muchos muchos liquorice. Phil gets soy sauce too. Its aq very rich aroma with a roast motif, certainly. Black, nice head. Remarkably light in the mouth. Quite carbonated, not a surprise considering the  source. Nice finish, leaves you wondering how they managed to make a 9% beer so not heavy. Alas, Anna didnt write any numbers down, she was scribing this one. So well have to wait for the bottle we have at home to get a numerical 2nd opinion.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2008 Bottle. Massive head, extremely carbonated. Nose of roasted malt mixed with fruit. Classic stout favors of coffee and roasted malts overshadowed by fruity sourness, hints of apricot turned to dark cherry as the beer warmed. Interesting and tasty beer.

RERATE: had this beer again a couple of months later, focus was much more on the dark, roasted coffee flavors, more bitterness, without the fruity aspects. Preferred the first.

11.2 oz bottle from South Bay Drugs & Liquor. With only a soft and gentle pour this stout created a glass full of thick tanned foam and took several minutes before it turned into a liquid pitch black. For the aroma, it was pure scent of roasted malts and a touch of sweet foreign chocolate. The initial flavor is a tart and slightly sourness which then follows with roasty dark malt that suggest cocoa beans. One healthy tasting stout.

33cl bottle, from slob - thanks man!  Pours black-ebony color and absolutely opaque, with a huge tan head that leaves thick lace.  Roasty, roasty aroma, bitter chocolate and souring milk, dusty herbs, figs and florals.  Flavor is unsweetened cocoa and espresso, prune juice, dandelion milk, bitter herbals, alcohol and anise.  Full body and little carbonation.

2006 bottling. Black with a frothy 3 finger head. Good smell of roasted malts and licorice. Medium body. Good taste is blackened malts with roasted nuts with earthy cellar mustiness. Not too bad. 5317
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Bottle courtesy of gunhaver.

Pours a deep jet black with a head that doesnt know when to stop. 4 finger head from a side of glass pour and its growing, wow this beer has a beautiful pour, the suds are dancing before my very eyes and the head is growing not shrinking.

Aroma is dominant with coffee and chocolate and roasted barley. 

As I chew the head off of the foam of this beer I am reminded of the foam  from a frappuccino from starbucks. After gnawing through the 3 inches of foam I finally get to taste the liquid. Taste is of chocolate, roasted b arley, coffee and roasted nuts  with a nice bittersweet dark chocolate style finish. But wait, what is this I taste a little sourness as well. What a excellent surprise. Very good beer from de dolle, YUM!

Pours a near black with several inches of a khaki bubbly head. Aroma of malt and burnt sugar. Rather high carbonation which tingles on the tongue and throat. Some hints of chocolate, a good amount of yeast, burnt sugar, a slight amount nuttiness. A little alcohol burn in the finish. Very Good!

Pours a very dark purplish black with huge foamy beige head.  Aroma of spice, chocolate malt, dark fruit, berries and figs.  Very carbonated up front with lots of chocolate maltiness, followed by a smooth balance of spice and dark fruit.  Lots of berry and fig.    Dry sweet finish.  Very complex and quit tasty!

No formal notes taken.  Almost black in color this poured a thick head that consistently faded.  Aromas were rather sweet and showed off yeast and nuts along with a backbone of chocolate.  Lots of carbonation kept this feeling light on the palate.

ZBF 2008: Extremely dark brown with big tan head. Aromas of dark malts with sweet bread dough. Chocolate roast with an herbal twang. Tree bark and green twigs. Bitter on the tongue with roast and green bitterness (possibly herbal). Sweet pasty dough sprinkled with ground coffee. Seemed better in the past. Was there a recipe change?

2008 Zythos Bier Festival, Belgium.

Thick, lucious head with texture and colour of clotted cream. Massive amounts of toasted/burnt malts come through making this really bitter. Smooth and unctuous throughout.

pours brown with a tan head which takes time to lace away.  leaves some residue on the bottom.  alcohol and fruit in the nose.  an assault of smokey stuff, chocolate, coffee that start the eyes a-watering.  thick and full-bodied.  not enjoyable or refreshing, but an interesting experience.

Pours black with tan head.  Nutty aroma with heavy yeast notes, chocolate, lactose, and some coffee.  Lots of candied sugar in the flavor makes this an extremely sweet stout.  Licorice, dark chocolate, dark fruits, vinous notes,  and coffee also apparent.  Flavor is also sour, which makes this stout extremely unique, though not altogether a great stout.  On second thought, the sweet/sour and chocolate combination is actually pretty well pulled off.  Extremely interesting, albeit confusing.

Zhytos beerfest. On tap.
Extremely dark and dense appearance.
Darkish head is everlasting.
Had a hard time drinking it because of its aromas. Mainly coffee, chocolate and yeast.
"stoute stout"

Pours a dark brown with a very large dark tan head. Interesting, sweet dark chocolate with the Belgian yeast. A lot of carbonation hits the tounge. Surprisingly easy to drink. Interesting, but not what I really look for in a stout.

A typical De Dolle beer...!
Great mslty sourness with a yeatsy background. The nose is is sour dough with mislty sweetnes. Flavor is also dolle with  crispy complex malt, plum and port.

Bottle.  Dark black pour, thick dark tan head.  Sweet lactose aroma with some mild earthy funkiness in the background.  Smooth, moderate carbonation.  Taste has a nice blend of choco-lactose and a funk that has just the suggestion of tartness.  Neither the funk nor the lactose notes get too intense.  A good balance of the De Dolle trademarks and stout character.  Subtle and tasty.
Bottle.  Brown-black coloring.  rich 1" tannish head with quick carbonated dissipation.  Grapes, sugary, molasses, toffee elements.  Similar in taste though tart and with coffee-ground finish.  OK.

A hodgepodge of unidentifiable musky aromas that never comes together. Ginormous billowing head that looks awesome, but really makes it hard to drink. Dry, ashy MF. Roasty, bready flavors mostly, hazelnut, oily espresso beans definitely, dried licorice. Overall, good, but I could have done with the CO2 toned down.

Bottle thanks to jrob_21. Pours a dark brown with a powerful thick beige head. The aroma is yeast, chocolate, dark fruits and roasted malts. This beer sort of tastes like a mix of a Belgian Strong Ale and Stout. Fairly sweet with chocolate, spices, and roasted coffee. A tiny bit of bitterness at the end. A good beer, underrated perhaps.

Tasted from a Delirium Tremens snifter.  This beer is black with a thick khaki head.  The nose explodes with cherry and licorice as aromas of chocolate, espresso, and toast struggling to fight through.  Flavor is a little heavy on the coffee character, with a nice touch of roasted malts and dark fruit.  Maybe a little too much sugar, but a very nice stout.

Bottle. Pours with a very fluffy head. Let the beer warm up to room temp if it is cold. Aroma is very sweet it has a roasted coffee with caramel. Flavor is also very sweet but once the beer warms up is starts to have a smoother chocolate taste and an the coffee thins out and you get a hint of smokey oak. The finish is a little harsh but the beer is very good.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2008 Bottle. Aroma pretty sweet, black/candied cherry prevaling, like a gourmet candy, nutty notes. Flavor very much like a dark rum cake, cherry and berry flavors, coffee at the finish just like the description says, some chocolate sneaking in. Absolutely luscious combination. I felt this was the most unique brew Ive ever had, by far, and in my book, that just bumps up the ratings. Not a stout, not a belgian strong, not like anything Ive ever tasted. This was a meal and a dessert all in one, and I want more. Now.8-4-10-4-18/4.4 Rerate 8/11/08. Bottle. Wow, either my tastes have changed or I got a starkly different bottle this time around, maybe much younger or something. I actually think both. Aroma was rather weak, sweet semi-roasted notes and somewhat out of place light fruit notes. Flavor was stronger, with more gently roasted character and a good deal of nuttiness. Rather bitter though, I think from a lot of charred malt that really started to build up with me over time. We’ll see what happens when my path next crosses with this beer...

July 2006 - WARNING:  DO NOT DRINK THIS BEER COLD.  Okay, it had to be said. Pour was huge fluffy head that took forever just for me to get all of it into my Duvel glass.  At the pour the aroma was nondescript, the flavor was metal ash and thin.  Truly horrible.  I contemplated pouring it out, but it was so freaking expensive, I just couldnt.  Well, as it sat and I got up the nerve to attempt to finish it, a wonderful thing happened.  It got better.  The burnt metal taste gave was to an odd smokey oak flavor, roasted malt and a touch of chocolate...non of which I could discern at all in the beginning...along with a sour finish that Im not sure I liked.  The mouthfeel went from an acrid mess, to a smooth silky palate pleasing sensation.  Not sure Id go there again, but I enjoyed the last two thirds of this.
Black colored pour with large tan head.  Sweet aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and a little coffee.  Malty, caramel, chocolate coffee flavor.

bottle at ODonnells in Ft Wayne - Pours black with a huge tan head.  It smells of dark roast malt and Belgian yeast.  The flavor is of course more dark roast malt, some mild chocolate and coffee notes, and some yeast.  Its very bubbly for a stout.  This one might be the first Belgian stout Ive had and its certainly different than the stouts Ive previously had.  The body is medium to full and it ends fairly dry.  Very good, but I wouldnt call it super...

bottle.  pours opaque black with a bit of mahogany at the edges, with a monstrous ever-present tan head that leaves a nice sheet of lacing.  big spicy fruity smell.  there are lots of dark roasty malts there, but they seem to take a back seat to the esters and spice.  notes of raisin, coriander, coffee, chocolate, molasses, grapes, and black cherries.  tastes almost like a black forest cake:  huge dark malt flavors up front, with chocolate coffee notes dominating, backed up a by an assertive black cherry taste, as well as a bit more spice.  big sweet palate, but not cloyingly so, with what seems like a bit of a sour tingle, light bitterness.  creamy silky mouthfeel, and a pretty fully body, and definitely a lot of carbonation.  the smell reminds me of a malt-heavy trappist ale, but the taste is definitely reminiscent of black forest cake.  quite complex, and very tasty.  great for dessert, which is what it is for me right now.

I love this beer!  My favorite Belgian stout, this guy slams up against a wall of alcohol-dryness which really controls - even eliminates - any sweetness.  The blend of coffee and chocolate is incredible and insistent - so much so that it tastes like a hybrid bean.  If you let it air out and have served in a snifter, the last drinks taste unmistakably of bakers chocolate.  A very fine specemin.

Pours a deep brown with ruby edges and a massive, rocky, immediately forming, dense tan head that just wont die, leaving globs of foam on the sides and bottom of the glass. The nose is fruity and roasty with raisins, candied dark fruits, chocolate, cherry and star anise. The flavour is just as advertised. The espresso and hazlenut flavours really pop in the finish with a roasty bitter lingering. The fruity flavours explode initially on the front of the tongue, with fig, raisin rich caramel and tart, vibrant cherry. The finish is completely different from the mid-palate profile, making this an extremely complex and interesting brew. The mouthfeel is loaded with sharp, lively carbonation and a medium, airy body that finshes dry.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 33 cl. Opaque black, with a huge head that spews from the bottle and lasts forever. Brown sugar, molasses, cocoa, and alcohol aroma. Tingly bitterish-roasty malt entry turns to cocoa, then charred wood and herby-malt finish. Body begins smooth, but flares up with carbonation in the mouth; finishes chalky-roast and dry.
Pours to an off white head that had aromas of chocolate and spice. Initial flavours of maltiness followed by spiciness and finished with a slightly sweet taste. Very good beer.

Bottled. An opaque near black beer with a medium sized brown head. Interesting aroma with roasted malt, fruits (plums), spices and chocolate. Rather malty. The flavor has much chocolate, some fruity and coffee notes. There is also some acidity and a good hopping in the finish. Medium to full body, very high carbonation, dry and quite long roasty aftertaste. Some alcohol is felt. A satisfacting beer, but probably my least favourite from De Dolle.
Rich, chocolate, plums, licorice, biier coffee - could improve after a few years? (2007-version) (Tasted at the BASMOF Nytårskur 07/08 12-01-2008)

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 Bottle, room temperature. Inky pour with cappuccino suds pimpled with clumps. Aroma an absolute dribble-maker, with massively heady blackcurrant and strawberryish fruit, De dolles signature earthiness, charcoal, yeast extract, and not much else. Certainly not getting any chocolate. Flavour also (hedgerow) fruity and slightly sourish, with more burnt character emerging as the memory of a Brewdog Riptide subsides. Lots of smoky malt, earthy fruit and alcohol sting, but for me somewhat lacking thickness, complexity and true stoutiness. (re-sampled, 05/06/08) Red apple, smoke and cocoa aroma. Impressively singed deep chocolate bitterness mingling with sourish fruit. Bit too fizzy, but worthy of more than a 3.6...

Pours opaque black into the glass, with a huge tan head that retains nicely to thick lace.  The nose is very vinous in nature, but some chocolate notes hint through the bouquet.  There is a nice, tart fresh cherry upfront, backed with hinted roasts and chocolate notes.  These notes appear later in the pull, and the Belgian Candi Sugar helps "ground" the brew from being completely citric in nature.  Sours round out the finish, with an effervescent espresso "hint".  There is a nicely integrated note of alcohol, although subtle, mingling toward the back-palate.  With the fruity nature of this, the mouthfeel is vivacious, yet controlled.  It feels full and satiating, and would make for a nice nightcap.  Im not getting quite the lauded coffee/choco/espresso contingencies that others laud in the finish.  I pick up much more vinous and cherry/raspberry sours here, "mingling" with dark chocolates and possible (but slight) coffee hints.  To give credit, these do come to fruition more as the brew warms, but so do the dark fruit and sour notes.  A different take on the same offering, maybe, and I do like it a lot, but just not quite the same interpretation on my palate as the commercial description.  De Dolle Brouwers continues to shine in its selections!

VERY malty.  Starts with the Belgian fizz, & finishes with a very clean stout-y taste.  Pours very dark, nearly black, with the typical Belgian head, but tan in color.  My first Belgian stout, & a very pleasant experience, but I dont think itd be on my "must have again" list anytime soon.

Bottle. Pours black brown  (not totally opaque) with an extra dense head that persists. Aroma is raspberry, chocolate, anise. Flavor is pine, molasses, coffee, chocolate, dried fruit. This is on the drier side with well blended alcohol.

Black in color, big fluffy head. Nose of first grade coffee (yemen?), maple and nuts, chocolate. Flavor is its feature I like the most for its roastiness, but mostly its tangy acidity (lactic), not too far from being funky, delicate yet powerfull bitterness and a good lenght. Definitely not on the sweet side. Easy to drink, no sign of alcohol. Creamy texture, finishes dry. My reference in terms of foreing stout. I have never had any beer that compares.
Black with medium brown head. Sweet roasted aroma with liquerice and chocolate. Flavor is sweet with roasted/burned malt, chocolate and liquerice. Ends bitter.

Enormous head! Bubbled up over the top of the glass eve. Smell is of cake batter and brownie mix. Loads of chocolate with coffee and espresso notes on the tongue. Quite vinous finish, which means this bottle could have some age on it. The candi sugar is a beautiful touch, and adds greatly to the already creamy nature of this stout. Id call it an Imperial Milk, Minus the Lactose, Stout. The mouthfeel is very carbonated and full. Gotta love these new school Belgian stouts. Did you know back in the day in Belgium they used to drink, for breakfast, stout with a raw egg in the glass? I know what Im waking up with from here on out. Great brew!

Bottle.  Pours Dark Black.  The largest tan head I have ever seen.  a quarter glass boiled over the top of the glass!  It was even worse than Duvel.  Ok, aroma, sour and alcohol.  Flavor is mild sour with some roasted malts coming through.  Good flavor, but the sour is a bit overpowering. Mouthfeel is bubbles on bubbles and champagne thin.  I think I got a bad bottle.  Same as yobdoog and crizay.  I can tell it would be a good brew if the sour and (not so) tiny bubbles were taken care of.  I wasted 5 dollars on this one.... ARGH!
Almost every bottle I get has way too much carbonations, mount vesuvios style. Sweet taste, a lingering bite at the end and some odd aroma.

Black pour, huge tan gusher of a head. Aroma is sour and roasty. Flavor is the same roasty but with a twangy sourness that probably shouldnt be there. Chocolate and coffee with a chalky dryness but again some sweet sourness resides that shows its probably infected. It really doesnt taste horrible but the way it gushed and sourness shows its not right.

Bottle, 33cl. Taste with Leen.
Black color, with medium beige tan head. 
Aroma dark fruits, dark coffee; roasted malts.Mediu mto full body.
Taste coffee, carmel, very strong roasted malts, bitter end. 
Not my favorite beer style, but this is a great beer !

Bottle shared by theisti at his Holiday Tasting on 12/28/07. Pours a dark, muddy, cocoa brown with a thin ring of bubbles around the edge of the glass and a few small islands of bubbles at the surface. Some chunky sediment sits at the bottom of the glass. The aroma is a blend of fruit, chocolate, and roasted malt with a vinous and light alcohol quality as well. Medium-bodied, lightly grainy and super-dry with a hit of alcohol at the finish. Woody, vinous and chocolaty, pepper and alcohol round out the flavor profile. A very interesting and tasty stout that is unlike any other that Ive tried, to date. Thanks for sharing this one with us, Tim.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2009 2004 bottle.  330 ml bottle purchased at Bottleworks, Seattle, WA, enjoyed at my Holiday Mini Tasting.  Pour is black to cola brown with a smallish tan head.  Aroma of some sweet malt and faint sour or hoppiness (hard to tell which).  Taste is coffee, chalky, pretty dry and a fair amount of heat coming through.  Description doesn’t sound to appealing, but this was actually an interesting beer.

Bottle 330 ml 
Appearance: Poured thick, viscous dark brown going onto black, surprised by gusher (fine cinnamon brown) Nose : Light aromatic meadow hops on top with chocolate lightly burnt side to it.7+ Flavor/Palate : Tart burned grain with brown malting. Softer , smoother finish. To acidic to my liking, lacking signature stout roasting. Taking this ale in wide spectrum is not half bad but expected more depth from it.

Bottle @ Microbar, november 07. Opaque black color with a big, beige head. Mineral, sea side like aroma with some apple, fruity notes. Interesting. Nice, chocolate, toasty flavor with some balsamic touches. Bitter chocolate palate. Warming. Pretty interesting mouse of chocolate flavor, although a bit too gassy. It gets creamy and engaging with the acid touch and keeps it drinkable. Interesting, bitter chocolate FES.

Big roasted malt & fruity ester nose. Huge carbonation, and huge head.  Nice woody flavors from the malts & nugget hops.  Rich coffee, chocolately alcohol warmth.  No harsh hot alcohol.  I would have been fooled if someone told me this was lightly barrel aged.  Nice and dry for the style, which is surprising because this runs right up into imperial stout category without venturing too far into that realm.  The only real thing I can ding this one on is the over-carbonation, but with Belgian yeast strains, you kinda expect it.   Let is sit in the glass and warm up and vent carbonation and it keeps getting better and better.  Bonus points for having such a great label..
Black color with incredibly big and thick, small bubble tan head.  Chocoalte coffee and salty licorice/olive.  Fair amount of yeast.  Full bodied.

Pours black, thick with a huge off white head that is really long lasting. Dry roasted malt with hints of cherry, raisin, and chocolate in the aroma. Upon the first sip, your mouth is just engulfed in carbonation. I felt as though I had to let it settle in my mouth just to get an idea of the taste. Fruity notes that come with belgian yeast, dry roasted malt, chocolate all come out in the taste. A really nice stout (as long as your not expecting Guiness).

Flaske. Flot sort øl med en meget umiskendelig belgisk karakter. Megen karbonation og en ekstrem brændthed der slår over i bitterhed- Den er så kraftig at det overdøver resten af smagsnuancerne hvilke trækker en anelse ned. Ellers en udemærket øl.

Pours rich and black with an equal sized tan head. Great lacing. Aromas of dark chocolates, dark pitted fruits, a fine port, and a Sambuca Espresso! Another fully carbonated Belgian Stout. Taste is similar, dark chocolates, espresso, some roasted notes. A long dry finish with a bitter end. Thick bodied like an Imperial Stout, with a micro-bubble explosion.
Creme marrom com incrível densidade e consistência. Aroma de malte, chocolate e caramelo, fugindo do lugar-comum das stout. Amargor moderado e seca na medida.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is of light roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, dark fruits, coffee, and a little alcohol.  Flavor is of roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, slight coffee, dark fruit, and some bitterness on the finish.  Enjoyed the flavor much better then the aroma.  Great beer.

Verydark brown, nearly opaque, big fizzy brown head. Aromas of stewed prunes, raisins, licorice. Delicious port-like palate of flavours-- stewed plums, raisins, fruitcake, with some bitter chocolate and coffee to round it out. Finish is bitter and slightly salty. My main criticism is the unusually high level of carbonation. This beer still maintains its magnificence despite the near-fizziness up front, but I think if it had a smoother body it could be elevated into something truly great.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle:  Pours as black as you can get with a massive tan head.  This is the most interesting stout Ive ever had and my first Belgian stout.  The staple belgian yeast aroma and taste are very prominent to go along with mild chocolate and coffee notes.  All in all a damn fine stout that is unlike anything else Ive had and one that Ill be seeking out again.

Bottle. Well, this one is certainly unique! The bottle I had was very carbonated, very alcoholic and very flavorful. Unfortunately, it was astringent enough to overpower what seemed like solid flavors underneath. Perhaps I got a bad bottle, and Ill give it the benefit of the doubt, but this is not what I was hoping for from such a highly-ranked beer.

12/1/07, 2005 vintage. pours very dark brown with foamy biege head that falls a few minutes but remains thin. nose is a little sour, a clear de dolle house quality to it, hints of roast, hazelnut chocolate, and raisins. flavors are pretty sour, citrus, slightly funky at first but this quickly fades into a roasty, bakers chocolate, and musty. really interesting de dolle yeast coming through in a yeasty and dry finish. alcohol is not detected at all. thin to med. body. sort of a fizzy mouth feel. perhaps some age has soured this a bit and dried it out. more along the lines the JP stout or a black saison than your typical english/american stout. interesting stuff.

Pours very dark brown with a thick sea-foamy tan head. Slightly sweet aroma of chocolate, with very notable alcohol, some spicy notes, and a nice coffee undertone. Flavor is very musty, and fairly tart. If it werent for some of the other reviews, I would think that I had a bad bottle. Other than that, there is just a hint of coffee and bitter bakers chocolate underneath. Palate is medium, and viscous, with some chocolate lingering in the background. This one just wasnt for me, the tartness really threw me off, and there didnt seem to be any real structure.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2008 Garrafa, em Bruges (BEL), em novembro de 2007. Coloração preta, com creme marrom gigantesco, denso e persistente. Show!!! Notas de café e malte torrado. Amarga, sem tanta personalidade. Stout diferente. Sabor mais aberto, talvez azedo. Seca. Não gostei da proposta. Muito azeda/ácida. Não é tão encorpada como as demais Stout. Desvirtuou um pouco do caminho. Parece mais uma brown ale.

The 11.2 ounce bottle poured an almost perfectly black opaque beverage with a thick, creamy tan colored head that was fully lasting and it left great lacing on the glass. The aroma had a nice balance with the malt aspect coming out on top. There was dark chocolate, molasses, and hints of dark fruit and coffee abounding. There is also an odd nose of dust or earth almost hidden. The body was medium-full with soft carbonation and a creamy smooth texture. The flavor starts out somewhat sweet on the palate and stays that way throughout the moderately long finish. There is noticeable alcohol warmth toward the end as well. My feeling is that this one might benefit from being cellared for a year or two.

Pours dark murky brown with a huge tan head.  Aroma is pretty strong in alcohol with a port like quality and a touch of chocolate.  Mouth feel is extremely lively with lots and lots of carbonation.
Flavor is tart, with a strong chocolate presence.  No bitterness is to be found. Its strange to have such a sour stout, but this is still pretty good.
A super, robust beer with all of the flavors of candy, rich malts, with strong cocoa flavors. A slight on the tart side but very drinkable.

Pour had hugh amble head with pitch black body.  The nose is musty, with dark dried fruit, yeast and hints of caramel mixed with dark chocolate.  the taste is largely dark roasted malt, hints of burnt chocolate and sugars.  Good flavor but not balanced with enough sweetness.

$4.49/11.2oz, probably from Holiday Wine Cellar on 8/2/07.  2 finger small bubble head fades to a finger creamy mass of tan microfoam goodness on a pitch black liquid.  Its really a sight to see.  Guinness would be proud.  Very mild aroma.  Musty.  Maybe a bit of chocolate and banana.  Some residual sweet, and some tart dryness, but not too much to be unpleasant.  Mild alchohol presence, reducing drinkability slightly.  Not so much hop bitterness, but more of a bitter chocolate bitterness.  Lots of flavor, but I wish it had more sweetness.

From bottle. Had the pleasure of enjoying this beer over the weekend, and might I say it was amazing. The pour was rich chocolate with a light brown head that lasted. The aroma was like walking into fall, dark fruit and espresso. This is definitely a beer that coats the mouth, making sure all the taste buds get a chance to experience something.

The aroma has hazelnuts, sour fruit, chocolate, coffee, yeast, heavily toasted malt, and earth. The appearance is dark brown with a very large head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is pretty good. Overall its not as good as I was expecting.
Big nutty chocolate aroma. Great head retention. Mouthfeel coats and blossoms. Quite dry. Full of complex flavors nutmeg, chocolate, figs, and slight dark fruits. Outstanding.

Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured a black color with a huge frothy brown head that lasted and produced good lacing. Good roasted malt and dark fruit aroma. Full body with a smooth sticky texture. Complex roasted dark fruit stout flavor with a medium bittersweet smooth finish of moderate duration. Very well balanced dark fruity stout.

Pours black with a thick, brown-tinged head. The aroma is complex and consists of two-levels: the first that hits me is the deep chocolate and yeast that hits the nose like a wall. The second is the lighter topside, which features the yeasts and light hops... great! Similar to Dogfish Heads stout, but without the DFHs unique yeast character. The flavor is very different from the dogfish head... lots of dry and bitter hops on the front, melting away into burnt caramel, coffee and burnt honey. Very grainy, but still smooth due to the finish. Not too sweet. Aftertaste has lots of dark fruits that leave you dreaming of exotic Lovecroftian lands with strange and beautiful foliage. Really excellent beer... one of the better stouts Ive ever had.

(on bottle( Quite disapointed here. Very black, light, beige head. Powerfull and winerous aroma, dark sugar, dark berries and a bit of toast. Not a very full body and an odd fruity-sour taste of the malts, like rotten stuff. And on top it was followed up by an almost acidic finish. Better check it again, some day

Dark beer on a brown creamy head. Very lively carbonation. Nice aroma with notes of dark fruits like plums and raisin, wood and vinious notes. Flavor of roasted malts and dark fruits. Light bitter at the end. Alcohol very well hidden. Medium bodied.
dark, big tan head, roasted and can taste the prunes and plums.  Has the de dolle signature flavor - I think they are our favorite brewer.  Delicious and im not a huge stout fan

33 cl bottle.  Pours a very deep opaque brown, almost black, with a massive, foamy tan head.  At a quick glance it almost looks like a rootbeer float.  The head eventually settles down and lasts through mid-glass and leaves partial lacing.  Very pleasant aroma of lightly roasted malt, candy sugar, and chocolate.  The flavors are subtle and come together quite nicely.  They include lightly roasted malt, candy sugar, chocolate, and a bit of dark fruit.  Light bitterness at the finish.  The alcohol was very well hidden.  Medium bodied.   I enjoyed this one.

Over-lively bottle which produced a near black opaque stout with an enormous, foamy tan head. The aroma had some roastiness and licorice. Smooth drinking with coffee and date flavours and some warming alcohol. Good, but not a stand out.

One of my first stouts, not an easy style to find in Belgium.
Aroma is deceptively thin, there are sweet bananas buried beneath it.
Taste is something else. At first quite numbing, some rotten fruit, it then goes to coffee and small blck candy we call drop - toffee. It kind of stays there, I dont know why people mention chocolate, I dont feel it ever goes there.
Then it hits you, theres a whole lot of Oerbier in this, aside from the roasted coffee flavour.
Have a hard time finishing 33cl of this, but luckily she likes it too. Want to have it again to see if I missed anything.

(bottle) Pours black with a very large tan head.  Aroma is strong of cocoa, very dry, with some hint of sourness too.  The taste is quite tart, almost like a tart cherry, with some chocolate and a long finish of espresso.  This beer was slightly thin, and the carbonation was prettyaggressive on the tongue.

[Bottle, thanks Guerde] Pours dark brown with a huge tan head.  Aroma is cocoa, roasted malt, fruit, hazelnut.  Taste is almost a little sour up front, then a lot of hazelnut and what almost seems like subdued cherry.  A little coffee in the finish.  Had to let it sit for awhile as it was way too carbonated at first.  A bit thin.  Another unique Belgian stout.

Bottle from City Beer Store.  Dark brown color, dark khaki head with massive bubbles--the beer looks alive.  Huge pungent aroma with yeast, bananas, nuts.  Tastes starts off Belgian yeast and fruits and finishes with a huge kick of smoke, nuts, very dark chocolate.  One of the more complex  beers Ive ever had (if unsubtly so--the flavors hit you over the head)

jet black big caramel brown head. big dark chocolate and nutty aroma. nice roasted flavor and slightly warming with the alcohol. chocoalte flavor has a hint of bitterness in it as well as the roasted coffee finish. flavors join together really well with this and perfect for the cold nights.

dark color very volcanic, spewing tan head. nice aroma of chocolate, malt, fruit. The rich malted (chocolate, nutty) components do not come through complely in the flavor, nevertheless, this brew is not lacking in complexity sporting a huge range of notes from toasty chocolate to slightly sour fruits. a wonderful wintertime beverage.

Most of these De Dolle beers have entirely too much head!  When it finally settles to a managable level, you have a huge, tan, frothy, fluffy head with good longevity and minimal lacing; body is black and opaque.  Nose is nice but nothing too special; dark chocolate, dry coffee, restrained roast, burnt caramel, and faint molasses.  Flavor is similar with dark chocolate, light coffee, hazlenut, molasses, and a peculiar sour note.  Palate is medium, velvety, round soft to lively, and dry.  Finishes dry and a bit chaulky with the sour notes  vanishing and leaving a decent bitterness from expresso notes; other notes of molasses and a slight anise tinge.  Actually quite nice, somewhat complex, not too dry for the style, and fairly drinkable at 9%.  The sour note just didnt mix well with the everything; I wish it would have either been more pronounced and complex or non-existant.  Either way, it was still a good export.

Poured from a 11.2oz bottle and served in a tulip.  This stout poured a very dark brown color with a dark tan head that showed great retention.  No lace, though.  The aroma of the brew was made up of dark chocolate, strong coffee, molasses, and also some funky yeast esthers.  The flavor consisted of rich dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, lightly bitter hops at the finish, along with a slightly acidic, funky, sourness throughout.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with lively carbonation and some light tounge warming alcohol.  Wow, this was a very interesting stout with a lot of different flavors interacting!  I cant wait to try some more brews from De Dolle!!!
Very "De Dolle" yeast flavored, light espresso and a slight sourness that leaves you wonder if its indeed a Stout, or some funky monk dark belgian ale. Its good.

A brown huge head needed to settle a few times. Pours black/very dark brown beer. Nose of coffee, malt and molasses. Taste of coffee, malt, honey, spice and chocolate. Light in body with some carbonation. A dry and hoppy finish. Some burn in the throat. Leaves and enduring sourness. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours as close to black as you can get. Head is huge with a brownish colour. Taste is slightly smokey / chocolate / caramel. The aroma is malty / chocolate / also alcohol. Finish is dry with a bitterness also. Complex but enjoyable.

HUGE head, had to let it settle several times before I could pour the whole bottle. Very dark with frothy chocolate head. Aroma is of strong chocolate and coffee malts. Flavor starts sweet with lots of chocolate and tones of coffee. Gives way to a strong berry/cherry flavor and turns lightly bitter with a lasting chocolate/cherry finish. Very very good beer, very complex and lots of flavor with an excellent creamy mouthfeel.

33 cL bottle. Pours black with a gigantic lasting brown head. Aroma is roasted malty, clear alcohol presence, somewhat dried fruity. Flavour is smoked, burned malt, coffee, some chocolate smoothness and some liqourice sharpness. Slight burning alcohol finish with a classic de dolle yeast presence, a slight acidity blending in with the bitterhops. Complex yet tasty brew.
Bottle. Nice big long lasting head. Aroma is thick with roast malt. Taste is likewise. Good long finish.

Solid black pour with the faintest tint of mahogany when held to the light.  Massive, spongy, cappuccino colored head with excellent retention.  Slippery, sudsy lacing creeps its way back to the body.  The aroma is unique, showing a funky sour yeast over a dry, roasty chocolate malt base.  Oak, vanilla, and hints of anise add complimentary scents.  The flavor is very dry and roasty, with chocolate malts and coffee kissed by vanilla laden French oak.  The sour yeast is present throughout, and when combined with obviously high carbonation level it makes for a lively mouthfeel.  Medium body with a roasty, slightly sour finish.  Very similar to Jolly Pumpkins Madrugada Obscura.  Interesting brew, but not something I would reach for frequently.
Bottle. Huge light brown head, mostly diminishing. Black body. Heavy malty aroma with notes of chocolate. Heavy bitter flavor. Very sour.
0,33 l bottle. Lovely stout. Coffee, smoke, a little sourness. There is a fien aftertaste of smoke and ashes that lingers on. Complex and lovely.

12 oz. bottle pours extremely dark brown with massive light-brown head sporting all sizes of bubbles.  It eventually fades into a creamy 1/4 inch.   The aroma is highly acoholic and smells much of dark chocolate, raisins, melted sugar and brandy.  Its bouquet is complex and surprisingly enjoyable to take in. 

The taste is mostly black coffee.  I can taste the hazlenut and chocolate too, but faint.  Flavors are slightly disturbed by an off-putting sourish metallic finish and then ruined.  Palate is slightly smooth, slightly thin, quite creamy leaving a fatty feeling in the mouth.  Carbonation is good.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 Pour is deep ruby red with a huge frothy head. Aroma is very nutty, some coffee and a hint of date. Flavor is bitter chocolate early then more sweet in the finish. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. This is an excellent stout!

Courtesy Knightly Spirits. Pours dark chocolate with a huge 2-inch brown head with staying power. Absorbing, foamy lace. Strong dark fruit, caramel, and oak on the nose. Mmmm...toasty malts in the mouth with more fired oak, subtle coffee and Fantome-esque funk, slight acidic finish. High carbonation and full bodied. The rounded mouthfeel is balanced and satisfying. Great beer. I like these sour stouts like Jolly Pumpkins Madrugada Obscura. Nice work.
Dark chocolate nose, roasted coffee and rich  malt, almost black, pours a huge cappuccino head.Bitter taste of coffee, dark chocolate and fine malt. Light bodied, sour/sweet, bitter. Great!

Date: 05/31/2005
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Party Pac, IN

pours black with a huge tan head, sweet malt aroma with nice licorice and a hint of roasted malt, nice big body, rich sweet malt flavor, touch of ripe fruity character, 

Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Score: *4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

33 cl bottle shared with Ben (thanks), served cool in a Maudite fishbowl. AU 25/07
App.:  Deep brown-black, clear(??), fleeting tan head.
  
Aroma:  Chocolate and dark dried fruits smothered in tangy organic acids, slightly woody and vinous; a little coffee; a touch of funk/cheese.
  
Palate:  Full body and slightly sharp effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Dark dried fruits, some wood, a bit bright; acids and inky dark malts linger, a bit of alcohol burn at the front of the mouth.

Not a fan of combining Belgian funk/tang with stout qualities.

Bottle courtesy Jmichael. Pours a dense tan head. Thats all. This is either the best or worst head youll ever get, depending on your point of view. The head sits there mocking me, taunting me with its non-drinkability as I wait for a layer of beer to slowly form beneath it. The beer is opaque black/brown that admits a bit of light around the edges. Nutty chocolate aroma - with something I cant identify - almost metallic. Lightly sour coffee taste with some licorice and an espresso-dry finish. This is an unusual example of the style, or maybe its beginning to go bad?

0.33 l bottle. Black color with tan head. Extremely foamy. Mainly roasted malt in the aroma along with some phenols. Roasted, sweet and sour flavor with charcoal. Acidic finish. The acidity, sweetness and roastedness is not in balance.

Black color with a monstrous and slowly-dissipating tan head.  Aroma a bit weak but smells of coffee and fruits with a hint of dark chocolate.  Very lively mouthfeel as this is extremely highly-carbonated.  Flavor predominantly sour fruits like grape skins and currants with only a slight coffee bitterness in the finish.  Very interesting stout.

poured into tulip.  pours a dark loose pour with hight fizzy head that slowly dissipates and sticks, took a cuple of pour and waits to get the full bottle.  sweet smooth light malt aroma with a citruss hop presence.  sweet front almost a sour tone, some hop presence an a smoky background to sweet mild finish.  carbonation presence on palate, slight hoppy citruss sour tone, lots of complexity and background, more sweet than smoky, yeast presence, and dry finish to aftertaste, smokiness arrives in the aftertaste, as it warms yeast presents itself..  good stuff.
Black. Begie head. Aroma brings a lot of spices. Flavo ris coffee, burnt malt, raisins and some chocolate. Not my best stout...

A surprise from Maria.  Pours a lively deep dark brown.  Head is dense and tan.  Musky is right on for the nose of earth and caramel. I am a huge chocolate fan.....(slob is saying "no shit!" right now) so this one hits all my buttons.  rich deep roasted coffee  runs paralell to the choco groove.  The hops kick right on the tip of your tounge.  I missed the hazelnuts entirely on this and thats probably for the best since that is one smell that makes me wretch a bit. Nice

Pours black iodine w/ a huge frothy expansion. Read retention is forever finally receding to a full rocky canopy and thick, sticky lace. Aromas of Belgian granite and mildly sweet roasted malts. Medium full nectar w/ expansive, pillowy soft effers. Extreme roasted coffee flavors w/ a defined pungent souring hits me smack in the face. Oddly enough the sour component isnt offenive at all, just very surprising. I can feel it on the back sides of my tongue. The roast componenet is so pronounced I cant taste much of anything else at this point. Nuances of bitter cocoa, dried dark fruits, bubblegum dust essence, cassis, black currant. The hops really stand out. As the brew warms the flavors really start to come forward. The sour turns to tart black cherries and unerripened stone fruit. Fairly dry if only fainty fruity. The finish is long w/ a heavy bittering. Well balanced. Overall: this brew is very strongly flavored featuring over cooked coffee, dried dark fruits, and underripened stone fruits. Drinks much better as she warms. A nice treat. Highly recommended.
Bottle. Poured a very nice darkly color with a very nice tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is is kinda harsh and sweet in the end.
Near black with long lasting beige head.  Signature aroma and taste of a Belgian including dark fruits, roasted malt.  Very nice stout.

Dark brown in color with light brown head and some lacing. Aroma was strong and rich malts and chocolate. Flavor was excellent, sweet malts, fruity, and just some light coffee/chocolate notes with a very slight hoppiness. Well balanced and delicious.
33cL bottle.  Very dark and very strong roasted flavor with a short, dry finish.  Not my favorite variety of beer.
Nothing special that would allow this to stand out from the others.  Dry & roasted yes, but lacking in a way that I cannot describe.  My least favorite of the De Dolle range.

11.2 black in color and quite dense looking. fluffy espresso head is quite lovely. aroma is wonderfully rich with molasses, coffee, plums, and touches of oak and vanilla. also a little sweet with some hops lingering in the back. wow. a mild sweetness is the short introduction to tons of deep roasted coffee and bitter chocolate flavors. a little licorice is present as well. a distinct yeast taste is involved playing along the sweet malts and the spicy hops that guide you to a long and dry finish. top notch.

Pour is black with a thunder cloud of brown foam.  A forward burn of espresso bitterness on the nose.  Chocolate covered cherries, ashes, and a fleeting hint of urinal.  Tastes of dry Belgian cocoa.  Sweet blackberries and cranberries swim in a kind of fermented maple and sarsaparilla syrup.  Unique.  A tart presence of prunes and dry black licorice, leading to a lightly roasted, smoky Latin American roast on the finish.  Though the descriptors are similar, the impression is unique.  It has a kind of firey tang that flares up between each movement of flavor.  Palate is very warm and very thick.  A campfire on a foreign planet, where the surroundings are lush and stunning, enough that they take a little time to appreciate for their strangeness.
decisamente scura buona schiuma note decisdamente tostate liquirizia secca decisamente complessa

Deep pitch black coloured body (100% opaque) with a soapy and frothy light brown head. Aroma of super strong malt, roasted figs and raisins, soap, yeast, chocolate, coffee and a bunch of alcohol. Full-bodied; Strong roasted malt flavour with a bunch of sugar and molasses kicking in the back. Aftertaste shows bittering malt, yeast that wont quit and even more sugars that persist throughout the whole taste. Overall, a damn good stout that shows its complexities even in the aroma, and much more throughout the life of the beer. I was very impressed with this one, and Ive been holding onto this bottle for a good 3 years already! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia on 28-July-2007 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

Pours a five+ finger light brown head that fades quickly to a thin layer leaving some lace.  Black as midnight.  Light-medium carbonation and heavy bodied. Burnt caramel nose.  Flavor has some sweetness but burnt caramel dominates. Nice stout. $3.49 for a 330ml bottle from Johns Grocery Iowa City, Ia.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, savoured on July 19 2007; eye: opaque black with a strong coffee-color head, voluminous head that falls to leave a carpet on top of the beer to protect it, no effervescence, slight lacing; nose: roasted malt, burnt coffee, lactic; mouth: in that order, astringency, roasted malt, burnt coffee, acridness, lactic, chocolate milk, a bit of hops, nicely balanced, finale in roasted malt with a good presence of acrid burnt coffee, lightly bitter, medium body, slightly oily texture; overall: quite enjoyable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, savourée le 19 juillet 2007; il : noire opaque avec une mousse café fort, mousse volumineuse qui tombe pour laisser un petit tapis protégeant la bière, pas deffervescence, très légère dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, café brûlé, lactique; bouche : astringence, malt torréfié, café brûlé, âcreté, lactique, chocolat au lait, un peu de houblon, belle balance, finale en malt torréfié avec une bonne présence de café brûlé âcre, légèrement amère, corps moyen, texture légèrement huileuse; en résumé : bien aimé
Dark brown body with black head.  Dark roasted malt nose with faint coffee character.  Similar body, but a little lighter in flavor.

11.2oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a large frothy brown head. Bready aroma with spice, chocolate and licorice. Flavor is heavy on the roasted chocolate malt, with coffee, licorice, and hops. Finishes dry, with some warming alcohol.
Bottle ah home (pda crashed lost notes from 2 days ago) Deep black .Some roast malt a nd a little salt !. HAs a bitterness very simelar to De Dolle Oeral

I was intrigued to see this; a Belgian stout?!  The beer poured almost black with a huge aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate, with a bit of that Belgian candy sugar as well.  The taste is chocolate, with coffee and nut characteristics thrown in.  An incredibly well-crafted brew whose smoothness belies both the power and the alcohol content of the beer.  De Dolle is one of my favorite breweries, and this does not the least bit disappoint.

Very dark in the glass with white chocolate aromas.  Very dry throughout, aromas, flavor, palate.  Nutty and roasted notes dominate.  Some chocolate and coffee.  More coffe, though.  Really light and sensual for a stout.  A marvel of flavor.  Well balanced.  The dark candy sugar really shows though.

My notes got a bit sparser as this was the last beer of my evening, but I clearly  remember the opaqueness of this beer.  Aroma was of licorice and was a bit musty.  Flavor was extremely grape-y and the beer had a very dry mouthfeel, much like a very astringent cabernet.  not bad.

Pours black with a monstrous, well retained light brown head.  Very thick and foamy.  Very roasty aroma with hints of sourness and some funk in typical De Dolle fashion.  Pretty much what I was expecting here.  The taste is very similar to the smell.  You get the light sweetness and sourness right up front, but it slowly turns to roast and some chcolate in the finish and coats the palate with some roasty malt flavor in the aftertaste.  The alcohol is masked quite brillinatly actually.  Really interesting beer, not something I want to drink all the time, but a truly enjoyable beer once in a while.

Bottle. Deep brown with a huge head. Fair lacing and good retention. Aroma is yeasty and dusty with tons of dark fruit and a bit of liquorice. The taste is where you get the coffee and chocolate, plus dark fruit. Very complex flavors that work surprisingly well together.

Nice black body with a wonderful tan head. Roasted coffee aroma, rather weak, somewhat disappointed. The flavor has a nice woody roasted coffee flavor to it. The beer is very carbonated, and not thick at all. The chocolate flavor is also coming out nicely. I am surprised about the palate. The palate is actually helping flavors of the beer tingle on my tongue which allows me to fully realize what flavors are actually in the beer. The beer is pretty good and I would definitely drink it again.
Pours an opaque brown with a small brown head. Sweet aroma. Roasted flavor with hints of dark fruits and coffee. Nice bitter end. Interesting and wonderful stout.
Bottle at home. Really nice dark chocolate colour with tan foam. Strong wheat, chocolate and coffee tastes. Prickly, sour at times and a real delight. A full-bodied mud pie!

An interesting beer to say the least. Quite different from the standard American take on stouts. Aroma was chocolatey, some toffee, subtle roasted coffe and malt notes too. Underneath it all was an odd fruity/apple like character that seemed to lurk around the entire time. Appearance was dark, but it carried some dark brown notes around the edges. Huge eruptive dark tan head too. Took awhile for it to reduce to drinkable status. Mouthfeel was on the thin side of things. Nothing bad, just..pedestrian. Flavor was something different, although Im not sure Id find myself longing for it after Ive consumed the whole bottle. Chalky chocolate on the palate with a sour funkyness that, although different, I didnt really like in my stout. Plus the alcohol hit ya like a freight train. Nothing really complex, and aside from this one occasion I doubt I will retry unless its at a tasting. Too many other great stouts to try.

Bottle at the famous Brugs Beertje bar in Brugge (Belgium), very lively, black with a brown bubbly head. An alcoholic aroma, roasted malt with coffee. A rich and sweet aroma, but lively and carbonated. Hoppy and burnished flavours. Quite sour and dry in the mouth. Complex!

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 Wow! what a nice beer. pours dark, dark brown with creamy thick head. Wonderful lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, and filburt nuts.  finishs with a dark coffee flavor.
A+

Bottle at The Raleigh Times- Raleigh, NC also at peace st. in raleigh
Bottle. Sweet chocolate nose with hints of fruit and spice. Frothy huge brown head on a black beer. Chocolate lead with a mild acidity, roasty sweet finish. Full-bodied and well-hidden alcohol.

opaque black, HUGE, and i mean HUGE light brown head that lasts forever. Aroma is roasted malt, and lots of it! Super robust, and some hints of coffee, and a slight sour funk, with a touch of alcohol. Flavour is slightly sour, but not over powering, its actually nice. Lots and lots of roasted malty goodness. Again, hints of coffee, and some chocolate, and the alcohol is hidden well in the flavour. Overall a very very nice stout.

Pours a dark brown/near black with a khaki colored head that would have been huge if I didnt pour it so carefully.  After much glass swirling and letting the beer sit, the carbonation is finally drinkable levels to support the flavors.  Aroma goes through a few temperature transitions, cause it was very odd at first, but now its sweet and very vinous.  Theres some clove and yeast funk for sure, a little ginger, milk chocolate and vanilla for sweetness all held by this vinous winey note.  Nice!  Sweet dark chocolate, plummy raisiny flavor with plenty of spicy yeast funk.  Finishes with the taste of a nice sweetened lightly roasted coffee, just a pinch of licorice and some buttery hop flavor.  Mouthfeel was way overly carbonated at first, but that was easily released.  Otherwise its medium and very creamy.  I have to say this was kind of strange at first, but sip it slow!  It gets better as it warms, moreso than other beers that do the same.

I found this beer so repugnant I poured it out. The first problem was extreme overcarbonation, such that i couldnt get it properly into a glass, and eventually was forced to suck foam. Worse was the taste. I like sour beers like Flemish reds. And I like dark, bitter stouts. But I didnt like this creepy combination of sourness and aspirin-like bitterness, with an alcohol burn to boot. While it smelled OK, I noticed no complexity--just sourness and burntness. It was too thin.

(of course, it may be, like others with similar low ratings suggest, that this was a bad bottle.)
Heavy lasting fluffy brown head. Black beer. Strong yeasty earthy aroma. Kind of mild start. Big sour finish. More like a roasted dubbel. Thin.

Very dark look with and exploding brown head. Aroma fairly fruity, with notes of chocolate and salty liqurice, and a strong alchohol/vinouse pressence. Flavor is, for me, extremly vinouse, like a strong redwhine with bitter notes of black chocolate and salty liqurice. Dry dry bitter aftertaste with a warming alchohol

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 While the trend in stouts seems to be towards bigger, roastier, bourbon-aged depth charges, its nice to taste a solid and subtle beer like this one. With initial overtones of beef jerky and molasses, this one blends the dark fruits and verrrry subtle roasts quite well. A slight thinness and a hint of astringents takes away from the rating, but this is mighty fine stuff.

Pours pitch black with a large, dark tan head.  Roasted coffee malt, raisin, berries, dark fruits, sweet molasses, alcohol, and cocoa round out the aroma.  Flavor is roasted coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, molasses, and alcohol.  Finishes with bittesweet chocolate and alcohol.  Medium body with nice carbonation.  Great stuff.

Had this after a mikkeller beergeek breakfast, by comparison, this was just a harsh alcohol bomb. Overall its a nice dark beer with really noticable chocolate character but the alcohol is really overwhelming, almost like its got a shot of cheap vodka.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2007 200th rating!!!....Bottle 07...aroma is malty, with chocolate and a bit of toffee...foam texture reminds me of Styrofoam...rich brown body with brown sugar head...sweet and dandy like candy...a most delicate balance of foam v.s. palate...coffee with a bitter presentation of fruitiness intermingled as well...de dolle as always, yum...this beer is alive...it taunts me to drink more...it pleads, and I give in

My 1000th beer, I picked this up whilst in Norfolk last month from beers of Europe. This is dark, in fact its just very black with a big tan head that continues bubbling from the bottle like an erupting volcano even when three quarters of the beer appears to be in the glass. Great cofffee and liquorice notes rise from a slightly sweeter than expected nose. The first sip saw these two aromas also very much in evidence in the taste but with nutty and fruity flavours as well also being quite dry with a definate soft tanginess to it. I really enjoyed this but having this beer four beers into the night and with a chilli con carne Im left with a feeling that I didnt quite do it justice, so may have to return to it again one day, still its only a number onto the 2,000th now.

Dark black color with a huge frothy tan head.  Very strong aroma of chocolate, licorice, fruits (blueberries, dates, raisins, cherries), malt, and brown sugar.  Intense flavors of dried fruit, cocoa, coffee, sugar, roasted malt, and some sour musty notes.  I was pretty amazed by the complex array of flavors.  Mouthfeel was soft and smooth, and the finish was quite dry and acidic.  Great stuff, I look forward to more of these!
11.2 oz bottle. Pours black with a full foam brown head. Chocolatey and sweet aroma. Taste of coffee, chocolate and cherrys with a dry finsih.

An interesting beer.  Not my favorite by any means.  It seems like what smhncabot said, a dubble and a stout mixed together.  
I get a lot of alcohol out of this beer, but I also get a nice fruitiness to it.  I am conflicted as to whether I like this beer for how different it is, and whether I think that the alcohol is too much of a detraction to rate it any higher.  
The coffee notes are present, but I do not find them overwhelming by any means.  Call that my American taste buds if you will....

pours dark with mahogany highlights.  aroma is spicy and fruity with some choco/exrpesso notes behind.  taste fruity/spicy as you would expect from belgium with hints of dark fruit caramel malt, expresso, and chocolate.  the later two flavors are mostly expressed in the finish.  this is really a blend between abbey dubbel and stout but still good.

Bottle. Creamy light borwn excellent fully lasting head. Brown colour. Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Really great. Moderate bitter flavor but too powerfull coffee-notes. Long finish. Oily palate but way too fizzy.

Bottle @ Brugs Beertje, Brugge. A big light chocolate head over a dark brown, opaque body. Sweetish and roasty dark malt aroma. Scents of dried dark fruits, rye-bread and cocoa. Taste is very powerful dominated by dry dark malts, bitter chocolate, black coffee, and a dry almost tart bitterness. Notes of fruitcake, alcohol and spices. Full body. Warming and  mouthfilling. Smooth and creamy texture. Long bitter end.  Very nice.

Pours black with a THICK brown head. The aroma on this is pretty sweet which actually surprised me a bit. Taste is much the same, even though the roasted and nutty notes are there I get alot of sweetness from this stout and I cant say I like it all that much. Mouthfeel is very thin and lacking. I will say this one dissapointed me slightly, I dont expect my stouts to be over sweet and this one certainly was IMO.

Poured a semi-opaque creamy black color with a nougat colored head. Espresso, citrus, spice, smoke, light chocolate, slightly alcoholic, malty, a hint of caramel sweetness in the aroma. Really tastes like a cross between a Belgian ale and an imperial stout.. and whoa, its delicious. Flavors of coffee, roasted malt, sweet chocolate/candy. Bright, well balanced, bitter in the most perfect way. Mouthfeel is too thin for a stout, but is good for what it is. Dammit, this beer is amazing.
Pours an opaque black with a brown head.  Aroma is malty with some fruity notes.  Flavor is roasted malts, with some fruity raisin notes.

Lots of roasted malt and some nice chocolate in the aroma.Pours black with a medium tan head.Lots of creamy chocolate and some big roasted malt dominated the flavor.Full mouthfeel with a very smooth chocolate finish.
Tap.  Black beer with a fine light head.  Complex flavor.  Fruity, coffee, licorice flavor.  Little fizzy and well balanced.

Bottle. Pours a dark black with a large long lasting tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma initialy is acidic, then the roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, and caramel come through. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, a hint of licorice, and acidic. Almost like a tart Pannepot. One of the most tasty Forien Stouts ever.

Slightly funky, tart, vinous and roasty aroma. Spicy yeast and hops give this a much different take on stout, although there is an underlying peanut brittle base that Ive come to equate with certain PNW stouts. The pour on this is fantastic, with a large, super thick and solid head that seriously goes absolutely nowhere for 10 minutes. Even rising above the top of my snifter, I could tilt the glass 45 degrees and have no spillage. Kick ass!

Flavor is smooth, chalky and roasty, less of the funkiness notable in the aroma -- in fact, none at all. In fact, the flavor is pretty much just that of a normal stout. Surprisingly subdued for a beer of "imperial" proportions (9% abv). Nice brew.

Bottle. Pours a nice black colour with a big light brown head. Sweet aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavour of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, coffee, alcohol and dried fruits. Roasty finish. Very tasty stout!
(bottle) very large dark tan head, no lace. Somewhat faint aroma of malt and coffee. Flavor is roast malt/espesso, dark wood, alcohol in the finish. Good, But I wasnt overwhelmed.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 bottled. So damn tastey, Im gonna make this brief so I can get back to the drinkin - roast coffee, dark chocolate bomb, creamy, picnic bar, nuts and caramel and baci italian espresso burnt wood bbq YUM.

Holy crap, the single most reactive head Ive ever seen. The second it hit the snifter it exploded, I had like an inch and a half of liquid and like three and a half of head. Poured a dark black brew with a head that was brown creamy and already described in thickness, broke down fairly quickly and left very minimal lace.
